But that might be against the law to, so I won't ding them for that.  The churros were pretty good!!  And I do like that they try to be green with their to-go packages.
author: Dee H.

description:
Everything is prepared right before your eyes.  There's a reasonable chance your carne asada was grilled moments before you walked in the door.  The shrimp plates are delicious. Tasty guacamole. Friendly hard-working staff working the endless assembly line of customers.

For years their humungous stick-to-the-ribs burritos were my standard meal-on-the-run.  Different Taquerias have their plusses and minuses.  But like a reliable Ford pickup or pair of old boots, Pancho Villa never fails to deliver if what you need is a solid tasty dose of fresh mexican flavors and convenience.
author: Kimbro B.

description:
Pros
-not too salty
- high quality ingredients
-good agua frescas

Cons
- Too pricey. Over $9 for a super burrito? Give me a break. I get a bigger and better tasting burrito from La Corneta Taqueria...and it's cheaper there.
- somewhat bland because spices on meats are lacking
author: Angus H.

description:
I love Pancho VIlla's Tacos. I always get the grilled chicken, or the Verde chicken (which is boiled and more flavorful and soft), with salsa and guac. I don't really order anything else, so I can not really recommend the burritos or what not.

But C'mon, really, Its Mexican food! Think authenticity, and order some tacos!

5 reasons Pancho Villa is my go to Taqueria:

1. Location 

2. Reliable quality

3. Vegetarian options for my health conscious buds 

4. Spicy salsa and guacamole!

5. That kid with the man hands (Photo 7) is amazing to watch, so fast with the chopping!
author: Kate R.

description:
I've been repeatedly disappointed with Pancho Villa's burritos, especially when sober.  I haven't tried anything else, so just based on burritos I give it 2.5 stars.

Pros
Takes credit cards
Line moves quickly
Great selection of aguas frescas

Cons
Expensive (a super burrito is over $8, that's BS)
Cheese is not melted in your burrito
Overall seasoning/flavor is nothing special
No Tapatio/real hot sauce

I felt like I paid way too much for a mediocre burrito.  The reason the line moves quickly is that they don't take the time to melt the cheese as they heat the tortilla before adding the rest of the ingredients.  The meat wasn't bad but none of the ingredients are especially flavorful.

The salsa bar seems great at first, with ample access to a variety of salsas, but they're all pretty weak, and there's no Tapatio or other hot sauce anywhere.

Maybe Pancho Villa's other foods are better,but in this area you can get better burritos for less money.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Good, but not great. The place is clean, they are open late and they make food quickly. I judge places by their ability to make a carne asada burrito. Theirs was good, but I couldn't find any salsa that was hot enough or didn't contain cilantro.

Speaking of cilantro, why do certain taquerias insist on putting cilantro in everything. I don't like cilantro! I know I'm not the only one! Cilantro haters unite!
author: Jordan M.

description:
I think they need to change the name to Pancho Villa Factory!  Those workers are like clockwork!

Went there last night after boozing it up at the Elite event...surprisingly dead.   No line at all, goooooooooooooooooooooaaaaaaaaaaaaaaal!

Two super chicken tacos was more than enough food.  Be forewarned, the salsa verde is SPICY!  Wasn't expecting that much of a kick, but it was good nonetheless.

I won't say this is my favorite Taqueria in The Mission, but it's always reliably bueno!
author: Melanie N.

description:
This is one of my favorite Mexican food places in San Francisco!  Every time I am in the Mission, I make every effort to get there.

My faves include the super chicken quesadillas, prawn burrito, prawn tacos, and red snapper tacos.   Their super chicken quesadillas are so huge that I end up taking leftovers home regardless of the hunger.  I am in love with their seafood choices since the seasoning and freshness is like no other.  The tacos are perfect in portion while the burritos are pretty big.  Whichever I choose to eat, I top it off with my favorite aguas fresca, the limon (lemon-lime).  Too bad their largest size is not large enough, as I would get it by the gallon if I could.  On occasion, I will get a Mexican cookie and eat it later - very tasty.

If there is a line out the door, no problem.   At the most a 5 minute wait!  The place is run very efficiently and service is very quick.  Plus it's fun to watch the guy at the grill preparing the meat while you decide your order.
author: Janet H.

description:
I have no idea why people like this place so much.
Back when I was new to San Francisco and hadn't fully realized what a Godless hellhole the Mission is, I used to pop by here on occasion for burritos before or after a long night of partying.

The food is edible, and tastes OK, but the ambiance is sterile and uninviting, and there are places that cost half as much and serve much better food within a block or two.

I know some people like the fact that there's a security guard, but it creeps me the hell out. 
None of the other taquerias need a security guard, so why does Pancho Villa? 
Do people get shanked here or something?
Oh god! I bet they do!
What's that on the floor? 
Is it salsa, or is it blood?
author: James C.

description:
The food is perfectly okay. The menu has all the standard items you'd typically find in a Mission taqueria--chile relleno, whole or refried pinto and black beans, tofu, churro, agua fresca, horchata, etc. There is a serve-yourself salsa bar with about 5 different sauces which all tend to be too salty. 

I would have given them 3.5 stars if it weren't for the ordering experience which goes something like this:

Poncho Villa associate: Next.
Me: I'll have a regular burrito with black beans, rice, and cheese to go.
PVA: What kind of beans?
Me: Black.
PVA: Okay, you want burrito with black beans and cheese. You want rice?
Me: Yes.
PVA: Super or regular?
Me: Regular.
PVA: For here or to go?
author: keith s.

description: First off Pancho Villa Taqueria has been a San Francisco Mission District favorite for YEARS!!!  But, haters will be haters!  The food is excellent and the people have always been friendly.  Gary don't let them get you down.  Keep on doin' your thing and let the food speak for itself.  Also, Miguel needs a thumbs up for his customer service.
author: Martha D.

description:
This place boasts a well run Mexican Food Production/ Consumption Line.  Just walking in you see lines and lines of people.  Line #1 is the customer line, which I estimate to reach over 45 people at one time.  Fortunately this line moves fast.   Why?  Because line #2, the food production line is very efficient.  The team on this line can quickly fill quesadilla, burritos, nachos, and any other orders quickly.

Now what about food?  Well given the long lines, it is a sign that the food is more than edible.  I liked my chili verde chicken quesadilla.
author: Alan T.

description:
So this is kind of an odd review for me, since I've never actually eaten at Pancho Villa Taqueria.  The place could be the next Ritz-Carlton, or your local dumpster, and I'd have no idea.  So this review's purely about food.

For 2 weeks in a row, my company's ordered Wednesday lunch from PVT via waiter.com.  It certainly isn't cheap, with their 15% markup, but what you're getting is 20-odd burritos made fresh and hot to order, labeled ACCURATELY for the owner, boatloads of pico de gallo (spelling??) and a monstrous bag of chips that just came out of the fryer (by the time it arrives the white bag is completely translucent).

2 weeks in a row now, PVT has been a big hit - and to keep 20 people with 20 opinions happy, that's no small feat.

Here's my tip: order 2 tacos instead of a burrito.  It's half the price and probably the same amount of food...on the tacos, the meat to topping ratio is heavily weighted toward meat.  good stuff.
author: brian w.

description:
Pluses
Great food
Great price
Fast service
Some of the best salsa

Minuses
Bad neighborhood
Hard to find free parking
author: Brando Calrissian ..

description:
Once upon a time, hubby and I helped our friend pick out a suit for an interview.  Friend was overjoyed and offered to buy us dinner at Pancho Villa.  I didn't have the heart to tell my friend that I was trying out a no-carb regime in order to lose the last "five or ten pounds" (note- I've been trying to lose this last "five or ten pounds" for a year- but, whatever).

Well, the low/no-carb thing lasted about five seconds because once I saw the burritos, I caved. Hubby had a quesadilla and I had a shrimp burrito. Hubby, friend, wifey of friend, and I split some cookies and churros for desert. 

In the end, Pancho Villa=bueno.
No-carbs= malo.
author: Kayla N.

description:
Dear Pancho Villa Taqueria, 

I can't imagine getting a better meal for $5 anywhere in the universe. If loving your food so much were a crime, then put me on death row for being a burritophile, and make my last meal your Veggie Super Burrito (extra hot, black beans, and smoky chili sauce on the side.) I wish I could send everyone one for christmas, but I don't think the US Post would look kindly on that.  Any of my friends who visit town are going to have to walk down the street with me to get one.

I'm not a picky chooser of Mission mexican food.  Others on here are more selective, but Pancho Villa is perfect by me.

I recently moved to town, and until I came here, I had never had salsa as good as the many choices at their bar.  

A few "minuses":

-There is often a 10 minute wait for food.  Last time I went, it gave me a chance to make friends with a girl who had an art portfolio under her arm for me to comment about.  Nothing wrong with being patient and interacting with human beings instead of the drive-thru life.

-The seating looks a bit crowded and not perfectly comfy, but I get take-out anyways.

After I taunted some friends on the East coast about the good food here and how they can't get any, they proved me wrong.  Darn, I though these burritos were an exclusive privilege for people lucky enough to live nearby, but then they told me about the alameda-weehawken burrito tunnel.   Now I know why the line is long.

http://idlewords.com/2007/04/the_alameda-weehawken_burrito_tunnel.htm
author: Pat L.

description: I've been nothing but pleased with this taco haven in the Mission. They have happy hour from 3-5 and the tacos are all $1. That means you can have a veritable feast for $5 or under. Free chips come with. Nice salsa bar selection. Good vegetarian taco and burrito offerings. Fast service. A+
author: Mr. E.

description:
My favorite taqueria in the City.  They have the best burritos.  My favorite is the carne asada.  Chicken is good too.
Their other dishes are also tasty, but the burritos really standout.  
As with other Pancho Villa stores, the fresh salsa bar offers a variety of salsas to complement your food.
author: Boba P.

description: I can't believe I have been coming here for so long and have not tried anything else except for the super burritos. For the first time yesterday, I tried the super veggie quesadilla. THE BEST QUESADILLA I HAVE EVER ATE!!!! It was cooked perfectly, creamy and tangy inside with just the right amount of heat. They also cut it up into four square pieces to make it easier to eat. Very filling for a lunch meal. By the way - the burritos here also the best in town!
author: Alex C.

description: Was super delicious, amazing service and speedy. Delicious and glad discovered a hidden gem.
author: Kat A.

description:
There's a lot of taquerias in SF and the bay area for that matter but I'm in love with a particular one in Millbrae for their burritos.  Millbrae however isn't the most convenient to travel to for just a burrito.  That said, I've been looking for something similar locally.  I have just taken a closer step to matching it up.
The flavor and textures are fresh and moist as the fore-mentioned.  I cannot stand a dry burrito.  The filling (rice and beans) was a little heavy of a ratio next to the meat (carne asada)  but not bad.  I didn't personally order my own or I would have told them , "light on the rice".  But it was fine.  There was a salsa bar with extensive salsas and condiments including lime wedges and extra cilantro which are a "must" for me.  
I plan on returning for a second visit to try more.  What got my notice was a free coupon for the burrito on HeardAbout.com for the reg size; which I upgraded to the "especial" (+cheese and guac.) for an added buck.  Went on a weekday during lunch hour, it was packed but ran efficiently.  Line + order + wait time was maybe 12min.
author: John W.

description: Came here for dinner after many years away  and was so disappointed. Ordered the especial carne asada burrito, a dish that was only special if you like rice. I ate just half the burrito, in part because I found (no exaggeration) 3 small pieces of carne asada in it and a trace amount of guacamole. Not a fluke -- my husband ordered the same item and found 6 pieces of meat in his burrito. Giving Pancho Villa 2 stars because of the great salsa bar and because my daughter's chicken burrito was good.
author: Emma G.

description: This is probably my favorite Mexican restaurant on the planet! I'm a vegetarian, so I love places that offer flavorful refried beans that are not cooked in Lard and offer whole wheat tortillas. All of the ingredients are super fresh as well. The line can sometimes get long and parking in the Mssion can be a bit tricky. Overall, this an affordable, delicious Mexican option.
author: Angela Y.

description: Best burritos ever!!! I've been going here since I was five or six and they have Ben a staple in my life! They catered my moms college graduation in 1997, my bridal shower in 2011, my graduation in 2012 and will be catering my baby shower in April! Even though I live in Concord now I still take  bart out just to get a burrito from here. And the d course I buy three more to take home for the week.
author: Alexandria T.

description: Their al pastor doubles as a hallucinogen and weight loss product (worst food poisoning ever).  However, they get two stars for the Mexican drag queens that sashay around the place wearing 5-inch pumps at 11pm.
author: Victoria G.

description:
Wanna get run over by a mariachi while they sing your favorite corrido?  Do it here...cuz at least you get a semi-decent burrito with a plethora of salsa choices.  

Pico de Gallo "Very Hot"....whooeee!!  Sinuses clear up with one chip full of that stuff.  And I do mean FULL...none of this wussy dipping it into the salsa juice w/ no actual salsa on it.  Scoop it, load it up and shove the whole thing in your mouth!!!  

That's the REAL way to eat chips and salsa!
author: Jay H.

description:
After my workout at the Valencia Muscle Gym, I'll stop by here to pick up a salad to bring home.
YES...this place makes excellent salads.

Pancho villa is accessible via Bart (get off on 16th), and 1 block from the 14, 49, 26, 22 bus lines.

I always order the chicken caesar salad. Ok, its not the typical caesar salad ok...no croutons or parmesan cheese.

It's really lettuce, tomatoes, marinated carrots, onions, cilantro, and a massive amount of freshly grilled chicken (they don't skimp) and a side of caesar dressing.  This is alot of salad...so it's really good for two meals.

Try the large Fresca. It's a strawberry drink ...homemade and delicious.
author: Charlene C.

description:
I crave the Molcajete salsa and the Camarones al Chile Chipotle above all else here, but you cannot go wrong with any dish. 

Been frequenting this joint for almost two decades and though I live in the East Bay I'll make up people to pick up at SFO to swing through and grab a bite.
author: Shashi J.

description:
The best burrito I've ever had! I dream about this place and would move to SF because of it (I almost did). However, when I go, I try to eat here as often as possible.

Go, eat and enjoy the atmosphere and community!
author: Garry C.

description:
As Alex B. said, "When I think of Mission-style SF burritos, this is the gold standard."

Their burritos are so good, they have to keep an armed guard by the door. Some people will say he's there to protect the cash register or the customers, but no: He is there to safeguard the most precious of all San Francisco's meaty treasures.

I don't think I've ever had a less-than-amazing burrito at Pancho Villa. The horchata tastes a little artificial, but this is a small grievance. They have a great salsa bar and tortilla chips come free with the burrito, just like they should.
author: Kevin R.

description:
Holy taqueria! SF Yelpers have this spot covered! In fact, there are a hell of a lot of Yelpers in the Bay Area... dang. Nothing to add here, but I'll quote some of the highlights below: 

"Best burrito in San Francisco" - Actually, beats anything NY has to offer, too, but no big surprise there.

"Much cleaner and less sketchy than Cancun" - So is SF in general... for the most part. D-oh, they meant the other taqueria, not the Mexican tourist trap!

"Great place to get a beer and burrito. But not a date." - Don't knock it, pal.

"This is THE spot for a munchie-run in-between your second and third bar hop of the evening" - Oh, joy. Just when we thought we had a refuge from the drunken lunkheads in the Valencia Street bars... Hey, didn't you hear? Cancun is a much better destination! Really.

"heaven on a plate" - sing it out, Kate.

"Even though I live further south these days, I always make it a point to swing by Pancho Villa's whenever I'm in San Francisco." - Indeed, second stop... Weekend Cake at Sweet Inspirations!

"I cry when I think of this place because here in NY you can't get a good burrito." - Yup. Tears on my plate full of flatbread instead of a tortilla, too, Tina.
author: Dan B.

description: Amazing! Great value and atmosphere in the Mission.
author: Sandra T.

description:
I love Pancho Villas.  I usually order a baby burrito, carne asada y arroz con aguacate.  Y les pido la misma salsa que ponen para los chips metido en mi burro.  Hijole, !que pinche delicioso!  Regularmente me gusta ir con mis cotrabajadores, y a veces ordenamos dos o tres de las cenas y comamos como puerquisimos.  Con una Corona, que rica.

Believe me, the baby burrito is enough for anyone.  But if you want more for later, get the redwood log sized super burrito.  Friendly service, great smiles, great aguas frescas, etc., etc., etc.
author: Randy F.

description:
Favorite Burrito in the Bay Area (grew up in LA, where the Mexican restaurants are on a whole 'nother level) , huge variety of meats, always cooked just right, no skimping on the sour cream and guacamole is frrrrrresh. I also appreciate the large variety of agua frescas and their salsa bar that's got something for everybody. \

The line is always long, but it usually moves pretty fast (it's the city folks, get used to it). The often cited El Farlito is pretty good, but toe to toe, in terms of quality and taste, Pancho Villa wins in my book.
author: Raf Z.

description:
Meh. My meal here was good, for sure, but I don't see what the hullabaloo about this place is.

Oh wait, yeah, I do. This is the spot for people who find your average Mission tacqueria a little too dark and dirty. Pancho Villa is so bright and clean I thought I was about to have surgery. The lines are long and the prices a dollar (or 15-20%) more expensive than any of the several dozen shops nearby. That's not because they are bigger or better, you're paying for flourescent transparency in the cooking process. Me, I trust my favorite spots to do right and I don't worry about being able to see. 

This spot does get an extra star for one reason: they simply out-spiced me. I'm not some gung-ho take-a-shot-of-jalapeño juice masochist, but I like the spice. Well, not this time. I don't know if it was the green salsa or whatever they put on my quesadilla but I was nearly knocked out by the experience. I'm talking sweating, gasping, going to the counter for milk hot. That's not easy to do, so well played, Pancho Villa. I'll still go down the street and save my money.
author: Ian M.

description: I can always tell a great Mexican restaurant by it's refried beans. This is a great place!  Very busy so be ready.
author: Mr. K.

description:
Right. We heard it all before. The prices are just way too "high". "the lines are too longgggg"...

SUCK IT UP!

THIS IS THE ONLY BURRITO SPOT THAT ROCKS FACE IN 5729845723573247 DIFFERENT WAYS!

So stop complaining people, because you know you will be back to shell out $25 on a mission burrito meal (2 burritos, and 2 mexican cokes @ 2.50 each.. and a churro!).
author: LiZANN S.

description:
Man, this is a place which if it weren't around anymore, I wouldn't know what to do.  I don't know how they do it, but their burritos are beyond compare.  They also make a really mean shrimp and steak quesadilla.  The blindingly white walls give it sort of an antiseptic feel, and they have a lot of tacky stuff up on them, but that hardly matters. They are usually pretty good at taking down phone orders to go, and though the lines are often long, they generally move quickly.  I don't know of any place that people swear by more than Pancho Villa.  Never have found a better taqueria, anywhere.

PS:  Their new store on the Embarcadero doesn't hold a candle to this one, the original.
author: moosedog i.

description: So many burrito places in SF- this place always has a huge line. The strong point is the great chips and best green sauce I have ever had. Also, they never skimp on the meat on their burritos. Great mix of people eating in this place too!
author: Jim B.

description:
The burrito I had was not as good as the ones I got in San Mateo's. The burrito was kinda dry and it lacked flavor. Where's the sauce???? Took one bite and was not impressed. I've had better tasting burritos where my reaction was like, "OMG!!! This burrito's taste is mouth-wateringly, earth-shatteringly DELICIOUS!"

The pineapple agua fresca wasn't that great either. =( And there was a gentleman who randomly walked in and started playing his guitar, serenading everyone in the restaurant. I don't know if that's his job or whatever but it's kinda annoying when you're having a conversation with someone and then getting interrupted mid-way by him asking for a donation in Spanish.

Umm....yeah....I wouldn't be coming back here. Food wasn't that good and I don't like people bothering me when I've had a long day at work and just wanted to enjoy dinner with a companion.

The prices are a little too expensive....$9 for a burrito? WTF?!
author: V M.

description: Some of the best sopas I've ever tasted in SF for a good price. Lines go by fast and horchata is on point and isn't watered down. Authentic mexican here. Go now, just leave 10 min before planned to figure out parking because it can be a gamble.
author: Kevin O.

description:
Definitely a party in your mouth!

Prawns on prawns on prawns.

Prawn tacos are amazing here. Great fresh salsa bar too.
author: G M.

description:
de puta madre. rico, barato. interesante. escuche que beck toco aca hace  tiempo. comida autentica mexicana? no. rica? si.

i saw two guys dressed up in turkey costumes being chased down the street by a furious chef with a gigantic plastic knife in his hand. it was quite a scene i must say. it definitely added flavor to the colorful night.

i went the night before thanksgiving.
author: JoseLuis A.

description: The lines at Pancho Villa on a Saturday are long, and the menu is dizzying.  Twice now I have experienced the madness of this taqueria, complete with security guards.  Twice now I have ordered the carnitas super burrito with a large watermelon aqua fresca.  Pancho Villa is always consistent with their service and taste.  I will try something different next time.  The tacos look tasty!
author: Camille K.

description:
It's good when I'm in the area and starving.  I don't go out of my way to come here, but it's good enough.  Al pastor burritos have been hit or miss...1 time I really loved it, the next couple times were eh.  I guess it depends on how hungry I am.

+1 for the mariachi dude in the back, and for the door-opener.  "Gracias!"
author: T. O.

description: I really like this place.  It has a cafeteria feel but it's good food, especially for the price, and very nice service even when it's packed, which is often.  I love, love their chile relleno and the tamales.
author: Sarah A.

description:
This is the best taqueria I've been to because it is big enough to handle the crowd. The line moves quickly, their kitchen is clean and their ingredients are fresh. You end up with great tasting food, and plenty of it, at a great price.

Some people complain about the seating, service, or parking, but considering that this is a counter-service taqueria in the mission, none of those cons warrant a point reduction.

I love this place!
author: Stephen L.

description:
So very hella goods (as the locals would probably say)!!!!!  I came here when I had a sudden craving for some good Mexican food.  I'd heard this was an awesome place to get it, so my brother and I cruised down to find out what the fuss was about.

They have a huge selection of stuff to choose from here.  It's like a Mexican kid trying to figure out which pan dulce they want from the bakery.  As usual, I always get something with carnitas, so I got myself a burrito with lots of stuff in.  So big!!  My brother got a steak and prawn one.  They were SO GOOD!!  It was like sex.  Ok, no it wasn't, but probably almost as good.  That's sorta sad now that I think about it ...

Anyway, the carnitas had a great flavor as did the rice and beans.  They had a big selection of salsas and chili if you wanted to add a little kick to your food.  My brother had some green chili and he was sweating, but liked it a lot.

I'd come back here again.  Being Mexican and coming from a town of Watsonville that has like 1000 taqarias, I'd had my fair share of the good and the bad.  But this is a great place to hit up when in the Mission for a good burrito.  Ya!
author: imelda j.

description:
The food here is great! There is, however, an issue with the service....read on for that. The dishes here are authentic and they use fresh, high quality ingredients. I have always felt that this is an elusive combination, so I was glad to find it here. 

The service is kind of lackluster and last time I was here they were actually pretty rude to my husband....long story, not worth telling. I will say that he and I ordered the exact same burrito (except mine had extra cheese) and when we left his was about half the size of mine. It would appear that the lady helping him, disliked him enough to majorly short him on his burrito. I think Pancho Villa knows they have the customers 'by the balls' cause the food is so dang good and the lines are almost always long. What I mean by this is that they don't feel descent, friendly customer service is necessary. Too bad......
author: Melissa S.

description:
So after another bust on our Monday night poker game, the rest of the guys and I decided to hit up a burrito joint. Like everyone said, their salsa's are great. All you can eat! I straight up took 10 cups of salsa for my one little burrito. So what if I freeload, I'm Asian.

If you want a burrito before Midnight, come to this place. It's well lited, clean, and even have a security guard to protect the crack heads from your food. 

Salsa verde, I love you. I will come back next week.
author: David L.

description:
Pancho Villa is a fine taqueria at which you can get a filling, tasty burrito. It isn't the best, but it's far from the worst, and it's reliable. You can choose from many different kinds of meat, and in typical SF taqueria fashion, you also select what you want in the way of a tortilla, beans, salsa, and extras like cheese and guacamole. Can't speak to the non-burrito menu items, alas.

The restaurant is spacious, particularly for a taqueria, with high ceilings and white walls. Many place to sit -- you probably don't want to sit on 16th Street to eat your food.There's often (always?) a security guard by the door to let in paying customers and keep out riffraff. No table service, of course, and the people behind the counter are quick, polite, but not super-friendly -- they don't have time to be.

A good option. Sibling of El Toro.
author: Tara M.

description:
After reading about this restaurant on one of the travel sites, I decided to read what the other yelpers thought, and I'm so glad I checked it out!  This is the best burrito I have ever had!

I actually checked out La Taqueria first but so glad I came here because this place by far is cleaner and nicer than the other taquerias in Mission.  They have a lot of vegetarian options, and so many meat choices and toppings.  I had the chile verde chicken which is a stewed kind of chicken and it makes such a difference from the dried out grilled chicken in NY.

SOOO YUMMY!  Why can't NY have this kind of Mexican food?!!
author: C A.

description:
I live for a tofu ranchero taco with guacamole. No chips please.

Okay, I admit my real craving is for a burrito but they're so big they reduce the rest of my day to a food coma wallow on the couch...so with the taco I shall go. It's just safer that way.
author: Penelope C.

description:
I used to work with a lot of Latinos before and this is THE place they used to always tell me to check out for a Great Burrito.  So I did and have tried it a couple of times.  They are good.  All their ingredients are very fresh.  And it seems like it's not as messy to eat as many other places.  

However, their prices are up there compared to alot of their nearby competition.  It's one of those places that knows they are the Best and they charge accordingly because they know they can...  

But if you've never been here, then you must at least try.....

HAPPY HOUR DEETS: 
M - Fr 3p - 5p
$1 taco's and $2 beers
author: Mark W.

description:
BBB always sabotages my BBM

Bloated Burrito Body..............Bikini Body Mission.
That's how I feel after I dine at Pancho Villa....and that's why I give it 4 stars, instead of 5.  Also because those little stools are dang uncomfortable. 

Anyways, I always experience BBB even though I usually don't order a burrito...but much of it is the same food, prepared in different ways.  Anyways, I really like the tacos...camorones.  That's shrimp for all you gringos.  I tried the quesadilla for the first time this past weekend and it was yummy.  With camarones, of course.

I only get the fire roasted salsa.  One of the other salsas tasted ketchup-y to me.  And the spicy salsa they use to prepare the food is SDS (Super Duper Spicy) so stick with the mild if you don't want flames shooting out of your butt.  

If you're a first timer, order any thing that has the prefix "super."  Be forewarned that if you order a "super" anything, it's Hola BBB and Adios BBM.
author: happy t.

description:
This place blows. This is the kind of taqueria that people who just moved to SF like to frequent and then tell their friends back home in Des Moines that they "hang at this super cool, legit Mexican joint in the Mission."

Any Mexican joint that has a grilled vegetable medley-stuffed burrito is NOT legit.
author: kdub ..

description:
Pancho Villa raised their prices.  Probably to pay for that fancy new menu they got (this is sarcasm--I understand that times are hard and that food prices are skyrocketing).  

But $7 for a regular (meat, beans, rice and salsa) burrito?  Big time CON.

But I still love their burritos.  What can I say?
author: Kevin H.

description: Clearly the 1274 reviewers prior to me never had an actual burrito before eating at this place. As the 1275th reviewer, it is incumbent upon me to save future victims. Don't eat here. Food is bland and overcooked. Meaning, it sucks.
author: Simcha K.

description: Expensive like tou have know idea, but it has exellent food
author: Wally B.

description: I have been eating here for the past 7 years and I love it! The staff here are awesome, sweet and always consistent in quality of the food! The portions are quite big and definitely filling. When I first started eating here I'd eat half a burrito and save the rest for the next day - two meals for $4-6! Now I go a little less often because I live further away, but I find it to be my #1 taqueria in San Francisco. I'm a native San Diegan and I know what mexican food should taste like. It's right here at "Pancho's" as I like to call it :)
author: Caitlin V.

description:
Oh man....I tried to go to the El Tonayense Taco Truck (recommended by yelpers), but they were closing down (around 10pm). So I tried to check on yelp to see what was a good Taqueria. My wife and I had tacos de lengua (beef tongue), carnitas (pork), and carna asada (steak). We decided to get the dinner version. comes with salad, beans, rice, and tortillas. The portions were huge and also the price. It cost $28 for the two dinners (including two bottle waters). For a Taqueria, that's kinda pr icy. The food was so so. Not good enough for me to come back again. I don't understand why it was so busy? The service was average. 

To give a little background... I grew up in a small farming town in the Central Valley, that had quite a few good Taquerias and taco trucks. I know what good Mexican food should taste like; grew up with a Mexican baby sitter that would make tortillas by hand and tamales for Christmas. 

I'm a little hesitant to try El Tonayense Taco Truck, since my yelpers FAILED. Can someone introduce me to a good Taqueria that's not going to break the bank?
author: Ken Y.

description:
Pretty darn good mexican food for Mission hipsters and business men & women who are willing to fork 10$ for a burrito like God intended. 

It's gotten pricey since the good ol' days when the clientele were skaters and actual Mexican people. But then again, this situation sounds like everything else in the f*ckin Mission / Valencia area.
author: Tomas V.

description:
Being from Southern California and a Mexican American, Mexican food is not a luxury for me.  I loathe the wannabe joints, ie Taco "Hell" and the such..that is NOT Mexican food people.  I was first introduced to Pancho's by the words..."They have the best salmon tacos!" This was no fable.  Not only are the tacos at bargain price, but they overload you on fish.  Since then Pancho's is my home away from home. While I miss mom's cooking, if you want true, home style Mexican...go to Pancho's. The people are great, and as you can see by the crowds, there's always groups in there at all times.

They also like to promote local artist's work, and hey, who doesn't like to eat yummy burritos/tacos and look at some eclectic art. Hands down...the best Mexican joint in the city!
author: Danielle A.

description:
This is probably one of the best Burrito joints in the city. Mission area could be interesting, but once you are inside, you will feel differently. The place is very clean and has security guard to make sure *interesting* people won't bother your lunch. There are so many things going on inside the restaurant, but you need to stay focus and tell them exactly what you want..... especially at cashier's time. There will be 10 burritos and they need to find yours quickly.

Great food = check
Good price = check
Clean = check
Fast = check

Everything is very fresh and good quality good. I truly enjoy this restaurant.

One option is to take BART and get off at 16th and mission station. Get out and turn left. It will be half a block away.
author: Susanto I.

description:
What are yall inhaling?

Too inconsistent for my blood.  Plus, the "good"  burritos aren't all that anyway.

For years, a buddy of mine swore by Pancho Villa.  I told him that they kinda sucked.  He insulted me for it every time.  Then one day I decided to give them a try and I met my buddy there.  As he asked me if I was ready to enter, a cloud of smoke crept out of his mouth.  His eyes were redder than a baboon's ass, and he smelled like he mud-wrestled a skunk.

Figures.
author: Pete M.

description:
Maybe the best burrito place in town. Fast and fresh. Real chips (not the ones out of the bag), good tortillas, fresh and fat-less meat. 

I always take visitors here for a great Burrito experience!

Warning - they just raised their prices! This week, I got a Super Prawn Burrito, Fresa Drink, and Churro for $15! Ouch!
author: Matt D.

description:
My review for Pancho Villa is long overdue!  I eat here whenever I can... whenever I'm running errands and passing by the mission, coming to this place is always satisfying!

This is probably the only place I know of where I can order a baby burrito and have it be the size of what is normally a large burrito!  It's cheap but its super duper good!  

I can eat here every day and not get bored...
author: Ramona D.

description:
It took moving to San Francisco to discover this great taqueria despite having a location right in my hometown.

My ineptitude aside, Pancho delivers with flavorful meats, generous portions, and a salsa/hot sauce bar which provides the perfect finishing touch to the delicious tortilla-wrapped goodness (my weakness for good hot sauce is a common theme).

I know it may exhibit the sterility of a chain restaurant and have the feel of a factory assembly line on the inside, but don't judge too quickly as it delivers some of the tastiest burritos in the Mission.
author: Drew W.

description:
This is kind of the end all be all of burrito joints in the Mission. Located right smack dab on 16th, this place has been synonymous with "mexican food" for as long I've been in the city (my whole little life.) That said, this is not my favorite, but the long lines (don't be hesitant - the staff is swift and friendly) speak volumes in terms of the preferences of the burrito thirsty. They make some damn good prawns here. I always though prawns sounded peculiar in a burrito, but Pancho Villa makes it work deliciously. 

This is probably the quintessential place to take someone out of the city for a damn good burrito. If you want to wow them with something a little different, I recommend Papalote.
author: haley d.

description:
Solid, friendly, and right there for you -- Pancho Villa won't knock your socks off, but it gets the job done.

Recommended? = Not really. It's fine, but there's not enough time in life for a "just fine" burrito, especially in the 16th and Mission zone.
author: Chris R.

description:
This place is the hangover spot in the Mission... 

It has got to be the best Mexican Taqueria in the city, and inexpensive to boot. Like a true Taqueria format they got hella condiments (variety of salsas, pico de gallo, limon, lemon, jalapenos and carrots, raddish etc) a full bar of stuff. I love the taco's! two tacos, a churro, and a cold beer and I'm out! always eat there when I'm in the Mission. 

Most of the times you gonna find a line, but ignore it, it moves fast, and it'll take you a while to read through the huge menu, everything you could want in Mexican food. Your server consults you on every step of burrito construction, and all the meats and other fillings are right in plain sight as you make your choices. 

PROS: great Mexican food, cheap 
CONS: waiting line
author: Branny J.

description: Nom nom nom. Everyting here is good! You could get vegetarian food and still be satisfied. I have yet to try their agua frescas or horchata which I do believe I need to do.
author: Mikhail K.

description: I liked their Al Pastor "meat only" burrito.  Included salsa.  Good chips.  Enjoyed the Al Pastor hot salsa at the salsa bar.  Clean place, efficient operation, good meat choices and fresh meat being grilled constantly made the place smell great.  Since I've accepted paying over $7 for a burrito in San Francisco of this quality (with guac, lettuce, tomato, and cheese, would have been $10), the price didn't bother me too much and I focused only on enjoyment of the taste and experience.
author: Marc S.

description: Everyone seems to love Pancho Villa; and for good reason--they do everything well and the folks there are willing to put together any Mexican concoction you can think of. The salsa bar is good and plentiful, chips are free flowing and there's all types of meat, seafood and veggie options for your tacos, burritos, tostadas or whatever else you can dream up. I particularly like the chili relleno. Stuff that bad boy into a burrito with some beans, salsa, etc. and even a jukie would choose this over their usual fix.
author: Brian J.

description:
Mm mm, fish taco good, nachos good, flan (I know, random) good. tons of people, meaning food is always fresh. Table turnover highly efficient.... 

Love this place!
author: Gabrielle C.

description: I've been here a couple times and I think it's average for Mexican food.  I have had their super burrito, their tacos, and their quesadillas and I would say some flavor was lacking in the dishes.  They are more known for their salsa and they have won awards for it, but I unfortunately only like getting the green salsa, so I cannot objectively evaluate their salsas.  But I can say the green salsa isn't anything special compared to what I have had from other places.  Overall, this place is average and I am sure there may be better places around the mission to get a Mexican food fix.
author: Lawrence E.

description: At 2pm, still packed with people. Had a super carnitas burrito - pretty tasty, but nothing that awesome...especially when there are tons of other Mexican places along the street. I do love the salsa bar they have.
author: Carol L.

description:
If you want a different kind of burrito try the prawn burrito.  They chuck half a dozen fresh prawns on the grill right in front of you - gave me the warm fuzzies - and then do the usual burrito stuffing thing. 

The place is very clean and the staff is memorable because of their great attitude.
author: Mamoon H.

description:
I'm no burrito expert and rarely eat it, but if I were to, this is where I  would go.  Definitely the best burrito joint in the city.  Don't let the long line fool you as it moves pretty quick.  The staff is friendly as well.

Since eating here, I've been eating burritos more and more.  Maybe once or twice a week.  There were a few places that I thought had good burritos that were close by my office but after my Pancho Villa experience, I've realized that those weren't good at all.  Craving a burrito but not wanting to travel too far, I stopped by Mexico Au Parc, which I use to like a lot and it wasn't all that good at all.  The steak was tasteless and bland, while at Pancho Villa, you can taste it with all its grilled glory.  The tortilla at Mexico Au Parc was thick and chewy, unlike PVs.  From now on, I'm going nowhere else for my burrito except for Pancho Villa.  

With them taking Orderahead, it makes grabbing food here even easier.
author: Milton W.

description: This place has delicious Mexican food and really good Horchata. While the Horchata was a bit on the sweet side, it was not watered down and was full of milky-ricey, cinnamony goodness. I got one super taco and it was loaded with stuff! What usually requires a good 2-3 tacos to fill me up took this one gigantic, overstuffed to do the trick. A definitely great place to enjoy some good, hearty Mexican food! It's a bonus that it's easy on the wallet.
author: Jing P.

description:
Me puede dar un Burrito con carnitas y con salsa picante, frijoles de la olla y guacamole por favor...Gracias!!  O!! Y tambien una horchata mediana...para comer aqui...gracias!!
Mmmm....tasty...(munching / eating noise....eating away)...Mmm...Buuurp!!  
Ahhh....that was good...pat the belly and roll myself out the door...
author: Karen B.

description:
Alrighty, so now that I'm livin' in SF, I'm on a hunt for authentic Mexican tacos. The real deal is two small tortillas, slightly oily from being heated on the grill with oil, your meat of choice topped with diced onions and chopped cilantro with a dash of salsa.

While I've been here before, I've usually been so drunk that I didn't really have my connoisseur hat on...i just wanted food in my belly like NOW ;-) So, last nite was different, although I was a bit buzzed from riding my bike for 2hrs and then eating only a few chips with 3 beers ;-) 

Any who, the first thing that struck me was that the tacos were $2.25, in my old hood, Redwood City,  the tacos were $1.19 and prepared as I described above. What I got at PV was two small steamed tortillas(ya need the oil man!) and a mountain of meat with some pico de gallo salsa on top. Well with the amount of meat they piled on there I would've just had two tacos. I understand that American like a lot of food, thus the obesity rates being on the rise, but I think they should make the tacos the traditional way and if some overweight Americano wants more food, then he can order more tacos. OK, OK, enough soapboxing. Sorry. But this is the food of my peeps and I don't like to see it bastardized.

So I order 4 tacos: al pastor, lengua, pollo asado, chile verde. The Chicken and al pastor were too dried out, but OMFG the lengua and chile Verde were off the hook! The meat was so tender it melted in your mouth. I even got my non-Mexican friend to try lengua tacos and he loved'em!

I do have to give PV major kudos for their salsas...good selection, tasty and spicy! Another nice touch is the fresh radishes, lemons, grilled jalapenos and chilies del arbol. Now that's authentic Mexican.

I also like the fact that their import beers are only $2.75...that's cheaper than the bars.

Last thing I dig about the place is that they always have local artists works up on the wall. The food is good-great, but the traditional-ness is a bit in question, but since the lengua and chile verde tacos wooed me, PV still gets 4.5 stars! I'll be back...drunk'n or not ;-)
author: isaias J.

description:
It's been a really long time since I've had good mexican food... like a really long time. I frequently crave good burritos and especially good carnitas, but when your only options are Chipotle and La Burrita, you stop wanting mexican food after a while...

This place has a great selection of dishes open til very late at night. Tacos, burritos, dinner plates, seafood, etc all at very reasonable prices. Everything comes in large portions with a salsa bar that offers many different levels of spice and can be combined in whatever way you desire. Their burritos are large and flavorful with a decent amount of vegetarian options, the carne asada is tender, and the carnitas are just right... not to salty and not dried out. 

For about $10 I got a dinner plate of carnitas that came with rice, beans, salad (that's basically lettuce onion and tomatoes) and corn of flour tortillas with chips. There was enough food to have a substantial dinner yesterday and lunch today. Great amount of great food that held up in the refigerator and still tasted fantastic today.

The restaurant is bigger than many taquerias with enough seating. The line is always out the door, but it moves fast and you always get your food in a timely manner. Be patient. Pancho villa is totally worth it. Will have to return to try their fish and prawn tacos, because those looked great too.

-1 star for the fact that I have to walk by crack addicts to get there. That's the only downside I suppose.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Pancho Villa is like the first guy you sleep with after being in a long relationship... "So THIS is what I've been missing!"

While visiting San Fran, my boyfriend and I were given a list of Mexican places to try since "you can't find a decent burrito anywhere in NYC."

We stopped in practically right when the place opened, and about 10 minutes after we ordered there was a line out the door. The prices were really great- only $20 for two carne asada burritos, nachoes, and two sodas. There was no way I could eat the whole meal, but you bet your ass I tried. the steak was tender, the black beans were delicious, and although the rice was also amazing, I was glad it didn't take up the entire burrito.

I'm ashamed to have ever 'enjoyed' East-Coast Mexican food.
author: Amber S.

description:
This place is the real deal for Mexican food in the City.  Authentic as it comes, coke in a bottle, good chips, better salsa.

There is a bit of confusion as you're finding a cook to make your food, but the line of food allows you to see what really gets your mouth watering.  

I had a chicken burrito (like I have everywhere!) and it was certainly one of the better ones around.  The nachos were monstrous, and fed the whole table of 4.  

Price was it was a bargain for the amount of food.
author: Zakk D.

description:
My favorite pico de gallo in the world is from here.  It's not too spicy, a little salty, and you can really taste the cilantro.  Perfect!

The food is also great, portions are HUGE and filling.  Don't be put off by the long line they get sometimes, it moves quickly, they have a unique and efficient setup for serving their customers.  The only problem is you usually can't find a table, so bring a friend who can wait for a table while you stand in line and order.
author: Gusty S.

description:
I never saw the appeal of this place. There's lines out the door, why?
I ordered the carne asada burrito and the man behind the counter is goin off on that poor beef with a cleaver like a liberal on Dick Cheney. Jeez I don't want hash!!! Also the one thing that always creeped me out were the little jam jars of salsa on the tables. NO WAY!! The one thing I found though was no matter how long the lines you could always find a table. The art could be pretty good on the walls or at least it used to be. I always prefered La Cumbre, the meat wasn't hacked into pieces the size of confetti. The horchata is pretty good not watery like some places.
author: .James A.

description:
This one star is for the Churro.... which was the only highlight of the meal.  Can't believe there are 4 stars from 900 people?  The food was totally tasteless.  The whole process of ordering and paying is chaotic.  People running around behind the counter and slap the food together as you call out your order.  We ordered a shrimp burrito, 1 fish and 1 chorizzo taco, one flan, one churro and 1 drink for $29.00 not exactly cheap for this fast food quality of food and service.
There r absolutly no taste to any of the food.  I had to make numerous trip to the salsa bar to try and add some taste to the food.
Yelp really fail me this time..... will never be back.
author: Mel T.

description: I've been eating at Pancho Villa since 1992. In fact, my sister who lives in St. Louis, MO has me FedEx a burrito minus the sour cream to her and she is still in love with the place. Now I agree with Alvarito on the best burrito joint and in my opinion that's El Farlito (besides they have one in Oakland---hint, hint Pancho, the Uptown neighborhood so needs a good spot). But Pancho Villa is more than a burritto joint, I almost never come for burritos (why waste such good ingredients), I usually get the Tostada Salad with carne asada and pollo asado with refried black beans topped will garlic grilled mushrooms. I've eating this since 1995 as a sophomore in high school. Their quesadilla suiza's are great, taco dinner, the seafood specialties are all amazing. So while the burritos are good, this taqueria is more about good Mexican flavors (fyi, burrito's are American not Mexican). I prefer to have options and they have great options. Especially since the mission has gotten annoyingly HIPSTER.
author: T.Domnic L.

description: On a trip to San Francisco we wanted to find a good Taqueria so we followed someone's advice and got off the bus at 16th and Mission and just looked till we found one.  Pancho Villa didn't disappoint.  I had a Fish Taco and Chorizo Taco.  I've had better Chorizo, but the fish was excellent.  Wife loved the steak enchilada she had.  Washed it all down with a tasty Lemon/Lime Aqua Fresco which appear to be home-made.  Their salsa bar was diverse and tasty.  Yum!
author: Jonny S.

description:
YUM! Great Mexican food for your bucks! 
Their meal is huge! Try five different kinds of salsa: my fav is smokey chipotle salsa.  
Sometimes musicians are playing serenades and art works on the wall can be fun.
author: Chacha M.

description: My favorite place for quick mexican food, awesome choice of salsas
author: satyendra d.

description: A mission classic. Good food, a little gringo and a little pricey(compared to the old days) but generally a hit.
author: Barrett R.

description:
The best place ever for burritos...

Great variety, delicious offerings, easy ordering, price is about right for the quality

I've tried other places in the city and so far, pancho villa offers the best burritos...you get to choose from baby, deluxe, special for the size and it can cost up to $10 for one (steak and prawn)...some ppl may claim that it's too costly for a burrito and indeed, this place charges more than other places, but I think the quality matches the prices..

All in all, great and tasty food
author: Amy Y.

description:
When I think of Mission-style SF burritos, this is the gold standard. I lived around the block from this place for several years and the super burrito (with asada, grilled chicken, or carnitas - all delicious) was a staple of my diet. Beck once somewhat legendarily treated the late night burrito-eating drunks to an impromptu acoustic show during this time. Anyway, it ain't fancy but it's effing awesome. Who gives a shit about whether or not it's "authentic Mexican" when you're eating a giant tortilla filled with grilled meats, rice, beans, cheese, salsa, sour cream and guacamole goodness? If you want authentic Mexican, go grab some cow's brain tacos and catch a donkey show. 

In the four years that passed since I moved away to Brooklyn (then Los Angeles), not a week's gone by that I haven't deeply missed the act of stuffing one of these bad boys into my stomach and sorting out the consequences later. Today I was finally reunited with my big lost burrito love and was delighted to discover that time hadn't changed it all.

Miss u Supes burrito.
author: Alex B.

description:
Let me start this off, by saying that I am from San Diego...and, therefor qualified to be as critical as I would like... for those of you who don't understand why? I'll summarize: In San Diego, any place that ends in -bertos, is good. Not only, is it good, you can get that fantastic burrito, with amazing hot sauce, and a side of spicy carrots...for under $5.

side note: I don't know what the deal is up here...but, in Northern California...you all call them taquerias. Which...i think is funny...because, it seems like an attempt at sounding ethnic, when TACO SHOPS in mexico, aren't even called that [or, anywhere else for that matter].

I would normally have given this place a 3 star rating...but, the security guard at the front door, let me store my bicycle inside. I forgot my lock. Suck. Plus one star for that. Thanks.

If you aren't put off by the Chipotle style assembly line approach, this place is great. I came in to a long line, of mixed types...as the mission usually is... mission hipsters, mexican/latin american families, and them regular folks.

down to it:
Food was good. Not outstandingly amazing...but, really good. 
There was absolutely nothing left of my burrito. Always a good sign.
Not only that...they had a salsa bar, which included some impressively well flavored/spiced hot sauce [NOT the norm for SF mexi food].
To add to that...the burrito was fairly well priced...for SF. Meaning, i got a super-deluxe, whatever they call it, veggie burrito, for about $8. Then a decent, albeit slightly too much cinnamon horchata, for a couple more bucks.
author: Ryan H.

description:
I've heard people tell me this is the best place to get a burrito in San Francisco for years. I was not dissapointed. Fresh chips, fresh steak, fresh salsa. The burrito was delicious, no disappointments there. I even had a churro.

This place is popular so be aware that there will be a line to get your burrito.  but have faith in the system that is well designed by the Pancho Villa architects! The line moves. I sometimes wonder if they are even overstaffed. But obviously they aren't paid much. SO TIP. a dollar or two don't mean much to you but it means a lot to 30 people.

Pancho Villa 5 stars!
author: Pascal C.

description: The food is always fresh & tasty, and it's the closest to Tx Mex that I can find in SF.  Great aquas frescas & beer selection, too.  Only downside: it's a bit loud and cavernous.
author: Kristine Kris C.

description:
I liked Pancho Villa. I perfered Pancho Villa. I took an extra taxi to get dinner tonight at Pancho Villa.

And then the Grilled Veggie burrito happened. And it wasn't good. At all. 

Long wait. Stuffy and just about as hot as hell. Usual mix ups when I specify no rice and that I'd like a whole wheat tortilla...no biggie. Then we took our second taxi home. I sat down to eat my yummy Grilled Veggie burrito on my couch.

And my yummy Grilled Veggie burrito was not a yummy Grilled Veggie burrito. It was more like a beans and oil (ick!) burrito. And my chips. ick! The veggies were cut up way, way to thin to have much flavor and they were totally undercooked. It was not good. 

Pancho Villa...make your lines short again and make the Grilled Veggie burrito better again please!
author: Bea H.

description:
OMG I love this place. The food rocks! I love the custom variations, the wide range of fillings and the quality of the food. It is always fresh, hot and delicious. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

For a taqueria, nothing comes close. It is fast, cheap and fantastic. 

I agree the parking sucks but the food is worth it. Also try Pancho Villa in San Mateo and near Fisherman's wharf.
author: Aedmar M.

description:
After an hour of driving aimlessly around the city and our blood sugars falling to an all-time low, we stopped at Pancho Villa.  With their enormous menu, I had a hard time choosing what to get.  I finally ordered a carne asada dinner plate which came with carne asada, rice, beans, and a salad.   The meat was tender and flavored just right.  I don't like when the meat is too savory because I find myself downing 4 glasses of water with the meal which makes me feel like a water balloon.

The guy at the end near the cashier offered me a sample of fresca.  I tried the strawberry flavor and that was enough for me to order it.  I wasn't intending to get a drink to watch the calories but whatever... go big or go home, right? :)
author: MissJennifer L.

description: WHY did they make this into what looks like a fastfood cafeteria? I know success changes things and all but this is not for the better. It makes the experience less authentic in some way. It even tastes commercial. Was SO much better years ago. Also expensive for real mexican food. I'm sorry but the taste is just not the same as how it used to be.
author: Sandy H.

description: This is a great little place to go after happy hour in the mission.  They are open until midnight, service is quick, it is reasonably priced, food is a 3.5 on a scale of 1-5.  Don't care for the seating, but all in all if you need a quick bite after a night out, you wont be disappointed.
author: Kelly W.

description: Not what it used to be. Ever since they started taking orders at a computer the burritos have gone downhill. Same for San Mateo.  Last two trips really disappointed me. The most recent tasting eactly like that fake green sour cream/guacamole sauce they use at taco bell. blech. No more pancho villa for me
author: Zac H.

description:
Thank you people at Pancho Villa, for not kicking me out on Saturday night when I was completely shitfaced drunk and I was reaching over the counter and picking up all the churros for no reason.

And by the way....why do I heart the chile verde chicken deluxe burrito so much? 

So sad I was too drunk to even remember eating it :(
author: Audrey K.

description:
I can honestly say PV is the best Mexican in the city.  I have tried every place I could or I see.  
For one thing PV has won the California State fair awards for over 10 yrs for their salsa. It is amazingly fresh and full of flavor. Their burritos are fantastic, hell even their "baby burrito" is amazing. they pile it high with meat and whatever you want.  Whatever you ask extra or etc the people at PV are more than happy to accomidate you. In addition they have many different flavors of wraps to serve.  
I have been coming here  yrs and it is still the best Mexican in town. if you guys get a chance order the plates a #4  it is my FAVORITE and you cannot be disappointed.  It is Carne Asada, and Garlic Prawns!! It is nothing short of amazing coupled with the Fresh Salsa and guacamole....my mouth is watering now!  Seriously the Garlic Shrimp is amazing.  You can also ask for the shells of the shrimp to be moved upon cooking.  Believe me anything you want they are ready to make for you.  
A security guard at the door,lol dont know how good he would be in a problem situation but he does open the door for you everytime you come and go.  
The only thing I do not like about PV is the occasional little band that does one song and then walks the tables to ask you for a tip/donation.  other than that I would recommend PV to anyone wh ois in search of authentic Mexican food.
author: Nick C.

description: I like this place when I'm in the mood for a lively, high energy experience to go with a 16th and Valencia night out.  The food is not amazing, but at least average.  They have a complete selection including fruit juices.  The prices are average.  The chips are not as good as at Tommy's or Papalote.  The seats are very little, but I kind of like that.
author: Dan C.

description:
I'm just not a fan of this place.  I don't get what all the hoop-la is all about.

The line was crazy. I waited about a half hour on a sunday afternoon to get my meal.  And the staff passed my friend and I up in the line and started serving people behind us.  When we nicely asked to be served, they ignored us for another 5 minutes.

The prices here are pretty damn high for a taqueria. I'd say a good $2-$4 more expensive than other nearby places to eat.

The decor and feel of the place just felt chinzy.  Like the Wal-Mart of Taco joints.  And the "chairs" - I have a skinny little ass and I was uncomfortable in these torture devices - anyone seen the torture scene in the new James bond flick? These are worse than that chair he was sitting in.

The food was mediocre at best.

Best part about this place were the salsas - which were amazing. Hence, the 3 stars.

Unless you are taking the Bart in from the suburbs, don't bother. There are plenty of other joints in the area that are far superior, with better food, better staff and better vibe.  But damn was the salsa good.
author: Matthew R.

description:
I rarely eat Mexican food since it tends to be really high calorie and pretty unhealthy when done right.  Here however, you get 1 burrito, you have two full meals out of it, and you are satisfied both times! Magic.  Yes their burritos are huge.  I get the junior burrito and still take part of it home! This is one place that you can skip the fatty sour cream, the cheese and guacamole and get a pretty healthy version of a burrito with a ton of taste.  The food is great, and FAST. The line moves fast, the guys/gals behind the counter are awesome and always get it right. I love those guys/gals!!!  I also love the salsa bar.  I want one of those in my kitchen. Great salsa.
one star knocked off for the horrible florescent lights that make me lose my appetite when I walk in and for the sometimes slow bus service.
author: Nilu r.

description: I love this place. Their Salsa El Pastor is the best Salsa that I have ever tasted.  If only I could make it at home.
author: Roger E.

description:
This has usually been my go-to Mexican restaurant whenever a burrito craving would hit me while wandering the streets of the Mission. However, it's been a while since I've been back and my most recent experience there was just meh. 

I've only ever really eaten burritos there, so my evaluation of the place may be limited, but let me just say that I'm the ultimate burrito whore and have eaten many many burritos throughout my lifetime. And so, I have a strong basis for comparison. I ordered a deluxe chicken burrito the other night and was super excited about the size of it, which I give them credit for. But the chicken was dry and it was overloaded with black beans. Plus, I didn't taste the cheese until the last remaining bites. I also think they should include sour cream in the deluxe option. Maybe that's what my burrito needed to make it all the more appetizing. 

I loved the salsa spread though and the complimentary tortilla chips aren't all that bad. They also have a great selection of agua fresca flavors. And I like how they cook the food right in front of you. Right when you get in line, you just see slabs of meat being cooked on the spot. Maybe the next time I go there, I should try ordering something different off the menu and venture out of the burrito world for a bit. Perhaps I'll have a whole different experience.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Overall good food. Enchiladas took awhile to come out. Some of more decent Mexican food in the city that I've had and I'm super picky about my Mexican food.
author: M S.

description:
This place is the standard 'Mission' Burrito.  There is nothing special about anything on the menu in my opinion.  La Cumbre is FAR superior and just around the corner.  Don't let the line fool you.  There is nothing great happening here.  Just the closest foil bomb to BART.

If someone inisists on going here, you will be underwhemled by the food.  Also, the lighting is terrible.  I mean REALLY bad.

Try Al Tenya (sp?) for some REALY carne asada.
author: Thadd L.

description:
KING OF CHEAP EATS

Man, how did J.Lo get that butt?  Red beans and rice sure did not  miss her.  Mark Anthony gets to put his small anaconda in the back of her Honda.  

I freaking love this place.  Get me a Spanich Super Carnitas Burrito to get to escape the dreadful Dolly Parton 9-5.   You know this place is great when they have a freaking security guard to open the door!  

You stay classy San Francisco!
author: patrick o.

description:
oh Pancho Villa how you fill me with love, and rice, and beans. You are so delicious, and inexpensive, and just generally great.

also you have the best limon agua fresca around.
author: Jared Z.

description: Wow, I don't know if it was just the right place and the right time or what, but this burrito really hit the spot. I got the super burrito, which was stuffed with nice big chunks of avocado - yum! Creamy and satisfying as a burrito should be, I'll come back! And I personally appreciated the ordering scheme - the departmentalization seemed more efficient to me than the average uber-busy tacqueria. (think subway vs. safeway's deli)
author: Jeff G.

description:
The rumors are true.
PVT rocks!!
THEIRS were the burritos I was longing for when my s.o. & I moved out of state! Nowhere else can duplicate that "Mission style".
After more than a decade of frequenting Pancho Villa, I can assure you their food is:
.fresh
.fast
.cheap
.delicious
The restaurant is clean but outside it's a different story..
author: Rachel D.

description:
The Super Vegetarian burrito is surprisingly impressive, with the right blend of everything.  It might actually be called the Super Veggie, but that is decidedly less comic book superhero-ish.

In fact, if I didn't have a show tonight, I might just walk down to the mission and order it right now.  But I respect my castmates too much to do that.
author: Tovah S.

description:
Pancho Villas has always been my favorite taquerilla in San Francisco. I have been going there for 15 years.

I love the fast counter service and the lively atmosphere.

They make the best vegetarian burrito I have ever had. It has a marinated tofu and all the fixing and fresh chips.
author: Charlie R.

description:
This place was expensive and the burritos were way below average! I ordered nachos, so they put some shredded cheese and microwaved it! By the time I ate the nachos, the cheese had already hardened because it wasn't "nacho quality" cheese. I got 3 burritos and a nacho for about $35!

I knew they ran a commercial on TV for a reason, they need the sucker more people like me!
author: Freckles H.

description:
I know, another 4-star review...

Try the steak & prawn quesadillas. A little salty, but really good. I haven't tried everything on the menu yet but the steak & prawns are tender and the guac is good.
author: Blue R.

description: Pancho Villa helped me realize my burrito dreams during my one week visit to SF.  After eating here three times in said week it also contributed to my feeling like I'm about to give birth to a burrito baby:  Chicken verde with refried black beans was my poison of choice, along with a melon agua fresca.  Great salsa bar with all the fixings.  I miss it already.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Always good food here. Never disappointed. Only disappointment is the line for food. The staff is pretty fast though. They know drunk/high people need their late night fix.
author: Chris Y.

description:
This is my favorite taqueria in the City!

Order a burrito, sit down, take a bite and enjoy. I love the way the ingredients all stand out with each mouthful and yet they all work together.

Here is my favorite -

Especial Burrito (cheese, guac, salsa, rice)
Chili Verde Pork
Hot Salsa
Re-fried BLACK BEANS.

I am craving one now just writing about it.

Oh, and don't forget their award winning salsa bar in the back.
author: Kemp M.

description:
I was pretty disappointed after our trip to Pancho Villa for dinner. First things first, when you walk in, you can see the grill and the food looks good. Next, the menu has so many options. Too many options. A curse in this case. 

I hear the prices used to be cheaper and they should still be cheaper. I heard the food used to be bigger and it still should be bigger. I had the Deluxe Carne Asada ($7.50). Here's my experience with the cash register. When "my" burrito was ready, I was rung up for $8.00. This was my first clue that this was not my burrito. After the lady had swiped my card for the wrong dollar amount, she scrambled to find out what was wrong with me or the machine, but it was getting hard and harder each week. So when it finally got sorted out, I got the correct charge, but they did not reverse the original charge. So instead of crediting the previous charge, I was given 75 cents from the tip jar to make up the difference. 

Anyway, I guess they're known for their salsa. I didn't have any, but the wall had a lot of awards. 

So the food tasted good, but I was hoping for a lot more. I'm probably not coming back.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
This is a great place to eat. 

When, I visit one of my parking garages around the corner on Hoff Street, I always eat at Pancho Villa Taqueria . This is a great place to eat. The food is great. I highly recommend this Taqueria to any one who want s to eat some real Mexican Food. The prices are very reasonable.
author: Francisco L.

description:
Was craving a burrito so went in today, only one couple in line ahead of me otherwise the place was quiet for a change. 
I ordered my regular small burrito and went to the end of the counter to pay. 
There are like 10 people in that line making food but what where they doing running around, it took forever to get my meal! I finally got my to-go burrito and took it home, it kind of sucked, not what I asked for, very little meat, tons of re-fried beans and too much crunchy salsa, totally disappointed. I think this place has gotten too big, I'm used to the smaller places where you stand in front of the person making your burrito and you can say, "that's enough, salsa, beans, cheese or more of whatever". Here they make you go to the end of the line so you don't see how they're over doing it or putting in the wrong stuff.
Prob won't eat a burrito for a long while as I was totally turned off and when I do I'll go to a smaller place.
author: Rick D.

description: They say that this place is better than the San Mateo location but I couldn't tell.  Though I do appreciate the security guard that opens the door for you.  Nice touch to have in the Mission.
author: Gina K.

description: Yelp hasn't steered us wrong in SF until now. The meat was dry. The spices were bland. And the price was too high for what we got.  Maybe it was an off day but this place sucked.
author: Mike L.

description:
I LOVE PANCHO VILLA (disclaimer to follow)

Back when I was living at 15th/Guerrero and abstaining from my kitchen I'd eat at Pancho Villa (or el Toro) every other day and NEVER got tired of it.  But here's the thing: I was broke most of the time and a cheapskate too and so I would ONLY order the rice and bean taco for $1.25.  I really have nothing to say about the rest of the menu, though I noticed they have everything from burritos to steak and shrimp plates for $16.

SO: for $1.25 I got a pile of black beans and rice with mild salsa on a double corn tortilla and a side of tortilla chips served on a ceramic plate with real silverware and access to an excellent salsa bar in a big, bright, sparkling clean establishment where all the employees wear crisp blue and white uniforms (almost Oompa Loompa-ish) and the world seems happy and orderly.

Whoa, bro. 

 'Nuff Said.
author: Sweet T.

description:
Open till Midnight! Pollo Asada Regular Burrito--$7(?), spicy, agua fresca, free chips to go and all set. Sometimes at night the bando is singing and this is right across from #22 bus stop going north.

Like to see them grilling stuff, sometimes a bit smokey, but yum.
author: miriam b.

description:
Considering the locale, this place was pretty clean.  The food was great!  We had carnitas taco deluxe, good times!  The salsa was great, the hibiscus tea yummy, and the flan...pretty good.

Love the location, next to a trannie bar!
author: Toonces The Driving Cat K.

description: Gotta love this place. It is always busy and the workers never seem to stop moving whether they are hard at work cooking or sweeping the lobby. They don't chat up it up with you or anything but provide swift service and good product. I highly recommend this place over other Taquerias in the city because they seem to have a clean, food safe operation running (in contrast see my review on El Farolito) . The ingredients seem fresh and the space is bright, open,  and inviting.
author: Hitomi M.

description: Moved to the City when I was 20 and broke --  this place provided me all 4  food groups daily. The prices have gone up a little bit over the years, but the food has always been fresh, delicious, and a good value for the $.
author: Dan E.

description: I was in  town last week for work and was really wanting Mexican food.  I asked some of my co workers who are locals what they would recommend and they said Pancho Villa Taqueria, so I thought I would give it a try. Lets just say I was very disappointed. I had the carne asada burrito. The meat had lots of fat and had no flavor what's so ever.  The Pico de gallo was so so. I was just expecting so much more. Especially with all the great reviews.
author: Antoinette C.

description: Carne asada tacos are delish! Don't forget the grilled green onions to go with it too!  The salsa selection here is totally good too!
author: Nadiyah S.

description: This place rocks. A local I met while in San Francisco recommended it, and it was killer. I had the spicy chicken especial burrito and it was insanely delicious. They also have beer. Really really good. I'll be going there again on my next trip to SF. Recommended for sure.
author: R N.

description: I visited this place as part of a Groupon deal. I ordered the combo shrimp/ steak plate which was pretty good. It was also pretty inexpensive. Also there was also a lot of seating, which is normally a problem in SF. Also, we were there on a Friday night, and there was a mariachi band! I'm not sure if it was planned or of someone from the street just walked in...
author: John W.

description:
Lots of food, lots of moneyz...

Probably the best thing about this "Taqueria" is the sauces. They are awesome. They even have some awards I believe.  I was impressed when I found that in the "Sauce Bar" you could find "Chiles Toreados".  

There is a huge selection of dishes, probably bigger that I could wish. There are so many items that I couldn't make my mind. I ended up asking a mixture of a "Combo" which included a corn quesadilla, one steak taco and an enchilada. I felt so guilty afterwards, so much food and I ended up paying twice as much as what I'm used to pay for my lunch. 

To drink I needed to try the "Limonada" which was horrible. My little niece can prepare a better lemonade than that crap. The worst part is that I payed three dollars for it. I should have asked for a Corona instead. 

As I said before, the only time I would pay more than 10 dollars for Mexican Antojitos is when I'm trying to score with a girl. The limonada was awful and there was a couple of birds that attacked me while I was ordering my food.

Tres estrellas amigos. 
Ciao
author: Daniel C.

description:
The best Taqueria in the entire Bay Area. I wish they would have something comparable in the southbay. 

Parking sucks but if your on foot, youre good.
author: Nael M.

description:
I've been there for the food, but only order to go since the employees there are RUDE as hell.
They're definitely not Mexican.  The first thing your parents teach you is: "Salude, muchacho cabron". And if you don't know how to greet people then your parents aren't Mexican.
author: d r.

description:
Man this is the SHIIIIIIT!
BUT....
I like La Corneta better.
Just simply because of a better taste, but please don't get it wrong because before La Corneta got up in the scene. Man I use to get on my knees and bow to this great and holy mecca of burrito sanctuary!
Still love it. Hey after 10pm and want a burrito and in the mission district
Go Here!
author: Nelson F.

description:
Best burrito I've found in San Francisco.  Tofu ranchero burritos to die for -- perfect combination of everything.  Delicious salsa bar; hot salsas that are actually really hot.  It's always packed, but I've always been able to find a seat.

And what's up with people docking stars for the decor?  Right now, they've got a cool photo exhibit up; and really, you're looking for a *taqueria*, folks, not Gary Danko.  Chill out, and accept that this is burrito Nirvana!
author: Nori H.

description:
So my friend and I were sharing a meal of 3 pollo tacos and 1 enchilada the other day, when he says to me...

"Oi! How about checking out those fire roasted chillis, mate?" (he's from Bangalore)
"Sounds fantastic, friend. Those are the ones that look burnt. yes?"
"Yessim, thats be the case. Ya'll come back now, ya'hear" (he's also lived in NYC for awhile)

:::: 20 minutes later ::::

"Please, pretty cashier lady!! Dos grandes horchadas por FAVOR!!"

5 stars = 3 for food, 1 for complementary hot stuff, and 1 for being open late
author: Andy A.

description:
