Uninspired burrito and the Quesadillas were likewise disappointing  The food definitely looked good while I was standing in line and ordering but I've had much better food at other places in SF.  (Dos Pinas comes to mind)

But if you're stumbling out of a bar late in the evening then Pancho Villa will probably hit the spot.
author: Rene M.

description:
Their super burritos aren't so super.  They're noticably smaller than the super burritos commonly found at most Mission taquerias, and about a third of the contents is LETTUCE.  Who puts lettuce in a super burrito?? Not El Farolito... not Taqueria Cancun... Pancho Villa does.  And it takes up real estate that rightfully belongs to meat, beans, cheese, or sauce... which means that that lettuce is a goddamn squatter.  And it's squatting next to meat that's just so-so. 
There are plenty of places right nearby that may not look as bright, shiny, and friendly, but they'll be better!
author: DemonPixie ..

description:
I'm from San Diego.

I miss real mexican food. I'd like to eat a burrito that isn't wrapped in foil.

wah wah
author: jared c.

description:
Went to Pancho Villa the other night- had friends in from out of town and it's an easy location to remember.  It's good.  Very good.  But I was shocked at how long it took to get through the line.  It took 10 minutes to get my food, and I paid over $8 for a burrito.  There are better taquerias in the Mission than this- they're cheaper, faster, and not nearly as full of themselves.  Part of  what makes a taqueria great is a low key attitude, and PV has ribbons and awards all over the walls telling everyone how great they are.  It sort of rubs me the wrong way at this point.  Farolito, Cancun, Corneta will be getting my burrito dollars in the future.  

Sorry, Pancho- even with all the awards you're not the best.
author: Chester H.

description:
Fast Mexican food doesn't get any better than this!

Forget Burger King, this is how you get it YOUR WAY. Since this place has opened it has been the best fast food burrito place in the city bar none. No need to tell you what is good, because it's all good. The staff stand in the assembly line and they move the long line quick, fast and in a hurry. But if you don't like the hood, and I do mean HOOD, then don't come to this location cuz it can be scary for those who feel easily threatened by teens wearing gang colors, druggies and street people who yell at you, gimme a dolla!
author: Jim L.

description: Parking and neighborhood around here sucks but the food makes up for it. Freshly made as ordered with big portions. They also have a cool salsa bar towards the end but i was disappointed since their salsa was either watered down not spicy at all or really really spicy...nothing in between!  I ordered the fish taco and the BF ordered a steak burrito- both were yum!
author: M W.

description: proof that this is a decent restaurant is that they have a guard at the door. i know this might sound biassed and almost offensive to some but bad people know where to get their mexican fix and so do i. i have been a regular when i lived in town and i'm one every time i swing by.
author: Augusto N.

description: There is always a huge line at Pancho Villa, but it goes really fast.  I love, love, love the tofu ranchero burrito.  It is amazing.  I think I could eat it everyday.  But then I think I would weight 400 lbs.  But I would be a happy 400 lbs :)  The tofu is perfectly marinated and the rice is nice and salty, just the way I like it.  I like that they have baby burritos as sometimes, you just can't handle a big burrito.  They also have at least 5 or 6 agua frescas every day and they are insanely fresh.  The salsa bar has a big selection of salsas.  I have to give it a 4 instead of 5 because of the meat - it pains me to see it and it sickens me to smell it.  If only Pancho Villa could be 100% veg...
author: Dana P.

description: We went to this place via a recommendation by someone we met on the airplane while visiting SF. We decided to check this place out and I think they serve the tastiest and most affordable mexican food. They have plenty of options for vegetarians. I would highly recommend this place for good mexican food. You would not feel like taking a picture here but you will leave this place with a happy face !
author: Harry J.

description: Been going here for a few years. This is what I like to call a gringo taqueria. Yes, I said it.. and as such the meats are leaner and most likely healthier for you here than at your whole in the wall, but due to this... you must pay for it. The prices here are higher than most places, but I am cool with that because I do not fear getting sick from food here... I am not saying you will get sick from elsewhere, but I just like how clean things are, etc. They are quick and get you out in a jiffy during lunch time. My favorite at the moment is the steak n nachos... it is enough for two, but since you can't save it... its my meal of the day... the carne asada is tasty and they have a a good prawn burrito too. Lately I have seen that they have a special happy hour type menu where you can get 3 burritos or tacos (I could be wrong) for $5.55 each... this starts at 3pm. No bad at all.
author: Amelia M.

description:
My friend dragged me here a few nights ago when we were looking for someplace cheap to eat after a trip to a local cafe.  She tells me she's addicted, so I sacrificed a trip to my favorite (Ti Couz) to indulge her.

This place is fine.  It's clearly incredibly popular, but I'm not quite sure why.  I had a Quesadilla Suiza with Spicy Chicken.  I asked them to make it spicy, and I guess that meant one or two jalapenos stuffed inside - I was complaining to my dining companion that it wasn't spicy like I'd asked when I got a mouthful of fire.

The salsa bar is certainly a plus, but it would be helpful if there was some signage telling you what the hell everything is.  Maybe there was and I just didn't see it, so dazed was I by the bright lights and diverse crowd.  But I had no idea what I was sampling.

Also, the quesadilla ended up swimming in its own "juices," for lack of a better word.  When I had half of it the next day, reheated, it was much better because it wasn't all soggy, and the heat from the cooking didn't take away from the flavors.  So my advice would be to get it takeout.

To sum: takeout, if you like spicy use salsas instead of asking them to do it, and get a veggie burrito, cause my friend swears they're god's gift to man.  Can't vouch for it myself, though.

I'm sure there are better taquerias in the Mission.
author: Sabrina L.

description: I feel like this place has been a home away from home for me.  I've been coming here for decades, and then I had my first showing of my photos/art back in 2007, and another show in 2009.  I've NEVER had a bad meal here.  The food is always great and often when I've come by myself I've sat down with another patron and had a great conversation.  And it's usually pretty easy to park if not right on 16th Street then on Mission.  Or take BART and it's just down the block from the 16th Street Station.  The gallery manager and I are getting ready to promote the gallery here into a first class gallery.  Stay tuned for details!
author: David Louis K.

description: Better than other taquerias I've been to yet I'm still faithful to la corneta in Glen Park!  Near to Bart and  Muni and good gor vegetarians like myself.  Reasonably priced and the window seats are good for watching peole walk by while eating a veg burrito.
author: R C.

description:
it's really difficult to find mexican food spots that are vegetarian-friendly so you can imagine how happy I was to walk into P.V.T. 

tofu ranchero, grilled garlic mushrooms and no-lard beans... YAY!
author: littledrummermoggs L.

description:
Yum.  Authentic Mexican at its best.  I got taken here by a local shortly after I arrived and I felt like I was back in South Tucson.

The decor is pretty simple but the menu makes up for it with complexity.  You can have a burro of many sizes filled with a slew of meats and topped off with just about whatever you want.  Authentic horchata and Mexican drinks too, and a decent selection of beers.  The burros are LARGE.  Save room in your fridge for the leftovers.
author: Kelly A.

description:
I miss this place! Since changing neighborhoods, things aren't the same when I get a craving after work or late at night for something tasty and filling with all the extras to take home.

I used to be in the Mexican restaurant business, and can say these folks know how to do burritos right. Too crowded and noisy to enjoy for a sit-down dinner, but the take-out is excellent.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Love Letter to My Dear Lost Super Burrito

Friends, I took a drastic step a few mere months ago...I want...da da dum...low carb.

What is the one thing I miss grabbing for lunch? You guessed it - a Pancho Villa super burrito. How did I love thee, super burrito?

*Sigh*
author: Kimberly B.

description:
I like this place. I really do. The food is good and not too greasy, the agua fresca is really good, and you don't have to wait on line again if you want a cookie after your meal. Oh and they give you extra chips if you give them puppy dog eyes and there's lots of salsa to choose from (and radishes!) That, and a security guard at the door, makes this a pretty awesome mission taqueria. 

One slight problem -- I always get stressed ordering from the ladies here. For some reason there's always a lot of unexpected decisions to make at the last minute, I feel rushed, and then they turn around too quickly and miss part of my order. Maybe I just need more practice. You should know to be prepared to order better than I usually am.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Best Mexican Food in SF!!

Wow, seriously.  I trek to the mission a few times a month for this food.  The rice and beans are where the big difference between this and other mex joints lies.  Don't miss them.  I always get the shrimp something-or-other but my BF has tried all the meats and the chicken mole rocks the casa.

Chips leave a bit to be desired, but you can't have it all.  Also,  know in advance that it's cafeteria style and, although they have beer, if you're looking for a margarita night, this is not the place.
author: Nicole K.

description: I always feel like I'm going to get mugged or harassed by a crackhead while walking to Pancho Villa, but it's all worth it for their spicy prawn taco (or spicy prawn nachos if I am extra extra hungry.) This place is crawling with locals, so you know it's got to be good. They close at midnight on the weekdays (hallelujah!) & are jam packed up until the last moments before the security guard locks the door & has to deny entrance to a few unlucky latecomers. They feature different, local art on their massive, white walls, which changes sporadically. Don't be put off by the long lines because they move fast or the kind of uncomfortable seats because you'll forget anything bad in life as soon as you take your first bite. Huge portions, moderate prices, big selection of drinks (agua frescas, jarritos, bottled drinks, etc.) & the fresh squeezed orange juice is the bomb.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
pancho villa is very clean.  staff is friendly but a bit difficult to hear because of the noise level/acoustics.  easy-to-read menu board, lots of options.

i ordered the baby burrito and horchata.  even the baby burrito here is huge and way more than enough for one person.  horchata was ok but i'm feeling i may have missed out on another delicious-looking flavor (strawberry, watermelon, jamaica, etc).  A LOT of agua fresca options.

love the salsa bar but would love it more if there were some descriptors nearby to help with selection process.

i think prices are about $1 more expensive than should be for most items.  

this place gets busy and lines form quickly but usually dissipate in a few minutes.

all in all, a good stop for lunch; not a spot i'd cross town to get to, but if i were in the neighborhood and mighty hungry, i'd return for sure.  and i'd have to find the willpower to only eat half the serving.  and i'd try a different agua fresca, too.
author: Noah C.

description: their salsa verde is kinda hot and definitely yummy on top of a delicious ceviche... and you can call in an order for pickup!
author: Laura F.

description: Came by during their happy hour. Between 3pm-5pm they sell tacos for $1. These were regular tacos with meat, beans, onions and cilantro. I'm not sure if these were the same ones on the menu for $3, but I wouldn't pay $3 for such a small taco, but during happy hour the price is right.
author: Robin L.

description: Solid al pastor burrito.  Good size.  Love the salsa bar.  Not the cheapest or the best burrito I've had in the Mission, but I will be going back for more.
author: AJ D.

description: Had an outstanding grilled chicken burrito w/my BF this past week.  Sat outside in the little park on Hoff Street.  The burrito was outstanding and enough for both lunch and dinner.
author: Kevin M.

description: They have these fancy to go containers now but they get really stingy with the food when they use it for some reason. Anyway I got a al pastor taco and they gave me such a  small portion.  And the al pastor was bland!  I am sure they have lots of other really good stuff on the menu, but I will be getting my al pastor elsewhere.
author: C t.

description: For those giving more than 3 stars I would like to ask, have you been to El Farolito or La Corneta etc? Pancho Villa seems over priced. El Farolito is almost half the price. Many salsas to choose from but not one that I thought was good. I would much rather prefer a small amount of Salsas if they are done well. Again, El Farolito :)
author: Neil W.

description:
So, here's the thing: I'm a rock star, but I'm also a complete, raving moron, and frequently a danger to myself and others.  Pancho Villa Taqueria is Exhibit 553 in support of this contention.  Allow me to explain.

As I have previously bitched and moaned about, I've been working hellacious hours lately.  Basically, 10-12 hours days, at least 6 days a week, for two months straight.  But, whatever, it's not like I have a lot of other things going on in my life, so work is a fine way to pass the time.  But, there's a limit on exactly how much of myself I can carve up and give away without repercussions.  On Monday, I woke up, didn't feel all that awesome.  Doesn't matter, had to work.  For 11 hours.  Little Afrin kept the pipes clean.  Tuesday, woke up, felt kinda bad.  Doesn't matter, had to work.  For 12 hours.  Little more Afrin kept the pipes sorta clean.  Sneezed on and off all day.  Wednesday, woke up, felt totally like crap.  Really didn't matter, absolutely had to work.  For 11 hours.  Afrin didn't do a damn thing.  Sneezed constantly, used up half a box of Kleenex.  Thursday, woke up, felt like I'd been beaten with a baseball bat.  Didn't matter, had to work.  At 11:00, I turned away from the document I was reading for 2 minutes to read an email, turned back, and couldn't find the place on the page where I stopped reading.  Because none of it was familiar.  Okay, no biggie, started reading from the top.  Halfway through, turned away for another minute to answer another email, turned back, couldn't find my place again.  Realized that my continued presence at work could constitute malpractice, went home.  Where I still worked for another 3 hours, but mostly from the prone position.  Friday, woke up, felt like a bag of smashed assholes, looked even worse than usual (if you can believe it), stayed home.  Took 2 DayQuil and a variety of other stuff.  Worked maybe 4 hours.  Seriously contemplated flushing Blackberry down the toilet so people would stop calling me.

By supper, I was actually feeling pretty decent.  Not all the way healthy, but better than I had for days.  And my sister-in-law and her fiance were visiting.  So, after a dinner of leftover Chinese food at our place (not my choice, long story), we head out to meet two of sis-in-laws friends.  They also live close to the Mission, so we pick a nearby place I like.  And by place, I mean bar.  And I'm feeling pretty decent, so I drink:

1 mint julep;
1 Crown & Coke;
1 12 oz. Watermelon Wheat Beer with a whiskey chaser; and
1.5 liters of some German beer beloved by the guy in the group from Munich.

Now, just so we're all on the same page, those bottles of Pepsi that sit in your refrigerator door, those are 2 liters.  So I basically drank 75% of one of those, in beer.  Now, at this point, between the massive quantities of pharmaceuticals that are coursing through my veins, and the alcohol, I'm easily not in my right mind.  But I'm not an idiot, and I know that the half-serving of Kang Shao shredded beef I ate 5 hours ago is absolutely not up to the task of fighting off this quantity of alcohol.  Reinforcements are needed.

Enter Pancho Villa Taqueria.  It's basically between the bar and my place, so it's the natural choice.  I split an enchilada dinner with my soon-to-be brother-in-law, wifey and sis split some nachos, and friend and German guy split a burrito.  I also have a watermelon agua fresca, because I think it'll go great with the watermelon wheat beer I had an hour ago.  Plus, I smother the enchiladas with hot sauce and a healthy helping of extra jalapeno slices, because how would that ever come back to haunt me?

Fast forward to 5:15 a.m.  I wake up to find that a small army of industrious dwarfs are building a mid-rise, mixed-use building inside my skull.  And it's a problem.  They're violating all sorts of building codes, they don't have the proper permits, and it's not even an approved use for that particular plot of my frontal lobes.  I sit up to have a word with them, and the bed turns 8 or 9 complete circles and dips up and down a few times like a log ride.  I burp 4 or 5 times in rapid succession, and its....watermelon and jalapenos?  Not 2 great tastes that taste great together.  I quickly lay back down and manage to organize a brief union picket that temporarily brings the dwarfs' construction project to a halt.  I am faced with three choices, in descending order of what would actually be a good idea: 1. go to the bathroom and prematurely reintroduce my midnight Mexican meal and accompanying alcoholic pickling juice to the world; 2. go get a drink of water; 3. roll over and go back to sleep and pray things turn out okay.  I try 3, but can't get it to happen, so I compromise on 2.

Bottom line: I would probably be in worse shape, but for my trip to Pancho Villa.  That being said, it's now 12 hours later, and I can still taste my meal.  And not in a completely good way.
author: Ben P.

description: I like that you can get plenty of veggie options, and the new $1 happy hour tacos seem like a great deal.  I'm bummed that you can get any meat, but not tofu in them!  lame!  Still, super yummy tofu ranchero burrito last night!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This place is my crack house.  While I can make a meal of the chips and salsas alone, the steak and camarone quesadilla makes me want to eat my fingers off.  The aguas frescas rock and the rice is delicious.  The cocktail de camarones, which is one of my favorite things, is a little watery and weak on flavor, but it is heavy on avocados and shrimp which is a good thing.  

Forget the taqueria debate, this place beats them all hands down!
author: Olga G.

description:
This is not the best Taqueria on the block. It is actually one of the weakest, if not the actual weakest of the bunch, though they do a couple of things very well.

Why, then, does it have lines out the door and constant crowds? 

Laziness and herd mentality. Think about it:  where is Pancho Villa located? Exactly between BART and the Valencia area bars where it is presently fashionable to get drunk. And people love to rationalize, they won't say "We're settling for this because it's convenient, and we settle for it every weekend." No--- That would be admitting to second best. So they say "You have to come with us to this exceptional Taqueria we discovered while exploring. It is the best that this edgy new neighborhood we found called 'the Mission' has to offer..." And there is no reasoning with the intoxicated. 

Pancho Villa over-salts everything. I feel closer to a stroke every time I eat one of their soggy, inconsistent, assembly-line burritos while sitting on their broken, uncomfortable seats. A lot of salt is one thing. A whole god-damn salt-lick is another. Their dry, stale nachos, though not quite prison food, are lowly. (In the indignant words of the late Matt "Uncle Matty" Oreto, "How do you fuck up nachos!?")

As alternatives, Mariachi's has a much wider selection of much better-crafted Burritos for about the same price, with accompanying novelties like mango salsa. And if it's basic Mission-authentic you want, go around the corner to El Castillito, next to the porno store on Mission--- solid, cheap, real.

Now, that said, Pancho Villa makes a very, very good quesadilla. The prawn quesadilla is great, while the juicy garlic-mushroom quesadilla verges on excellent. So it's not like there isn't a reason to go there every now and again. 

Their much-touted salsa bar is pretty damn good, too, though it is inconsistent, and they seem to change salsa recipies at random.

As a parting shot, though, back about a year and a half ago, when the city's living wage measure passed, Pancho Villa was the first restaurant that I observed in San Francisco to take it out of their customer's hides by jacking their prices. Weak.
author: David M.

description:
Pancho Villa is the shiz-nit.

This is my fave:

Wheat tortilla.  
Black beans, NO rice. 
Lengua (braised, saucy, delicious cow tongue.  Sounds gross, but hey, I'm brown- grew up eating it, but forgot all about it until Pancho Villa)
Lots of spicy pico de gallo
Scoop of guac

F-ing fantastic.  Just the right amount of food.  No self-violation and self-induced 3-hour bloat.  Wash it all down with a large agua fresca sandia- straight watermelon delight.  Priceless.  Well, almost, as you get all this goodness for under $10.  Throw a buck in their tip jar- they're friendly, clean and have free roasted jalapenos.  Word.
author: Camille C.

description:
This is really just an excellent Mexican place.  You get free chips with your tacos, and I use the chips to eat the surplus meat/cheese/lettuce/etc off my taco.  The pricing is perfectly reasonable.  The food is delicious.  The salsas they provide are delicious.  The location is great when visiting the Mission.

The only downside is that due to its popularity you will likely have to wait in line for five minutes or so before ordering.  Somehow, I've never had any trouble finding seating here even though it always looks packed.  I think this is due to its high turnover in customers.
author: Joel H.

description:
5 HUGE GD STARS... 
they are the HEYSOOS of burritos.

...'nuff said.
author: J B V.

description: My favorite taqueria in the Mission, Pancho Villa is always reliable for a delicious bite to eat. This place can get really busy at lunch time and sometimes it's hard to snag a table but the food is well worth it. The salsa bar is delicious and yes, award-winning. I always go for a burrito, not very imaginative, but oh so great. The place is pretty clean and I've never had a bad experience. Definitely recommended!
author: Kristin M.

description: 2nd and 3rd xp not as good as the first. Steak wasn't very good
author: Captain B.

description: Now I know what it feels like to be pregnant. Thanks, Pancho Villa!
author: Catherine S.

description: I'm always in the mood for a good carne asada burrito.  I was not disappointed my first time here, though I must say that the burrito got cold too quickly.  They have an endless selection of salsas ranging from mild to super picante!  Definitely going to come here again.
author: Ben T.

description: The Embarcadero location has closed and the taqueria here now is horrible. Please don't mistake it for Pancho Villa.
author: sonja h.

description:
My first experience here I got a shrimp quesadilla and a small jamaica. The jamaica tasted a little more watered down that I would have liked. The shrimp was juicy, but the rest of the quesadilla was extremely, extremely meh. It was quite large, but it was mostly lettuce and some beans, hardly any cheese. I was extremely confused how the laws of supply and demand worked out so that this meal cost me 12 dollars.

Today, as part of my quest to find the best horchata on the Mission, I stopped by here again. I got a burrito especial with lengua, which costs 2 dollars more than a regular meat burrito because it comes with guac. The tongue was juicy, tender, and better seasoned than El Farolito's on 24th. The rest of the burrito was, again, meh. They put too much rice, which itself doesn't have much flavor. The guacamole was runny and I couldn't really taste the avocado at all. Very, very meh. 

The horchata is pretty good,  though it's a little pricey because of their biodegradable cups. 3 dollars for a "large" that is more like a medium? I'd rather hop 2 blocks to La Oaxaquena for the same if not better quality but much cheaper. 

My lunch again came out to 12 dollars. The burritos are large, yes, but not that large. Most of all, taste wise it just didn't seem worth it. My quest for the best horchata in the Mission continues, but I won't be making any more stops here.
author: Polly F.

description: The steak and prawn quesadilla is spectacular.  This is now my favorite fast mexican food.  Very clean and efficient for a cantina style restaurant. The rice and salsa is what makes the burritos here with decent quality meats. I am a big fan and go here often.
author: Ted C.

description: Great food, quick service, free chips, serves beer, great salsa.  Not much more you can ask for.  Great taqueria.
author: Trevor W.

description: I never thought I liked Mexican food, but wow, this place makes me crave for more!! It's so different from the greasy, slimy mexican food I am used to back at home in London. I particularly liked the sea food tacos. We had to wait a bit but it was so worth it!
author: Artichoke Q.

description: On two different visits to SF,  two unacquainted friends of mine brought me to this Taqueria. During my most recent visit, I had no idea that my friend would drag me to the same taco joint that I had visited over a year and a half ago. This most recent visit served to reinforce my last experience. I'm glad I made the second trip here, and I definitely recommend the joint to anyone who's looking for good, relatively affordable Mexican food.
author: Jeremy C.

description: This is my favorite taqueria of all time. I went here for ten years and I return when I am back in SF. The food is consistent, the service is reliable (the same workers have been there for ten years) and the place is clean and comfortable. The crowd who goes there is a slice of all Americans: black, white, mexican, asian, hipsters, suits, etc. There is a salsa cart where you can get your selection of salsas, radishes and peppers. Try the drinks: my favorite is the watermelon fresca.  If you are on a strict budget, get the bean taco for a little over a buck.  If you can splurge, there are many delicious options to try at Pancho Villa.
author: A N.

description: I came here during happy hour like from 3pm to 5pm.  You know why?  Why to buy their special One dollar taco that happens only during happy hour 5 days a week.  I brought four taco and seat by the salsa bar.  I should ask them to put fresh cut tomato on it next time like tommorow.
author: John F.

description: The salsa bar makes this place!  Its more expensive than other taqueria's and the taste is not as great, but the salsa is bar and far the best you will find in the area.  I recommend to drench you food in your favorite sause.
author: Brent F.

description: The steak and shrimp burrito was phenomenal. Easily one of the best burritos I've had in the mission. The salsa bar also made the meal - wonderful variety. A bit pricey, but you're at least getting something great for your money.
author: Munaf A.

description: Good food... Shrimp cocktail was really good and so was thier garlic shrimp!! Love the guy singing and playing the guitar... Takes me back Cabo days... Great laid back atmosphere ...Would def come back here :)
author: Jan Marie V.

description:
FINALLY!!!!! I found the best damn taqueria north of L.A.
It's a style one becomes accustomed to being spoiled in SoCal.
Many will argue but after 10yrs in SD, there are certain expectations. PVT- meets and exceeds those expectations. Their "Puro Carne" is what it's all about. ALL MEAT & salsa. By far the best taqueria I've been to from SJ to SF.
author: Jaeger M.

description:
Consistently great Mexican food.  Plus, there's always something crazy going on at 16th & Mission.

I too doubted the authenticity for a while until I bought lunch for a couple of guys who had helped with some work in the Mission.  Both were born in Mexico but have since settled in San Francisco.  I agreed to pay for lunch on the condition we go somewhere good & authentic - guess where we went...

I was a little disappointed that we weren't going to some hidden gem where Abuelita dishes out handmade corn tortillas etc...but then I felt content going back to Pacho Villa for tasty,  somewhat -authentic, Mexican eats.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Ok, This is it, this is the best burrito I have ever had.
Yes I am latino, yes Ii have had home cooked mexican food, and yes I have eaten in mexico from the big cities to a small village that had no running water or a main road, and THIS place has the best burrito. I have had well over 50 burritos from around california, anywhere from San Diego up to Santa Rosa, and this place is the best. I could go on forever, but to keep it simple : very fresh vegetables and meats. The best way to see how good the meats are at a mexican place is to check the al pastor (BBQ pork). and this place has the best, not running with pork fat. The staff is very friendly, the kitchen is kept in an incredibly clean way, and of course the salsa bar is huge and has won countless awards. and no, before you ask La Cumbre is not better. quantity is one thing and quality is another. Please try this place out, you will not regret it. They have one in San mateo that is also very good, but this is where it all started. Very good food and great place to eat.
author: Francisco C.

description: A great, authentic Mission district eatery. Try a burrito with everything. No visitor to the Bay Area should ever have to go back to their home state without experiencing the joy of a Mission district taqueria burrito with EVERYTHING. Most people can't eat the whole thing but it's a meal they will remember when they go back. Even if you take them to fancier places, that burrito will stand out as one of the best things they ate while in San Francisco. This can be said of at least a dozen places in the Mission but this is as good a choice as any. A perfect place for a low cost, great quality Mexican lunch or dinner with fresh ingredients and great flavor.
author: Sara N.

description: Um, DELICIOUS!!!! My fiance and I never, NEVER venture out to the Mission, but we happened to be in the area and were craving Mexican. In that area you could toss a rock blindfolded and find a Taqueria, and our rock happened to land here. Boy were we happy! I ordered the 2 fish tacos, and a chicken Tamale. MMMmmmmMMMM! The tacos were very fresh and tasty. The assortment of Salsas were definitely fun to try. The spicy could be a little hotter, but thats just me. The medium was super flavorful, and the sweet was pretty tasty too. My Tamale was one to remember. Bigger than most I have had in a while, and I was pleasantly surprised with the cheese melted on top... two thumbs up for that!  Plenty of seating, fun music for the scene, all around great place. From the reviews below I might have  to hit this place up for happy hour and get some $1 tacos!
author: Miguel V.

description: Probably the best taqueria in the Mission! My buddies and I come here every once in a while for Taco Tuesday. Great tacos, great prices!
author: Marty F.

description: Not a fan yet... maybe I had the wrong meal (taco and enchilada)... the Quesadilla looked yummy. A little pricey for nothing amazing and a long line.
author: Ashley M.

description:
WARNING TO REGULARS: SOMETHING HAS CHANGED AT PV! NEW OWNERSHIP?

I've been coming here for over 10 years and gave them 5 stars back in 2006. Recently things have changed for the worse:

1) They have gotten CONSCIENTIOUSLY careful about portion size, expecially with the tacos. The tacos are now fully half the size that they used to be - half the beans, half the meat, half the lettuce, cheese, etc. Considering they raised prices last year, this is an even bigger deal.

2) The line seems to move at half the speed.

3) The meats don't look as good as they used to.

I'll give them a couple more tries before deciding for sure, but it does seem that they are now cutting corners.
author: C S.

description: I went there on one of the hottest days of the year in the city and it was even hotter inside of this restaurant.  i don't know if they don't have AC or if it just wasn't working that day.  I had a quesadilla and a Coke.  I know, I was supposed to have a burrito, but I didn't feel like one.  I tried a bit of burrito and it was OK, but I've had better.  They had a clean bathroom, especially for SF.  We were very lucky to get a table for 4 at peak time, but it was so damn hot in there that maybe our luck wasn't all that great after all.
author: Tina L.

description:
When I think of a San Francisco Mission Taqueria, this place always comes to mind.  When I have friends who visit from out of town and they want an SF burrito, this is where I take them.  Everything from the food, to the salsa bar, to the ambiance is exactly what SF Taquerias are all about.  You will find less expensive options within a few blocks of here, but this is my go-to place in the Mission for burritos.

My normal order is the steak fajita super burrito.  Their fajitas are cooked to order.  But, their pre-cooked meats are consistently good too, including carne asada, chicken, and al pastor.  The place does get packed, but for good reason.
author: Alan C.

description: Everything was really tasty, and they make it fresh when you order. The ambience is quite non-existent, but if you don't care about dining in what could be a prison dining hall, you'll be fine. Just close your eyes and enjoy :)
author: Dennis G.

description: Panhco Villa catered our party yesterday for the Blue Angels.  They did an excellent job and our guests absolutely loved the food.  Thank you Pancho Villa.  We highly recommend them and will be using them annually (at a minimum).
author: Joe S.

description:
A few words of caution when going here: Hippies smell like homeless people if they don't smell like Nag Champa or Pachouli and ROAMING MARIACHI BANDS ARE CREEPY, CRINGE-INDUCING AND TOTALLY TOO INTRUSIVE. This place is already loud enough without them!

This is the place I take my out of town friends to show them what San Francisco style burritos are like. The Central American influences in the menu reflect the neighborhood so people looking for authentic Mexican should look elsewhere...

I would love to give this place five stars for the food because it's always tasty and even with their price rises over the years I've always found it to be a good value - anyone who thinks it's too bland has obviously missed the salsa bar with sauces, salsa, radishes and peppers.
author: Quartknee K.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE! Haha their happy hour tacos: 1$ per taco. It's the best! And everything I have had so far is fantastic. No complaints! And their salsa bar is always fun to try out. It's a great little taco shop!
author: Catherine C.

description:
you know what's great about PVT?  stormi c. gets so excited in line that she starts hopping around and talking to herself while drooling on her fine fine boo-baies.  this, in and of itself is worth 5 stars.  

i thought the food was decent too.  watch out for the salsa at the 'bar', it is freaking hot.  in the very best of ways.
author: Karen K.

description: I wish I had one of these in my area!!! Good carnitas, al pastor and grilled chicken. Has a salsa bar with about 5 different types of salsas. I don't give it a 5 star only due to the location, price and ugly bathroom. The mission area needs to be cleaned up a bit.
author: E. Y. G.

description: Busy Mexican institution. From reading the wall they've won many awards for their salsa. I had churros, but right now could go for some fresh tacos thinking about this place. Crowded with a line, but if there's a line of people for a burrito joint in a city full of them, you know you're not in the wrong.
author: S S.

description: Pancho Villa is a really good taqueria. If given a choice, I would probably eat at Taqueria Cancun, but Pancho Villa has better salsa and is MUCH cleaner. Now that I live in San Mateo, I hit up the Pancho Villa down here on what seems like a weekly basis. Definitely a landmark in the mission!
author: Ben E.

description: Pancho Villa is pure hype. I hadn't been here for a couple years so I decided to give it another try. The burrito was pretty lame. It was cold when they gave it to me even though I ate it at the restaurant. It was also bland. I mean, it was edible... not terrible but certainly not good and nowhere close to El Farolito which is a full two dollars cheaper. El Farolito is the true king of burritos. Hop on the BART and ride it one stop down to 24th. You'll thank me afterwards.
author: Aaron V.

description: I have to admit, this place might be packed at any hour of the day, look and act like a chain, the food is good yalls! It is good, so if you are on 16th and want a taqueria, wait the wait, it's worth it. It's not the best taqueria in town, but def. better than average. They also have great salsas, try 'em out!
author: M S.

description:
another one of those places that doesn't need my review. a whole shit load of people have already written how this place rocks one way or another. 

i love how the long ass line just moves along lickety split. before you know it you are at the cash register and salsa bar. some damn good salsa's to be had for sure. one of my favorite salsa bars in the city so far. it's all good man. i have had dinner plates, burritos, tacos, stewed meats, and on and on. 

big 'ol security guard to keep you from being shot at i guess. or maybe to keep a homeless person from raiding you plate when you head back for more yummy salsa. damn i'm getting hungry
author: roger b.

description: Good food but i wont eat there anymore just cause of the price.  You can't get out of there without spending over $9 bucks for a buritto with sour cream and avacado.  I just dont think burritos should be expensive.  I don't care how good they are.  There's definitely better for cheaper!
author: Joel J.

description: Super huge plates! I love the garlic shrimp plate and the enchiladas. I don't love the service. The counter people can be super rude if you need a second to decide what you want. I feel the whole "Hurry up and buy" vibe every time I dine here!
author: Yvonne C.

description: This place has some of the best burritos, tacos and quesadillas in the City.  There is always a huge line to get in and you are always assured of an entertaining street show out front starring roaming mexican cowboys with guitars, heroin addicts, meth-head tweakers with dogs, indie rocker vixens and other assorted crazies.  I love this place! Parking is difficult, but not impossible.
author: Rick H.

description:
i just keep coming back.. Pancho Villa is the joint. 

i know this place is super hyped... but i just really can't find a reason to hate on it.. 'cept for the fact that the spanish rice is suspect for being chicken broth-based for vegetarians.  (this keeps it from being a 5 star)

but seeing how i don't like rice in my burros anyway.. let's party!

order away my burro loving brethern. i like the #K (i know, what's with the letters for the veg selections and having to say "i'll have the NUMBER K please") but it is super simple: beans, cheese and salsa. the vegans can order lots here and the tofu ranchero stuff is rocking. 

great salsa bar! HOT CARROTS and radishes.

great chips (heads and shoulders above Cactus or Cancun) which is reallllly important to me. 

great agua frescas (limonada is my tops).

great service including door man and bussers.

great mariachis.

clean. inexpensive. easy to get to on foot or bike.

i think this is still my favorite taqueria in the Mission. i sometimes BART from oakland over to 16th street just to eat here.. making it a really expensive burrito. but really, what is life all about?
author: Clarence B.

description: late evening hours....bustle of crowds...hungry lines long....decent burrito joint....daze of mission....cutting of lines....quick horchata the order...too full to endulge in a pura carne burrito....surprise of tacos....mini soft taco flaps...mount everest of toppings....a salad?...a taco?....dos flaps to make dos tacos?....
author: Hen A.

description: All i can say is where else can you find a juicy delicious beef tongue burrito? The meat is juicy, melts in your mouth, and is cooked in a great sauce. On a side note the fish tacos are off the hook as is everything else on the menu.
author: Anton G.

description: Pancho Villa serves up some good burritos.  The line/ordering process can get a bit crazy when busy, which is fairly often.  Seating is ample for the most part.  There's plenty of veggie choices on the menu (e.g., tofu ranchero).
author: Marsha Z.

description: This is hands down the best all around Mexican place anywhere (including Mexico!), an order and sit restaurant with taco stand feel, all in one, the best of both worlds. You get one person who makes your food down the line (don't be intimidated my the length of the line; they have usually 15+ people behind the counter helping you) the people are very nice and efficient. The prices can't be beat and the Nachos are big  enough for three! My favorite is of course their burritos, meat or veggie (depending on my current mood) no matter what I get it is always awesome. Love the rice; it has peas and carrots, soooooo good!!!! If ever you're in the area you simply must go here.
author: Briana D.

description: Love this place, the potions are pretty big and the quality of the meats are A++++!
author: Andre B.

description: Ok, I don't particularly crave for Mexican food but if I would this place is IT!  It serves better mexican food than mexico or san diego!  I only tried the hot and spicy prawns and it IS da bomb!  I've got such a kick outta it that I'm craving to go back there again the next day!  The line's always long but it's definitely worth the wait!
author: Cathy Y.

description: Mediocre burritos with an oversized reputation.  The salsa bar is great; can't complain there.  Still, I think P.V. rides its reputation a little too much and overcharges for a burrito that falls short of other Mission establishments like El Tonayense, La Corneta and certainly El Farolito.
author: Freccia S.

description: One of the better mexican restaurants in the city.  They have really tasty burritos and excellent nachos.  I prefer La Corneta in Glen Park overall, but only by a little bit.  My only complaint is that you usually have to wait in a line and it can be tough to get a table.  If you're willing to deal with that, though, this place is totally worth it.
author: Chad H.

description: Over rated, over priced and nothing special.  I'll take any Taco Truck any given day over Pancho Vila.
author: Edward P.

description:
After a night of just drinking and enjoying a lazy afternoon, we decided to go here for a quick bite. 

My friend ordered a cheese quesadilla, pork taco, beef taco and shrimp. I ordered 2 fish tacos. Boy, was I h u n g r y! 

I enjoyed spending time with my friend and the weather was fantastic! I could not ask for anything more except food!

I used to come here all the time but for some reason, this time the fish taco did not taste good. Something was missing. Sauce perhaps.

The chicken tacos I order from the taco truck in San Bruno seems to taste better compared to the fish taco. 

I will come back here again just to see if it's just that one day my fish went array.  Maybe I should try chicken and the shrimp instead of the fish.
author: Lileth M.

description: With so many reviews already for Pancho Villa, why bother? Because I wouldn't be able to live with myself if I didn't broadcast to the world that the Pancho Villa Beans, Rice and Avocado vegetarian burrito with refried black beans, and a watermelon agua fresca just might be the most amazing meal known to man.
author: Sharon T.

description: The burritos here are juicy and filling, but don't order the nachos unless you like chips and salsa with a smattering of cheese.  The selections are fantastic.  You pick your tortilla (four options), beans (six options), meat (? options), salsa (six options).  You will not leave hungry and service is prompt and fast.  Try the Carnitas!
author: Sam L.

description: Awesome happy hour!  Great tacos!  For a dollar each, what more could you ask for?  Nothing.  The meat (chicken) was super flavorful and the tortillas were perfect.  Once I added my salsa, the taco was perfect!  That's all I have to say.
author: Cara D.

description: Prawn tacos are mouthwateringly great and the salsa bar contains some of the freshest and most plentiful salsas I've ever had. Rock on, Pancho.
author: Emily M.

description: I loved the food here.The tostada was so crisp and fresh. .there was an excellent selection of vegetarian enchiladas and burritos...I was actually tempted to try everything..(that doesn't happen very often BTW).And so many types of salsas !! Plus its so cheap!! Hell yeah, its awesome!
author: Natasha I.

description: Food was EXCELLENT for a great price! Location is on the edge of the Mission. Limited seating.
author: Amy B.

description: BEST Mexican food North of San Diego. Enough said. If you havent been already, go there tonight.
author: Arti D.

description:
Ugh, I always see lines out the door of this place. I finally decided to betray my regular places and give pancho villa a shot.

The ingredients were bland, soggy, and pretty much tasteless. I had the super vegetarian. Maybe their meat is so good all the 5-star reviewers can look past the rest. That's the only reason I can think off. 

Two blocks away you can go to Taqueria Los Coyotes, which has lower prices and very tasty food without the line.
author: John B.

description:
i'm embarrassed because i was bragging to all my friends that i know good burritos since i'm from san diego but then i got this place mixed up with some other place and we all went here and it wasn't very good :(

i got a baby burrito with carne asada, and everything just tasted the same.  i couldn't distinguish rice from beans or meat from guacamole.  the salsa bar is great though and a nice employee refills the salsa and wipes it down constantly.  the salsa definitely saved the burrito.

order a combination plate if you come here.  the chile rellanos were exploding hot cheese and tasty and the plate is very generous for the money.
author: Holly B.

description:
highly overrated.

the thing is, their burritos aren't cohesive enough for me. 

i like the firmness and gumminess of the edges of the flour, fully melted cheese evenly distributed, firm but soft-enough beans, the hot, savory almost-saltiness of the rice, fresh, juicy, perfectly seasoned grilled meat or garlic shrimps with the crispness of the greens, and lotsa spicy pico de gallo with the coolness of a light dollop of sour cream. 

i don't get this here.

but i do get it at la corneta taqueria (not the best, but at least better), either in the mission or next to the glen park bart station on diamond. 

i also get a much better (though still not the best) burrito at sf favorites, taqueria cancun or el farolito.

this place is doable, but to me, the ratings don't justify my experiences.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
When I was new to the Bay Area, over 8 years ago,  a little doe-eyed Southern-Californian 18 year old, bright-eyed and bushy-tailed very very homesick for my mom's home-cooked Mexican food I was told to take BART to the Mission, get off on 16th street and walk around the corner toward Valencia. There I would find Pancho Villa. And so I did, and I was happy...for a while. The demise of their quality began about 4 years ago when I bit into a chile relleno burrito I'd ordered there and it was DISGUSTING! The egg batter-fried shell the chile relleno had was hard, crunchy and too greasy (it's supposed to be supple and smooth with the texture of an omelette), the green chile was hard as well, the seeds hadn't been removed, and the cheese in the chile was chunked inside, not fully melted. Ick. Never again. I stopped going there.

This week I found myself in the Mission trying to grab a late night burrito with my honey only to discover that one of my favorite places, El Toro, on the corner of Valencia and 17th (yes, I know it's owned by the same people who own Pancho Villa but it is WORLDS better) is under construction and closed! The wait was too long at Puerto Allegre, also another favorite of mine and we didn't want to go all the way over to El Farolito on 24th and Mission (my absolute favorite for tacos de carne asada) as it was getting late. So, we decided to give Pancho Villa another try. Big mistake. We shared a carne asada "especial" burrito with guacamole, cheese, rice and refried beans. The burrito was soooooooooooo salty. The guacamole tasted like someone had literally dumped a whole shaker of salt in there. The saltiness was so overpowering I couldn't even finish my burrito half. Past that, the carne asada was so completely bland and tasteless. 

In their defense the service is great, fast, the place is clean and they do have a decent little salsa bar, they still fry their own chips (unlike other taquerias in the Mission), the Horchata is okay, and the musicos playing mariachi is always nice, too.  If only it were as good as it looks. Sigh. But, a good burrito is a good burrito, and alas, Pancho Villa does not a good burrito make.
author: Dee I.

description: It's edible...but this is nothing like the Mexican food I'm used to in the Dago.  What up with the mushy tortillas?
author: Max B.

description: La taqueria is a very good taq. it has grilled steak and chicken which i like alot and good beans and rice. that is key to a good burrito! the servings are good and the prices are fair. id say one of my favorite burrito spots. Not the best but they are up there!
author: Daniel C.

description: I have spent many a meals at Pancho Villa. I have already moved onto El Buon Sabor. However, I still go to Panchos cause if the other joint is closed, El Pancho is usually open. they also make two veggie burritos. A tofu burrito which is simply delish, and a garden burrito with grilled veggies. I can't vouch for this one, cause I keep getting the tofu burrito when I come. Pancho Villa is very consistent, the people are friendly even when they are overwhelmed, and they're right off of bart!
author: malarky j.

description: Amazing, Love it. Great salsa and a cool place to hang out in the mission.
author: Sasha K.

description:
We just left the Warriors game (where we got to sit in box seats) and just downed a couple of very large beers. We entered Pancho Villa with empty stomachs and a slight buzz. Instead of doing like my sister and her husband and sharing 3 tacos, Abby and I ordered 3 each. These were not small tacos. The carne was definitely the best, but the carnitas was not that far behind. Prices weren't bad for all 3, but did seem expensive if you just ordered 1 taco.

If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd come back routinely. I give Pancho Villa Taqueria 3 and 1/2 out of 5.
author: John Paul N.

description: Standard Mexican fare. I had a chicken burrito and a strawberry nectar. Not the best but not the worst I ever had. It was hot in there! Someone turn on the AC!
author: John S.

description: My favorite vegan burritos in SF, hands down. Instead of using soyrizo or some other fancy vegan-specific ingredients, Pancho Villa just has really great rice, beans and veggies that speak for themselves. My favorites are the beans, rice and avocados or the grilled vegetables. A tip when ordering their vegetarian burritos: order by the letter printed next to it on the menu rather than the description (e.g., "D" for beans, rice and avocados) to be sure they get your order right.
author: Tim M.

description: pricey, but almost worth it. the grilled veggie burrito owns, there was like broccoli and mushrooms and potatoes in there. and i always appreciate a place with a large salsa selection, and even more so when there's one that's actually spicy.
author: Monika S.

description: I used to be whatever about this place but then I got a super taco and it was fucking retarded. Two little corn tortillas with about 8 vertical inches of ingredients stacked on top of them. At first you feel like a tool for eating a taco like it's a salad, but you're like, "fuck it," because you just got a fuck load of food for three bucks..
author: Tim S.

description: This is some of the best Mexican food I've had in a long time. I recommend this restaurant to anyone in the area. The food is top notch, and the salsa bar has an excellent selection with many award winning salsas. It has been very busy each time I've gone in, but the line is well worth the wait and speaks well of the quality of the restaurant.
author: William M.

description: Great Mexican that I wish was closer to my neighborhood.  You'll stand in line to order but the tables clear pretty fast and the food is very good, decently priced and largely portioned.  Good aguas frescas and sometimes and irritating mariachi band which actually just adds authenticity.
author: Jill D.

description: Good lengua but I favor taquerias that grill their tortillas. Also a little bit pricier than you average Mission food log.
author: patrick g.

description: Solid taqueria. Delivers what you expect--a bit polished and a little chain-y but nothing wrong with the food.
author: Mark T.

description: My favorite place for authentic Mexican food...great value, great portion, just wonderful...our of of towner friends love this place too!
author: Yan M.

description: This place has a great salsa bar with all the works. The seats there kinda suck (stiff leather stools) and aren't real great for anyone of the particually large persuasion, but its a great place to go before you head out to delerium, kilowatt, or any of the other bars in the area. Not open as late as Taqueria Cancun, but they have a great selection of foods and the lines tend to go quicker, plus there is more seating.
author: Eric O.

description: Lets face it, this isn't the best Mexican food you will ever have.  But its not the worst either. I like the fact that you can customize every aspect of your selection.  You can choose the type of beans, rice, meat (or vegetarian), how hot your salsa is.  Just don't go there if you are feeling indecisive.  It could take hours.
author: Melissa G.

description: This place used to be kind of good, but lately (the past 5 years), it's been tasting pretty crappy.  I usually only get burritos here... both carne asada and grilled chicken, but MAN.  They put way too much meat (which should be a good thing) only that it's some dry ass chopped up beef/chicken tasting like it's 2 days old.  Oh well... there are much better places around the corner.  Oh, and they're overpriced for what you get.
author: Michelle H.

description: I moved up from San Diego a while back and was spoiled with great Mexican food. Not until I found PVT did I believe there was good Mexican food in Northern California. They make an awesome vegetarion burrito and don't use lard in their cooking. It's a great meeting place before heading off for a night in the City.
author: Katie U.

description: Although I highly favor, El Farolito's, Pancho Villa is second to none.  With a huge menu and almost everything you would request in a taqueria, this place will no doubt please your hunger.  If you are drinking or partying up the block at Skylark bar or around the corner at Blondie's I believe PV's is open late night for your after-drinking hunger.  If you opt out of the sausage stand or tamale lady hovering in and around the neighborhood go to Pancho's!!!!!  The difference between PV and Farolito is that everything is PV is fresh and on the healthy side.  They offer the green tortilla, brown rice and offer a veggie menu which includes tofu, etc.  I even think their sour cream is on the light side.  If you want down-home street style mexican food and don't care about calories, go to Farolito's!  If you don't want to feel heavy after you eat a huge burrito, go to Pancho's!
author: Chris S.

description:
When one tires of wrestling methjunkies and purchasing stolen goods at 16th and Mission one can refuel and kindle that old flame in authentic mission style,  Pancho Villa.  No funny stuff, they got security, desperado trios posing as musicians, bulletproof screen for the long line of speedyquesadilla artists, crazy dude with twin cleavers doing a drumroll over a heaping mound of still-quivering chickenflesh.It is truly a sight to behold. Mixed crowd, intimate lighting, leather chairs, everpresent queue, genuine Mission weirdos-delux, trannybar next door, 5000calorie portions...awesome
     And roasted jalapenos, pickled green and orange stuff, red and black chunky stuff, free utensils, lotsa beers,  wow! you'll almost ignore the syringes littering the lavatory floor..you leave sweating and bloated, eyes bloodshot, waves upon endless waves of chili-induced ecstacy guide you back to the cold streets, and for once you feel truly alive
author: owl c.

description:
One of my favorite mission burrito spots.  Vegan friendly because their beans and rice are lard and chicken broth free.  The line is usually pretty long, but moves quick.  

They give you lots of options to really personalize your burrito experience.  Choose from whole or refried, pinto or black beans.  More than five different salsas. Avocado or guacamole etc.

cons:  As amazing as their wet burritos are, I usually refrain because it's a pain to try to eat one with plastic cutlery.

16th & mission isn't the most desirable of locations... but we're all used to this by now aren't we?

Update:  I am to understand they had a 'Yes on 8' sign in their window.  Not cool.
author: Jasmine W.

description: My favorite standard super vegetarian burrito in SF. The beans are so delicious they alternately make me want to cry or start making out with my burrito. It's kind of hard to contain myself here. It's not unusual for me to BART over from the East Bay just to grab one of these burritos.
author: Tiffany O.

description: Great. Fresh. Tasty. Fast. Get the chicken ceasar salad. I know it's not a Mexican dish silly people but the way it's prepared at Pancho Villas it is. No anchovies I don't think. Been to quite a few taquerias and this one is up there with the ones I like the most.
author: Johnny J.

description: I cry when I think of this place because here in NY you can't get a good burrito. On a visit to the bay area in 1991, my best friend took me here to  get a burrito, and it stuck, literally and figuratively. Years later when I moved to SF I tried bunches of Taquerias to try to decide which was the best. Pancho Villa won every time. It still wins and I also love the salsa bar, the  Aguas Frescas and the occasional mariachis. Every time I go to SF this is one of my first destinations.
author: Tina E.

description: Ypu know, it's good for Mexican food in SF.  But I'm from San Diego.  And it dosn't compare.  By my Mexican food standards, the burritos here are expensive, small, and lacking in flavor.  But perhaps I'm used to the burittos that are bigger than newborns and cost about $3-4?  Regardless, the food here is really good actually, maybe the best you'll find in SF.  And it seems pretty clean.  But god.  I miss tacos in Tijuana.  And burittos in San Diego.
author: Angela H.

description:
i spent four hours in pancho villa. . . 

for the sake of art. sort of. and free beer. and friendship. the place is known for being pretty good, but now i know good people are behind the whole joint! one of the brothers (damn, i forgot his name and he was so nice) that own the place let my buddy hang his portraits of san fran street people and for the "opening" provided free beer! for anybody that asked! it was amazing! we were there for hours, met new people and had a great time. and a bunch of burritos.

shout out to the fish taco!
author: Chelsea B.

description:
Pancho Villa is the best.

It's not even really about the burritos, which are also awesome. It's about the salsa bar. As everyone has already said.

Eat the orange salsa!
author: Alisa W.

description: Had to give it 5 stars.. its still freakin good.. i suggest you go to the one in San Mateo.. better parking...
author: Reese D.

description: It's been a while, but yesterday we had lunch at La Pancho Villa.  The only thing that has changed since I started going here in the 80's is the colored wall menu complete with photos so the uninitiated can see what their food looks like before ordering, the guacamole is a different recipe (used to be smooth-my favorite) the salsa bar is the same and of course the prices went up.    Carnitas was juicy and in chunky as ever, and the line at 1PM was waning, but not for long.  Keep up the good work.
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description: Best Taqueria ever!  I moved away for 3 years and craved this place!  Happy to get back!  Great salsa...awesome burritos!
author: Lily B.

description: Fun concept, and the variety found at Pancho Villa's incredibly fresh and flavorful salsa bar is frequently my sole reason for visiting.
author: Aaron J.

description: My go-to-taqueria.  But skip the burritos and other stuff -- the secret winner here is the chipotle prawns served with rice, beans and tortillas.  Ask for it with the prawn shells peeled to save yourself some work. Absolutely fantastic.
author: Suresh K.

description: This place is always crowded and I'm impressed with the wide variety of vegetarian options they have. Service is quick and everything is always fresh. Tofu and black beans taco is my favorite! Make it extra hot hot hot!!
author: Perry S.

description: This is my favorite mexican food in San Francisco.  I lived in San Diego for many years and I feel that over-all the Mexican food down there is better, but Pancho Villa Taqueria is one of my all time favs. And I'd recommend this place to anyone- the meats are good and clean and they have many vegitarian options.  Also, one of the most important things, the salsa is great!  There might be a line to order, but it usually moves quick.  The service is great and the price is right.  The only downside is that I wouldn't recommend it for a nice romantic sit down dinner (Although I ate there on my birthday).  Pancho Villas is more for the to-go order or sit with a friend for a few minutes. Oh and the beer is cheaper than most of the bars next door.  Sit and have a couple before going out!
author: sonrisa m.

description:
when you can get a complete meal with an alcoholic beverage all for just under $10, you automatically get a star! unless it's really really crappy food, which is not the case here!

pancho villa is almost like a tourist attraction but i don't mind being the tourist and going there for their super fresh fish tacos and burritos that are wrapped so tight you can have one in each hand and double fist down the street! plus they have a complete salsa bar that appeals to all levels of hotness!

i'm sure there are tons of taquerias in the mission that are five stars. i'll have to try out the next time i'm in sf. but for now, pancho villa will be getting my $10!
author: Diana L.

description: When I'm feindin' for a Burrito, this is the place to go in SF.  One of my favorites used to be La Cumbre in San Mateo but now I think I have a new favorite, or at the least they are equivalent in terms of hitting the spot.  One really minor issue I did feel was when it was finally my turn to order after waiting in the long long line (which wasn't too much of a problem for me), the person who took my order ran off to make it without me being able to walk her through what I wanted and didn't want in my carne asada burrito.  They are way too much in a hurry to get you your food without checking with you.  Anyone else ever have that issue?  The food is still excellent though.
author: Ahmed B.

description: Took my parents here when they were visiting from the Midwest.  Deliciousness all around. A little chaotic, but the food was great.
author: Sarita T.

description:
impressive salsa bar, not so impressive mexican food. 

SD Mexican food is greater than SF Mexican food. for DAMN sure. 

I like my simple big and meaty burritos from down south. I can do without the rice and beans etc. I could have gotten my burrito sans beans and rice, but really what would be left? the meat isn't good enough to stand on its own. The way that they make the burritos made me feel like i was at a Chipotle. I will give props to their awesome salsa and free chips. I agree with my friend that brought me their... San Diego does need free chips :)
author: Rochelle I.

description: This is a solid place. For sure. 600+ reviews claiming Poncho Villa saved their life after a night of debauchery in the mission can't be that far off right? The burritos are good, a solid good, but they are not orgasmic. The Al Pastor doesn't have that special little something that makes you go "Oh lawrdy there's a party in my mouth!" Nope, it doesn't do that, but the never ending radishes and pickled jalapenos/carrots are a big plus in my book. The Salsas are good and having a few different kinds to choose from makes me happy. So if you're in the area yeah check out this corner stone of mission taquerias...
author: Len S.

description: The burritos here are the typical nor cal style burrito.  I have yet to eat anything that comes close to an authentic burrito that you can find in southern cal.  Two burritos (non-supersized), a XL juice, and a churro was $23.  Why?  Burritos should be cheap.  I just want a $4 carne asada with gaucamole.  No beans, rice, sour cream, dust, or flowers.  Gemme my meat and advocado.  The burritos here can really add up if you decide to make it a super with cheese, lettuce, sour cream and some other random things.  You can also make it wet (*snicker*) for an additional cost.  So if I made my steak and prawn burrito a super wet steak & prawn burrito it would have cost almost $15.  Crazyness if you ask me.  The quality of the meat however is pretty good but on the dry side for my taste.
author: Fatty A.

description: I moved to New York last August and it's been months since I had a burrito worth calling a burrito.  Came back to SF last week to visit friends and family and made a requisite stop at Pancho Villa's.  Super burrito con carne asada, frijoles refritos, y salsa picante por favor!  Ay dios mio.  The first bite was just heavenly and I immediately sank into a blissful state of contentedness.  Spent the rest of the day rubbing my happy belly.
author: Emily L.

description: Great burritos with fresh ingredients and clean environment plus a doorman makes me a happy customer. Grilled chicken and the shrimp burrito are both good.
author: Phil M.

description: With 343 reviews already I hardly even need to say anything, but simply to endorse this place as the very best burritos EVER. I don't eat most meat, but they offer really great seafood and tofu options, which very is rare for a Mission Mexican place and their food is all lard free - extra points! Also, their employees are fast and friendly and it's always been clean behind the counter whenever I've been there :)
author: Hazel Grace D.

description: What really made me enjoy this place is the salsa bar. If it wasn't for that I probably would have gave this place 4 stars instead of 5. The only problem I really had with this place is that I wish they put more portions in my burrito. If they did then I would have loved the burritos more. It was tasty though, but give me some more meat!
author: Sonlay V.

description:
I've been coming here for 10+ years and it's consistently one of the best Mexican Food places in the city. I love the vast menu and the fresh salsa bar!!!

Great place to people watch, look at the rotating wall art and listen to Mariachi music!
author: Donald C.

description: This place whips up some good, inexpensive, fast taqueria food like no one's business.  Located just a short walk away from the scary 16th and Mission BART station it's well worth the trip if you don't already live in the neighborhood.  Their meats are cooked wonderfully and chopped into nice managable bits.  No worries about biting into your burrito and pulling out all of the filling.  They have their food line pretty well organized.  You go down the line and tell them what you want as they make your order to your specifications.  I wish they had this system at the Embarcadero location.  If you have a craving for taqueria food then this place has to be on your short list of places to go.
author: Luis M.

description: I like everything about this place, and I don't mind waiting in line.  I would probably rather go here than anywhere in the area.  The place is cavernous, the food is great, the salsa bar is awesome, good agua frescas and good art on the walls.  There is even a door dude to pull open the door for you.   What more do you need?  I don't care if all my friends say this is the white people's burrito place!  Heck, I am a white people!  Really good food and darned good salsa and plentiful seating and that's good enough for me!
author: RJ M.

description: This is one of the best taquerias i've been to.  The only downside is the price is a little high compared to the cheap $5 burritos i'm use to.  The salsa are award-winning and you can really taste the freshness in the food.
author: Brandon L.

description: I dont get what all the hype is about this place? It's about $2 more then the regular Mission taquerias. The selection of fillings is better and the place is a lot cleaner, but if you're in the Mission....those shouldnt be that much of a concern. I got a steak burrito, it was about 1/4 smaller then one I would get at Taqueria Can-Cun and El Farolito and more expensive. It wasn't bad, but just overhyped.
author: Dustin L.

description:
I generally go to Pancho Villa twice a week, 'cause they're the only place open late after the climbing gym closes on a weeknight. It took me a while to learn how to order a burrito at PV, but now that I've learned all the tricks, I find it really hard to top their burritos. Other places may hypothetically have better burritos, but unless you know how to order it, you're likely to make a wrong choice somewhere and end up with something less than the theoretical best.

So here are my tips for ordering a burrito at Pancho Villa:
1. For fillings, go for carnitas, chorizo, grilled veggies, or chile relleno. Although the grilled chicken and carne asada are tempting, because that's what you smell cooking on the grill, I think they're too dry.
2. When they ask if you want "mild or hot" salsa, choose option (c) Molcajete [roasted tomato & chile] or (d) chile verde [tomatillo & avocado]. They're way better than the out-of-season pico de gallo-type "mild" and "hot" salsas.
3. All the beans are good. Whether you go for whole (black or pinto) or refried (also black or pinto) is a matter of how moist you want your burrito on a given night.
4. Unless you can really pack it away, go for a baby burrito. It's still too much burrito for all but the most ravenous appetites, and it'll put your total under $5.
5. Add cilantro and green onions. They don't cost extra, and they add kick.
author: Jessica J.

description: Mad delicious veggie taco. Is about $1.85, and they hook it up with a wide variety of plant material, including appearances such stars as the zucchini, carrot, broccoli, and bell peppers. There were others, but it's been a while, so I forget what they were. I never thought $1.85 could go so far. Also, mad tasty chips and salsa.
author: Ashley M.

description: I love the burritos here!  They have good vegetarian options and very very fresh salsa.  They also offer many varieties of drinks.  It's fun to be able to try different things.  Cheap, fast, and delicious!  That's how I think burritos should be.
author: Vivian H.

description: My go-to burrito place in the Mission.  I can't usually finish a whole burrito so enter their brilliant menu item: the baby burrito!  With some Al Pastor and guac, my stomach will be happy all day.  They are quick, cheap, and all the ingredients are very fresh.  I love the variety of salsas and such in the back.  I like the green-guac looking one, but beware it is SPICY!  Bonus is the awesome busboy who can tell you what day of the week you were born on.
author: I-Chant C.

description: Great place!  I love their tacos (3 for $7) which is not cheap but not too expensive.  But the meat is to die for.   I usually get one carne asada, a pastor and carnitas.  But always debate if I should get two carne or pastor as those two, I believe, are their flagships.  It's what keeps me coming back  My good friend meets me for lunch by taking BART from Lake Merritt to 16th Street (10 minute ride) so the location is easily accessible!
author: Martin I.

description: Decent food and I definitely felt like I was in Mexico or something, but the overall experience was a little disappointing for how long we waited in line.  My meal was $11, which isn't bad considering that one of their burritos serves up 2 meals for me.  However, my beef is (well I had chicken) is that the contents of the burrito were cold.  Including the meat.  Ended up having a few bites there and enjoying it more reheated at home.  Another thing that slightly irked me is that the musicians panhandled during the meal.  Get enough of that on the street, don't need it while I am eating!
author: Amy Z.

description: Cheap agua frescas and tofu tacos. The occasional Mexican folk duo singing to you. The salsa bar is awesome. They have spicy pickled veggies and whole jalapenos. Pull up a battered old stool and have a seat. There's always some people-watching to be had in the Mission and PV Taqueria is no exception (though the people who wander into El Toro, their smaller sister on Valencia tend to be a little more interesting). The food is yummy, there is one woman behind the counter with bright blue eyeshadow, and the service is consistently good. I'm a total sucker for the tofu taco, bean and cheese burrito and my boyfriend heartily enjoys the tofu ranchero. Extra points for the Pancho Villa decor!
author: Natalia C.

description:
This place is not my favorite burrito establishment, but it does the trick when I need my burrito fix. I think this is more a place where you go after a few drinks (they're open late), or if you're starving and want something quick that will satiate your hunger. It's also a decent place that is close enough to Dolores Park where you can order to go and eat it in the park on a Sunday afternoon with friends.
I wouldn't crave the food or burritos from here per se, but I do appreciate some of Pancho Villa's qualities.
I wouldn't come here for a veggie or a BRC (bean, rice & cheese burrito), I'd come here for more of a meat based burrito. Their refried beans taste a little nutty, not fresh homemade like La Palma's beans. 
I recommend their Al Pastor burrito, with a little sour cream, black beans, salsa roja, and rice. It's always consistent, sometimes they get carried away with the green onions in it but for the most part it's pretty yummy. They do take cards, but I recommend bringing cash, as they have once double charged me (jerks).
author: Kristy H.

description:
love love love this place! :)

awesome fresh burritos. i always get carne asada, but the flautas and tacos are good too! friendly staff, clean environment & very affordable. the chips are fresh and crispy too with a cart full of extra toppings and 3-4 different kinds of salsa.
author: krismarie b.

description: There's no point in trying to improve perfection, this place is as good as it gets,  The Super Taco is amazing, the Steak & Prawn quesadilla is "Da Bomb" and the Salsa is the California State Champion. If you don't hit this place up you're missing out.
author: Sean V.

description: Whenever I'm in the Mission, this is where I end up eating. Whenever I'm wandering around SF and not sure what I'm hungry for, this is where I end up eating. I don't do the "THE BEST" garbage, because everyone's got an opinion, but Poncho Villa is by far my favorite cheap quick Taqueria in the city. I've been going there ten years, and they've never done me wrong.
author: Stefani P.

description:
This is the greatest Mexican food in all of San Francisco!

I've been here dozens of times and never has there been a lack of customers.  This restaurant is busy for a reason, it is fast, tastes amazing and reasonably priced.  

Try the Carnitas Super Quesadilla, extra crispy.  That is my favorite!
author: Seth H.

description:
my dad's shop used to be around the corner, and we often had lunch from here.

yummy mexican food!
author: Sheri N.

description:
good size for the super burrito. too brightly lit and too clean for a mexican joint, seemed like it a fast food chain. better then average food for the rpice and the time of the day tho i heard some good things about the place round the corner, 'la cumbre' but was closed ...

guess i was out lookig for one of those divey places which sells authentic mexicna food and one that kinda looks sketchy but actually isn't, u know like one of those street meat people...
author: jigi s.

description: This place is GOOD and that is why they are so successful.  The perfectly steamed tortilla, fluffy rice, wonderful assortment of fillings and salsa. Yum.  I know it's not the most "underground" or "best kept secret" type of place, but I don't care.  I'm not reviewing the Black Eyed Peas, I'm reviewing a burrito.  And it is good.
author: Val U.

description:
probably one of the best authentic mexican food in the city.
reasonable price and portion, although most of the time order 2 entree or some side order. tasty spicy chicken, good fish taco.
try some jarritos or fruit juice,, refreshing.
with live music and security guard, nothing beats that.
if you don't like crowd, try the other location on b street, san mateo
author: Suki S.

description:
I was in San Francisco on business and Pancho Villa was recommended to me by the hotel concierge and a sales girl at Anthropologie -- I am so glad I followed up! 

The salsa bar is excellent and I especially loved the green and spicy salsa options. Yum. I ordered a baby burrito, which was literally the size of an infant, and stuffed full of veggie goodness.  I was really impressed with the variety of options, especially the veggies which were all fresh. Again, Yum.
