author: kathleen m.

description: I feel like it is almost totally unnecessary to write a review about PV simply because it is THE BEST pub crawlin' food EVER!  I went there on double date night Friday after drinking a few at the local bars and had oh so yummy shrimp nachos...yummmmm...eeee. One of the best things about that place (apart from the chow) is the people watching. Friday night had pretty boy couples with lots and lots of make up on, a couple of homeless kids, a table of girls stuck in the Cyndi Lauper 80's, whole families,a punk rock band, old couples, politicians, and a bunch of  semi-drunk preps looking to nosh...oh wait...that was us. I think it would do the owners some good if they stayed open till, say 3am.?? They have a security guard in case us crazies get out of hand.  Just hire two more!
author: Kris K.

description: The best! I love Pancho Villas. I love the chicken tacos.
author: Amber L.

description: How this place gets mentioned as best burrito in the city I will never know. To me it is overpriced and always leaves me unsatisfied. There are so many better places nearby. They do have good salsa but besides that, i'm going to El Faralito.
author: Robert H.

description:
something about mushy burrito taste doesn't do it for me.  i like my flavors distinct.  maybe the burritos are not the way to go here, but me and others with me were not impressed.  and i was damn hungry having not eaten since boarding a plane in new york 8 hours earlier, so that should have been working in their favor.

too much rice?  too wet salsa?  poor ingredient distribution?  i'm not sure what did it, but i have had sooo much better than this.
author: Lindsay M.

description: A couple of my co-workers are HUGE fans of this place. It's always packed during lunch, but the line moves fast. Food is decent. The baby burritos are the perfect size. It's hard to find more than 2 seats. You are probably better off taking your food to-go.
author: Mary C.

description:
pura carne - all meat.  make it a super burrito and its basically normal but no rice and beans.  it's a variation on something that makes me happy.

its clean, not so fast . . . and not super cheap, but its not bad.  i'd definitely come back, and say the burrito was good enough to keep me coming back.
author: Jason J.

description: "Eat my tacos" says my Pancho Villa T-shirt to onlookers. And if you do your belly will thank you. From the friendly service, good taqueria food and excellent salsa to the Mariachi band and the bus boy that will tell you what day your birthday is on. He's always right, by the way - except he's not as good at predicting when the Bulls/Cubs will win. I will always come back here. For the food, and for the experience.
author: Brad S.

description: A taqueria worth visiting. Big cheap burritos. The security guard at the door helps everyone form a winding queue, but the line moves quickly. The menu is extensive, with several vegetarian options including strange pseudo-Mexican tofu. The bathroom is clean and you don't need a key, which I alway appreciate because I don't like to bother busy burrito-makers.
author: Claire C.

description: This huge, high-ceilinged taqueria serves great tacos (I'm not a burrito man, I hate refried and black beans). They have the best salsas, and their guacamole is really good (I don't like guac, but I can tell how fresh it is, it's that obvious). I love their huachinango (red snapper) tacos ($2.65). The seats are a little uncomfortable and the interior is a bit spartan. The agua frescas are also great, and you can always get a Jarritos Mexican soda (they taste like candy!). They have another branch in SF, as well as San Mateo, and they own Taquera El Toro on 17th & Valencia as well. There's usually a long line, but it moves fast.
author: Hao L.

description: Not spectacular, but one of the more reliable taquerias around.  Fresh ingredients, the carne asada and carnitas are marinated well, the salsa is tasty ...and the place gets some extra points for being clean (ahem... El Farollito).
author: Andrew E.

description: Just ate here last weekend after about a 2 month hiatus (not by choice!). Um, I love this place.
author: Nora G.

description:
My friend and I would put all of lunch money together and cut school just to get a burrito at this place back when the steak super burrito was still under $6 along with an order of the cantaloupe aqua fresca.  It was good enough to duck behind cars so I wouldn't be seen by my dad who frequented the neighborhood during school hours.  It was a mission but worth it.

It's been years now and I still like the food here even with the price of inflation.  Now that I live in the East bay, I don't stop by as often but I do stop by when I'm in the area.
author: Maryanne D.

description: It's great place to have Mexican food, whether its lunch or dinner. They have excellent workers, who can make your burrito or taco just the way you wanted. You definitely can have it your way. I like how they have the varitey of soft taco shells. Instead of having just the flour, you can have spinach, wheat and red pepper. You can watch them as they prepare your food. You can even watch the cook, grilling the beef and chicken. That is always a sight to see. It's hard to say when is the best time to go, because it seems like the line is always wrapped around the restaurant. You know they are cooking something good.
author: Baseemah R.

description: If you go to a taqueria, and no Mexican people are eating there, then beware.  Sanitized overpriced crap wraps.  Way too much rice, and that ain't nice.  The aguas frescas are good, although again, overpriced.
author: Mark W.

description: Best burrito in San Francisco.  The carnitas super burrito is to die for.
author: Dave L.

description:
this is one of my favorite spots for people watching in the mission. since everything is big, affordable and pretty damn delicious at pancho villa, it has quite a following. on any given night, you can see family, tourists, socialists, anarchists, gangstas, crack addicts, hipsters, yuppies, hippies... hey, even beck was here. if it's good enough for beck, it's good enough for me. 

there's a traveling mariachi band that often pops into pancho villa. be sure to tip them.
author: frisco j.

description: This place is so good that I've been taking spanish lesson there and it kind of backed fired on me. I've mostly been learning to order my food in spanish and I've gotten pretty good at it. But this one time I ordered three dinners all in spanish with great detail but when Rosa I think her name was starting talking to me about more than food a blank expression fell upon my face cause all I understood was five  maybe 6 words. So in english she asked me how I order all that food and can't understand spanish? I don't know but I did my best ocho cinco impression and enjoyed my garlic prawns and black bean.
author: Karim R.

description: Great food and service.  Pricing is great too.  There can be a pretty big line but as it's been said before..  You can usually still get seating.  If you're in the Mission, this is a great place to get a quick lunch or dinner.  They have another location in San Mateo too.
author: R G.

description: **Three and a half stars**This is a decent place for a burrito, taco, whatever Mexican thing you crave. It's awesome when you've been drinking at a nearby bar all day and need food to soak that liquor up. I go with the basics there as the meat has been ok when I've had it. Baby beans, cheese, and rice please. The greatest things about this place are the fresh drinks which are delicious and the baby burritos. Sometimes a whole burrito is just too much, you know? The salsa selection is cool but I'm just all about the super hot red ones, so the variety isn't a big deal to me. Overall, a clean, well lit, safe (that dude at the door) place to stop in for a decent meal.
author: gabby m.

description: aww man, before I was married w/ chitlins, we use to hit this spot regularly for the big shrimp burritos, award winning salsa and refreshing melon drink! Very delicious however, it's pricier than most burrito places in the area. The food deserves a 5 star but man, parking is a toughie. Also, make sure you wear the right colors in this hood. During one of our burrito dinner nights, my friend was confronted by a neighborhood homie talking bout, "I don't like your colors man." Next thing you know, he did one of those birdie calls and the rest of his homies came out the cuts! A fight almost broke out so, what did I do? I snatched the bag with the shrimp burrito from my friends hand and ran to the car! Thank god the shrimp burritos were safe.
author: Bj S.

description: I've been all over SF looking for a great mexican food restaurant. This is by far a favorite. I have daydreams about their salsa. It's soooo good. My only complaint is that it's always packed. Other than that i love love love it!!
author: Willow G.

description: Definitely the best Mexican restaurant in SF. Spicy chicken (in the red sauce) rocks the house in both burritos and in quesadillas.
author: Derek B.

description:
there is ALWAYS a line.
the food is more expensive than most places.

but they have a baby burrito option. c'mon this is one of the greatest things in the world. i have a habit of eating burritos before im supposed to have drinks with people and it never works out. im always way to full to drink anything after. solution? baby burrito.

i agree that if you are on a budget, go for the tacos or better yet, go to another place. i think the food is great and has never let me down. the only complaint that i have...food coma. and really, thats not a real complaint. it hurts but it feels sooooo good.
author: Chan W.

description: The tacos here overflow with the fillings. The "dinner" has the standard rice n' beans n' salad, but the tacos are nice and delicious. Good selection of what I like to call "accessories": Jarritos, churros and Mexican cookies, too. It's one of those "hits the spot" places. And check the myriad of salsa awards on the back wall!
author: Maximillian M.

description:
this has got to be one of the very BEST taquerias in SF.  it's in a large, well lit space.  the line to order food moves super fast.   the staff behind the counter is fluent in spanish and english and they are very efficient in taking your order and preparing it quickly and accurately.  

the "condiments" bar is awesome.  i like a LOT of cilantro and lime.  this bar makes it possible to garnish/ finish your food exactly to your liking without feeling like a pain-in-the-a**.  it offers too many things for me to remember, but i also got some radishes and several kinds of salsa.  

we went on a sunday and i've never seen so many different flavors of aqua fresca being offered anywhere.  i wonder if they have such a large variety offered all week?  (i'll look forward to finding out.)  it was a sunny, warm day in the mission and tons of people were coming in just to pick up an aqua fresca.
the drinks come in 4 sizes of biodegrabable cups (not plastic).  
they offer real (metal) forks and knives for those who are dining-in.

the food rocks and is suitable for all levels of heat tolerance.  the last time we ate there the crowd was very diverse;  about half and half: latino and gringo, with a smattering of asian folks.  there were many families and children.  Everyone seemed to love this place!
author: passion f.

description: This place was packkkked at 9 on a Saturday night--tough to get a table. I was really wanting some queso and I am still on the hunt to find a place that has what I'm looking for :-/ They didn't have any and everything seemed pretty standard though a bit expensive for my appetizer and a beer.
author: Krystha B.

description: Having recently moved back to Missionloin/18th after about 15 years gone, I am rediscovering some old friends like the Walgreen's tar balloon dude, that guy selling my laundry in front of Casanova, and Pancho Villa Taqueria.This is not to imply that PV is ghetto in any way, but in fact is one of the cleaner, fresher, less greasy taquerias in town. This does compromise the taste, because we all know filth is where the flavor is, but only slightly. There are just so many choices here is would be hard not to find something satisfying. Got a to-go order of two burritos, a beer and an aguas fresca which set me back $20 including a tip. My order was right, and I was safely nestled back in my penthouse with a familiar outfit and enough dope for the weekend in under 30 minutes.
author: J. R.

description: Ok the place is essential and very lively. But the food is GREAT! It's the best Mexican food I've ever had in the city. And you can always take away the food to your more comfortable and more quite place :)
author: Steve E.

description:
Fresh ingredients, quality customizable fixins, and easily the best salsa stash in the Mission. I entered Pancho Villa Taqueria because rolling it off my tongue brought me back to my caballero days (and because the door man practically dragged me in). But I go back because I want to dispell the notions my friends harbor that there are better mexican joints in the city. 

Mounds and pounds of marinated meat bubling under an open flame, seafood cooked to order 'a la plancha', and a vegetarian menu to round off even the pickiest of tastes. 

The pollo asado (grilled chicken) and the carnitas are the meat highlights, while the Prawn Cocktail and the Grilled Vegetable Burrito hit the spot for the less carnivorous. The salsa molcajete and the salsa verde strike a perfect balance between spice and garden goodness.

And even if you ain't eatin', there are always new art exhibits on the walls to whet your mind's appetite. 

!!VIVA PANCHO VILLA!!
author: Ashwin S.

description: Yes! Good food, Good price and Great spicy carrots and salsa bar!
author: Marianne s.

description: Pancho Villa is a god sent.  I am no Mexican food critic, but I love some Pancho Villa.  There portions are humongous (I am a weird exception though that can't even finish the baby burrito) and their food is oh, so fresh!
author: Sarah A.

description: Always excellent Mexican food.  They have a great selection of entrees and for the price the quality is very good. Highly recommend them for a quick take out or eat in when cooking is not going to happen.
author: Richard B.

description: This is how you do a taqueria! So much to choose from on the menu and the burritos are HUGE! I could probably OD on the enormity of these things. Add some guacamole and you've got me hooked.
author: Nick S.

description:
STINGINESS and COST-CUTTING ALERT!!

I went in today (they were open early) to pick up a burrito for lunch. What the server behind the counter did was one of the measliest burritos I've ever seen. I ordered a burrito with al pastor (marinated pork). One heaping very small scoop of meat, ams with the rice and beans. there can't be more than 3 oz. of meat in that whole burrito which cost almost $7 with tax. (Other burritos being made by other staff looked much the same in what was being doled out.)

I asked at the register about that. I pointed out that it was essentially the amount of meat put in a soft taco. The counter person told me that the boss had told staff to put less meat on.

This WAS formerly one of my favorite places in the Mission.

You have been warned.

La Cumbre around the corner on Valencia is a good alternative especially for grilled chicken and grilled beef (carne asada) , but not quesadilla and Mariachi's across from La Cumbre is good for other things. (I have a review up for the latter.)
author: Martin F.

description:
Prob my favorite taqueria in the city. I'm a taqueria fan, even though a.) I've not eaten at all, or even most of them, and b.) I don't like burritos. Yes, heretic am I, I can do without the giant roll stuffed with 2 meals worth of rice, beans, meat, etc. All the vitamins and twice the calories needed a day!

So I can't comment on Pancho Villa's burritos. I love 'em because they make a great dinner plate: get the steak and grilled shrimp, with more than adequate rice (a complaint I have for a lot of other taquerias: skimping on the rice is not acceptable!!), creamy refried beans, fresh little salad portions, warm tortillas and the hands-down best guacamole in the city. It's a little expensive for taqueria food, I know, but one combo plate is enough to feed a small family, or at least 2 moderately hungry friends. Plus, salsa bar! -- honorable mention for 2 tranny hooker sightings I've had while dining in.
author: Frida K.

description: Ah disgusting! on my way to pancho villa's restaurant I nearly stepped right into some unrecognizable substance that looked as though it came out the back of someone. Then I went inside and ordered a pollo verde borrito. To my surprise the line was just there. While standing in it I asked my friend what she was getting and she replied with, " hold on sweety im on the phone." She never answered me and later i didnt ask her again because i dont think i really cared much what she was eating. The weather there was beautiful and i think it was a tuesday. If youve never been to San Francisco you should go there soon because its a blast! 4 stars for sure.
author: Cameron Scott C.

description:
Can't go wrong with the Taco's and the soup

Barbacoa, pastor tacos. Beef nachos done individually is excellent. Nice seafood salad. It's very busy restaurant which goes to show that people in the neighborhood appreciate it . Very reasonable prices.
author: Kristen E.

description:
i've been trying out all the best lunch places around 16th and guerrero this week, and pancho villa was definitely on my list (especially after reading yelp reviews). 

i have to say, i wasn't too impressed. my 'especial' carne asada burrito, which cost about $8, was good. not great; not terrible. i guess i was expecting something extraordinary and special. instead, i got standard taqueria fare. 

on the plus side, the place is huge and there's plenty of clean seating if you have a large party. and if you're lunching with picky eaters or with out-of-towners who are scared of dive restaurants, feel confident to check out pancho villa.
author: Maveric V.

description: I will never eat Mexican food with the same enthusiasm again because this restaurant ruined it for me! I live in Boston and we were on vacation in the Bay area. This place blew my socks off with enchillada-ey cheesy spicy goodness. Everything was seasoned and baked to perfection on my combo place #1 and the rice and beans were perfecto. Not only that, but they have a never-ending salsa and condiment bar where diners can pick and choose from a wide variety of pico de gallos and salsa verdes and wicked hot salsas. However, the food is so tasty you don't even need to add anything to enjoy it!
author: Evie U.

description: I'm a die-hard El Farolito fan but a friend convinced me to try Pancho Villa and it wasn't too bad. It's pretty fast food-y. Actually, it IS fast food, but it was good. There's always a line but it moves fast. Portions are large. The quesadillas and super nachos were tasty, as was the fish taco. The fish taco might have been my favorite, actually. Prices are what you'd expect and the food isn't too greasy. A-Ok, my friends.
author: Christine P.

description: If you haven't eaten a thing all day and you're looking for some major sustenance, be sure to check out Pancho Villa in the mission. Major burritos, good nachos and pretty tasty horchata most of the time. Always a line out the door, and for good reason. Their salsa is usually fresh and their grilled chicken, pork and chorizo are usually top-notch. The San Francisco location is great, but I've had really good luck at the San Mateo location more often...
author: Michael E.

description:
Taquerias, like politics and religion, are a disputatious topic. People that you love may come out in defense for some place that plates up gringo-bland salsa and tacos full of soulless cardboard, and no matter how much you argue with them, they still won't agree with you. Damn them. 
Anyway, you'll often find me in line at Pancho Villa. I'm not even sure how this became one of the most frequented taquerias on my list, but it did. Don't get me wrong, there are many great taco stores out there, this is one of many that I love. 
What I like-pollo asado or al pastor tacos. When I'm feeling glum (or the munchies) it's all about a large side of refried beans, a pint of salsa, half spicy half mild pico de gallo, and a big ol bag of chips. Then I park myself at a table, in front of someone's tv, in the park, where ever, and add as much salsa to the beans as possible and eat with the chips. Replenish salsa in beans as needed. 
In favor: close to bart and bars, open late, varied menu to please everyone in your group, cheap. Out of favor: small tables, long line, parking is for crap, sometimes the mariachi bands are a little too loud.
author: Candice L.

description: I am definitely in the minority, but to me, its just OK.  It's too clean and bight to qualify as a Taqueria.   Sure it's big, portion wise, and the menu is huge covering everything from shirmp to asada.    I like the fresh salsas, and the suiza is pretty good, but there are much better burritos to be had.  Plus the line is out the door, and you have to shout to make your order.  Me being vertically challenged, its hard to talk above the glass surrounding the prep area.
author: Michael M.

description: Check it: Me and my girl, eating cold Pancho Villa super burritos in dad's Plymouth with the widows rolled up, perched on top of Mt. San Bruno watching the twinkling Brisbane city lights below, about to make out. What?
author: zach f.

description:
here you can do 2 illuminating things:
1. dos tacos camarones con todo, por favore! (i'm not so good at speaking and spelling espanol)
2. practice your spanish!
author: Holly F.

description: No beef with the Tamales lady, but Pancho Villa and Zeitgeist is a marriage made in heaven.  Late night hours are convenient. Cerveza is moderately priced. I highly recommend that you not overestimate the portions of the food. I thought a burrito and quesadilla suiza would be light, but I was seriously wrong. It felt so good yet hurt so bad. Fortunately I was invited along to a random party in the area where I could exact Montezuma's revenge. So sorry to be THAT guy.
author: Tom B.

description: Pretty darn tasty.  Good happy hour specials.  Cleaner than other burrito shops.
author: Jo W.

description:
while the food was pretty darned good, i have to admit, i had a serious communication problem there and didn't get what i asked for.

however, i believe in 'fate' and ate it anyhow and it was pretty good.
author: Mark D.

description:
personally, i think el farolito's burritos are better. however, they don't come close to the choices you get at pancho villa.

personally, i think the tacos are better than the burritos.  and the vegetarian nachos are first rate, especially if you like avocado.

be prepared for long lines and mariachis if you go during peak hours
author: Steve S.

description: this is my favorite burrito place, especially cause their baby burrito is the exact right size for me to consume. Since they are so busy all the time i have no worry that my chicken or gauc has been sitting there for days under that suspicious heat lamp. the only downside is the chips leave something to be desired. I'm not a fan of really hard thick chips..
author: rukshan b.

description:
so they did mess up my order, and ordering itself was a bit of an ordeal, but i loved their food!

we ordered a carne asada burrito (especial) and the fiesta plate, which were both very tasty.  the carne asada was spot on, and i especially enjoyed the sides of garlic shrimp, sauteed mushrooms and green onions.  the flauta was less than exciting, though.

a highly recommended mexican find!
author: Jill k.

description: Really great burritos (and they come in a baby size, which is actually a reasonable size for a meal), a large selection of quality fresh ingredients, and the best salsa bar in the city.
author: Don H.

description: GREAT Salsa Bar! The BEST burritos are the Puro Carne (Puer/All meat) burritos meaning no fillers like rice and beans! LOVE the variety and the quickness and how friendly everyone is there!! My disappointment though is not them personally it's the way NorCal Mexican food, especially Carne Asada is prepared, not bad at all just different from what I'm accustomed to. This is a GREAT spot and check out the guy that works the salsa bar he knows stuff about birthdays and he's funny!!!
author: Rob L.

description: Since we are heading to Coachella in mere months, the ladies and I are on the Coachella diet. The Coachella diet consists of coffee, water, vodka, marlboro lights, and the occasional slim fast shake. Throw in a daily 5-10 mile run and a couple of high intensity yoga/pilates classes and we'll be hot short and string bikini top ready just in the nick of time. Because I have good friends who want to support me in staying on this diet, I was redirected from Cable Car Pizza to Pancho Villa last night, after a particularly refreshing vodka soda and gossip session at Killowatt. I am a new devotee of the super tofu taco, which I calculate at about 125 calories if you don't actually eat the tortillas (I do not). That's one hell of a post-drink nosh. And diet friendly. And cheap, too. Thanks Rick, for caring as much about the size of my ass as I do. You're a real late-night warrior. Farewell, Pizza! I'll see you after April 17th.
author: Autumn K.

description: "No preservatives, no bull!" is what they have posted throughout the place.  I'm from South San Francisco, so I know good Mexican food and this place holds its own.  My fav is the super carnitas burrito with wheat tortilla and black  refried beans.  Just recently, I put together my "break the bank burrito", which is the chicken and prawn burrito, add steak.  $12, but hey you only live once.   The fresh fruit drinks are not for the potentially diabetic, so be warned.  I don't know when they close, but I normally go there around 11pm and it is pretty crowed then.
author: Jason A.

description: Good run-of-the mill Mexican. Even the baby burrito is quite large. I found the food to be authentic albeit somewhat undistinguished, although it was a good value. When you ask for "spicy" food, expect it to be pretty darn hot.
author: Dana L.

description:
this place needs to dim their lights... it's way too bright in there after usually having been in rather dark or dimmed areas before going in there...
the food is good, but i find the burritos smaller and more expensive than many places in the mission...
i prefer los coyotes across the street
author: charlotte s.

description:
Edit:  I went here last week and the carne asada wasn't flavored and was undercooked, which was terribly disappointing because I was only home for one night and all I wanted was a yummy carne asada burrito.  I also tried an al pastor burrito, which was much better, but I was still disappointed with the carne.  Someone told me that they are just letting things slip, so its hard to say if it was an off night or what, but it was a let down.  Times have obviously changed since I was a kid.  So I had to take off a star.

Original post (4 stars): This place is wicked good, one of the best in the Mission.  I swear my dad made it his life mission to go to every restaurant around the city, and if he says this place is good, you know that he's been to almost every place in the Mission and he has deemed this one worthy of his patronage. I've been going here since I was a kid, still makes bomb ass burritos.
author: Margie N.

description: When I lived in Seattle, I always thought about Pancho Villa. Now, I'm back and love it more than every. It may not be the BEST mexican, but it's pretty damn good and reliable. I usually go for the chorizo or prawn tacos and my husband likes the quesadillas. The salsa bar rocks!
author: Thanya S.

description: Not really sure why there's always such a long line--it's really nothing special.  I decided to try one of the vegetarian burritos once...I'm not sure why.  Anyway, it was bland, as could be expected.  But the other things I've gotten there haven't been that great either.
author: Gina K.

description: pretty typical taqueria. nothing done really well, and nothing done too poorly. the only thing that stands out in my opinion was the salsa bar. I particularly have a thing for salsa verde, and this one definitely had a kick, and trust me, I can handle my own when it comes to spicy food.
author: Ngoc N.

description: Good cheap Mexican food. I have been going there for year and the food has been consistent. I love the grilled chicken and carne asada burritos. And the steak and prawn burrito...Mmmm Mmmm! However, I just noticed how much oil they put on the food they grill (prawns, veggies, etc.). It's kinda gross to see but at the same time I guess it's why the food is so good.The tamales are not the best because they are microwaved. The aguas frescas are also very good and there are plenty to choose from.
author: Oscar C.

description: They're in an somewhat challenged location, but I heard all these good reviews so I decided to try it out. I thought it was a bit pricier than other taquerias I been to. I had the vegetarian nachos for around 6 bucks. I had better for a little less. They were stingy with the cheese. The workers don't look or act too happy. They have some handicapped(he has down syndome) person to 'watch' over the salsa bar to make sure it was kept tidy I guess. Anyways there's other better taquerias in the mission.
author: E W.

description: They truly do have the best salsa's around. Super spicy and full of delicious flavor. I enjoy their carnitas soft taco's especially and I like to wash that down with there pineapple flavored aquas frescas.
author: Ericka A.

description: I hadn't been here in 6 years until today, I stayed away because it is one of the more expensive taqueria's in the area. But overall it was very good. The carne asada was tasty, the burritto was the perfect size, not too overwhelming but I did get it with no rice. I would definitely recommend it, if you're willing to pay a little more.
author: Erin O.

description: Steak and prawn burrito: yeah, it burns a hole in my pocket, but it's so damn good. Love the plates ... they give you a good amount of food. The only thing I hate? When there's some long a** lines. I hate waiting for food. Hate it.
author: Caroline L.

description: Not as good as La Corneta or La Taqueria, but open late, and good location for drunk food stop.
author: Catherine K.

description: Love this place. One of my favorite lunch spots. My feller and I split the steak and prawn quesadilla on a spinach tortilla. It's pretty filling and DANG TASTY. Always been packed when I've been in there, but they've always been well staffed and efficient. It's pretty loud and the seating is not comfortable. Not a place for dates or groups.
author: Casey D.

description: Pancho Villa was my virgin taqueria experience in San Francisco; I was not disappointed.  I ordered a spicy chicken burrito; it was both spicy and flavorful.  They have an abundance of various meat and vegetarian options for the burritos (three kinds of chicken alone!).  The atmosphere isn't amazing; it is loud and busy, which speaks to its popularity.
author: Matt P.

description: I don't know why I've been all shy about giving a shout-out to this place that I frequent approximately once a week. I mean jeez, that means that about 5% of all the food I consume is made here. Actually, way more than that considering the fact that a grilled veggie burrito is bigger than a baby's head. Plus I always stock up on containers of their award winning salsa, and get the large horchata cuz it's only ten cents more. Yeah.. this place turns me into a bit of a piggie. Maybe that's the source of my shout-out shyness.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Best Taco & Burrito joint in the entire Bay Area.  It is the mecca shrine for burritos.  It's a shame that I don't work or live near the Mission, but damn, it's always worth coming here just for a burrito.  Best prices, and portions.  It's so damn good here, my friend said he could've sworn he saw Carlos Santana himself here (he said there aren't many people who wear sunglasses and sit all the way in the back of the restaurant at around 10pm) but I wouldn't doubt it.  He also told me that when he used to live in the Mission, and he was low on cash, this was all the meal he could afford, and it was more than enough to feed him for 3 days.  I think he was exaggerating, but with the amount they give you, and at the price, I almost believe him.

I also want to mention that they have won numerous awards for their salsa, which is also top notch.  I always get at least 3-4 packetfuls and keep the rest of the stash at home, since it's free.
author: Jim N.

description: Nothing wrong with this place exactly. All I've had are their burritos, tacos, and chips, which were solid. It's just that there's a lot of competition in the area and the overall value and quality here were not exceptional. Their meats and tortillas are tasty but the burritos are a little small and overpriced. I wasn't at all impressed by the salsa. Not bad, just not really that great. I might give Pancho Villa another shot at some point, but then again, with all the other options out there, I might not...
author: Brian H.

description: I have to write a review of Pancho Villa at this very moment becasue I want to eat it right now!  The only prob being that it's pretty far away from me.  I would totally have the El Pastor Super Burrito.  It is the f-ing best.  I would just UH do anything for it right now.  With a dousing of lime juice this thing is perrrrfect.
author: Rachel P.

description: This is my favorite place to get a burritto in SF!   My uncle would always bring food home from this place and when I finally learned to drive.  This was one of the first destinations I went to in SF.   Whenever I go to a punk show at Balazo, I stop by here.  It's cheap,, open late,  food is tasty and the menu is massive!  The lines and crowds can be a little intimidating, but the wait isn't to long.  Meat and veggie friendly!
author: Norm P.

description: I'd give this place 5 stars except for the fact that a burrito will run you about $8, which I personally think is a little much.  However, I think you'll come away satisfied with the different meat selections, with the Chile Verde being my favorite.  They give excellent portions and the ingredients mix together very well in the burritos - so cheesy and warm... Yum!
author: Jeffrey J.

description: Among the people I knew on Church St., the debate was not Red Sox vs. Yankees, it was Cancun vs. Pancho Villa. For burritos I prefer Taq Cancun, but Pancho Villa is a good place. It's a nice big space with a security guy to open the door for you. You can get much more than burritos, including fish tacos and fish dishes that are not to be found at Cancun. They have a nice selection of aguas fresca, though a bit more expensive than I prefer. The atmosphere is not bad, and you get a nice selection of salsas for your chips. We ended up here a lot of times on the way to Cancun but realizing the extra three blocks was too far to go.
author: Art K.

description: This is pretty damn good. My carne asada burrito especiale was very tasty but what put it over the top was the salsa. Unlike most places where "hot" salsa is something you can pretty much shove into your eyes and not feel a thing, this place doesn't hold back. It definitely has a great kick. I gotta come back here!
author: Barney M.

description: this is definitely a stop over for my drunk ass on the weekends. lol i recently stopped here for their prawn quesadilla and i gotta tell ya, it was so good!! the perfect blend of sour cream, guacamole, enough grilled prawns, pico de gallo and lettuce kept me afloat.
author: Mika D.

description: Food lacked a lot of flavor and the room was very noisy.  On top of it, you get to watch all the ugly hippies and transients pass by as you try and enjoy your food.
author: Darren V.

description: This place is yum.  The burrito is huge....share with a friend, or take half home with you.  The line is long but moves quickly.  Very good food.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Definitely one of the less sketchy taquerias in the Mission.  Clean and quite large with plenty of seating.  The shrimp cocktail was not my favorite.  The fish taco was decent.  They have about 8 different flavors of frescas.  I like that.
author: Jeanne L.

description: After frequenting the Pancho Villa in San Mateo for years, this location in the Mission just didn't stack up.  Our Super Vegetarian burritos were on the cold side, the cheese unmelted and basically lacking anything special.  I think I will be looking somewhere else in the mission for my next burrito fix.  Still, if I stumbled off the street with no idea what to expect I would think that I had made a decent choice.
author: Jennie J.

description: I am fully addicted to the super vegetarian mojado burrito, which is perfectly complimented by a bottle of Pacifico.  I mean, that is heaven on a plate.
author: Kate C.

description: Ordered a Baby Burrito with Carnitas, avacado, salsa, and cheese. Defintely more than enough food for lunch which included chips and the great salsa bar. The Burrito wasn't the best I've ever had, but was very good. I expected the Carnitas to be a little bit more savory, as it just tasted like normal pork to me. Get the Super if you don't feel like eating for the rest of the day...
author: Nicolas H.

description: There's a reason a line forms out the door during lunchtime. Love the fresh meats and veggies and appreciate the fact they have a variety if you're not into the standard carne asada, chicken or carnitas. They have tofu, grilled fish or shrimp. Also, try the fresh fruit drinks made with strawberries, pineapple or cantaloupe. My personal fave is the horchata. I noticed the prices have gone up and the portions have gone down on at least one of my favorite things (tostada salad). I'm guessing the same has happened across the menu. However, since the food is so good, higher prices won't keep me from coming back to get my Mexican food fix.
author: Mel E.

description: Not the quickest, but everything's made to order, so no worries about bits of cilantro falling in your burrito.  Also, they sell the Mexican versions of Coke & Diet (they're sweeter!).
author: Chris R.

description: Quick, cheap food!  Great place to grab a bite before going out or taking visitors to see The Mission.  Reasonable parking a block away and huge portion sizes will keep me coming back for more!
author: Lucas M.

description: I know that taquerias aren't exactly monuments of cleanliness and food safety. But last time I went to Pancho Villa, I got some pretty serious food poisoning. I admit -- it was partially my fault, because I knew something didn't taste right about my food about two bites into it. But a word to the wise for anyone who eats at taquerias with any regularity: beware the burrito.
author: Blake E.

description: So here's the deal.  Last night I had a not-so-pleasant Pancho Villa experience.  But that wasn't their fault.  Really.  I just found I wasn't in the mood for Mexican.  So why go out to Mexican, you say?  Beats me.  But if you are in the mood for Mexican, Pancho Villa is pretty much the best place in the city.  Their ingredients are always fresh.  And they're cool.  Cool people just seem to gravitate toward the place.  Like, one time Beck actually came in and played.  Or so I heard.  I wasn't actually there.  I went there the next day, you see, because I felt like eating Mexican the following day, not the day Beck came.  But the burritos were still good the day I came too.
author: Igor N.

description: I don't think their food tastes very good.  And it's not that cheap -- last night I got a chicken burrito, nachos, and a beer -- total $16.95.  Same price, really, of Papalote, which by the way is a MILLION times better than this dive.  The fact that people call this the best burrito in SF speaks to the fact that there aren't very many good Mexican places here.  Of course I'm also spoiled by Cactus Taqueria in the East Bay, which has amazing, fresh, local, organic flavor.  It's the same price as Pancho and a BILLION times better.  So I don't know what you all are talking about when you say you love this place and it's amazing and good and cheap.  I'll never go here again.
author: Abendigo R.

description: Super amazingly fast line system that always amazes me.  It's like watching a machine at work when they're taking peoples' orders and wrapping burritos left and right.  Unlike some taquerias, PVT has a well balanced quality menu with all their selections being delish.  They try to keep it simple and it works.  You can and will find cheaper places but PVT does it right all the time and their authentic touch makes it that much better.
author: Sokokyu K.

description: Before I went on a mission taco crawl, I didn't know where to categorize this taqueria relative to all the others in the area.  It doesn't stand out in a good way.  The meat is dry and the salsas are watery.
author: Tim G.

description: This is all about the salsa bar.  It rocks.  The food is good.  Not great, but you know what you are getting.  I think it is also a bit more idealized in my mind as I went on a Good date there.  He gave me his coat, what can I say?!  Have the tacos al pastor or carne asada. Quesadillas are tasty as well, but not mind blowing.
author: Nicole F.

description: This place is ok. The super burrito's were small, but it was tasty. But for a place in the mission, there is alot of places alot better. They have a good selection of condiments. I saw alot of people taking excessive amounts of condiments and leaving. I like how they have people playing music in the back while you eat, but I don't appreciate how they come to your table and stick their "donation" bag in your face and ask you for donations.
author: Dao C.

description:
can i have a super burrito with chile verde pork, whole pinto beans and hot salsa?  

you have to check out the salsa bar to get extra helpings,especially the roasted chipotle.
author: rosemarie l.

description:
This is the best taqueria I have ever had. seriously.  They have these refried black beans that are just amazing, and this tofu ranchero that I love, as well as an extensive salsa bar.   It's pretty busy and crowded but absolutely worth it, and the wait is never very long because these people can somehow make the best burrito of your life in about 30 seconds. 
they also always have a person who opens the door for you to make you feel like a real lady and they refuse to let you put away your dishes 
SOMETIMES, they have these great mariachi bands that put on free dinner shows and steal your heart away.  The staff is really nice and there's really just not much to complain about. OH GOD except the bathrooms.  I swear that someone goes in there and purposely just makes them as disgusting as they can possible be with shit constantly clogged in the toilet and mounds of tissues everywhere and a faucet that never stops dripping.
author: Naomi M.

description: When it comes to Mexican food, it all pretty much tastes the same to me.  Personally I prefer the many different flavors Caribbean food brings to the table.  However, I have grown to love Pancho Villa.  They offer a great variety of fish, poultry, meats, rice and beans to build an endless option of tacos, burritos, quesadillas and other fun dishes.  My favorite (kids don't try this at home) is the all meat burrito.  I typically get the steak all meat burrito with their medium salsa, and cheese.  I call it the Mexican cheese steak.  I've tried the one in the embarcadero but it seems to be missing some of the finer attention to details in the food preparation so I forgo the short walk for a slightly longer car drive and make this a highly frequented spot.
author: Javier O.

description: This is the greatest taqueria ever. Get a burrito, slather it with one or two of their kick-ass salsas, and top it with some lime juice, done.
author: Allison B.

description: I love Pancho Villa.  I am a burrito fan and I really love their burritos.  When mocked by my friends for never trying anything new, I had their tacos...delicious (but I went back to the burrito the next time I was there).  I'm sure there are other gems in the Mission, but I have not been able to move on from Pancho Villa.  Try a burrito or the prawn tacos...well, I bet everything is delicious!
author: Lauren H.

description:
the portions are huge, for sure. i think this place is landmark of the Mission but not the best in town. cheap food with a great selection of so-so salsa [i seriously, don't know how they got all those awards]. great vegan-vegetarian options, though. 

don't get me wrong. i'm down for a taco anytime at Pancho Villa - esp, over the heartattack city El Farolito. 

warning: don't get their guacamole for dip unless you like  super salty food.
author: Jocelyn T.

description: Amazing food! Their combination plate of shrimp, chicken, carne asada, refried beans w/ rice, and salad is delicious! I would definitely try out the combo plates as much as you can! Overall great. The only thing is I wish they provided more chips. Also, it gets a little too crowded and parking is difficult. Though, it is definitely worth the effort!
author: Charmaine G.

description: I come here a couple of times a month. It's not in a nice neighborhood of San Francisco, so I recommend not carrying a purse when you go here. It gets busy fast and is filled with locals. Great salsa bar and fresh drinks (ex. lime, horchata, etc). I highly recommend the carnitas street tacos.
author: Francine S.

description: If you're hungry this place is good, but otherwise it's just really not all that. The put all this stuff on your taco and when you don't want cheese they look at you like you're crazy. I don't eat cheese due to sinus issues. Anyway, it's pretty fresh and clean for the most part and their burritos are big. But I think Can-Cun is better.
author: Gina R.

description: This is La cumbres big competitor around the corner here. I must say they have pretty epic burritos with a really good spiced carne asada. I am very picky when it comes to mexican food and have trouble deciding whether it's going to be la cumbre around the corner or this place. You try and both and make the decision. The line here always seems to be much longer.
author: Bowser J.

description: This is a great place to stop by for lunch during the week. They have a lot of choices on the menu, they are fast, they give you large portions, and it is cheap! They also have a salsa bar! What more can you ask for?
author: Carly W.

description: No shame in their game.  Sounded like a Mexican joint for tourists -- but it's the real deal.  Obviously the best post nightclub late nite stop in the Mission
author: E C.

description: Best taqueria in town.  Their garlic mushroom quesadilla -- to die for.  Everytime I have guests in town, I always take them here, and they're never disappointed.  So cheap, so good.  The portions are so big that they end up being 2-3 meals for me.  Really busy though -- but well warranted!  Sometimes so busy that I just go across the street (which is good too!), but I always feel a twinge of regret cuz pancho villas the best.  YUM.
author: Latef X.

description: I always get the veggie burrito and it's always good.  My friend gets the mushroom quesadilla and I always steal bites.  Yummytron.  They're open until midnight which is both a good & a bad thing (I do NOT need to eat a burrito anytime near midnight).  The line can appear long but it moves very quickly, don't let it scare you away.
author: Emily T.

description: Yummy, inexpensive, conveniently located near BART - a great place for burritos and the line moves quickly.
author: Sydney L.

description: I could eat mexican morning noon or night. I say that to give you perspective.  Love this place. Fresh, good portions. Great place to get a beer and burrito. But not a date.
author: Jon C.

description: Yummy!! This place is great. It's always clean and even when the line is wrapping around the place, it moves quickly with it's huge staff. The black refried beans are the best.
author: Nicole S.

description: Hands-down, some of the best Mexican food in the city.  Yum!  Great place to take someone experiencing the Mission for the first time.
author: Joanna S.

description: Doesn't get anymore authentic than this. The best carne asada burrito I've ever had!
author: Ari T.

description: For a vegitarian, this place is H-E-A-V-E-N.  By far, the best burrito that I've had in the neighborhood!
author: Hannah N.

description: Fast service, good salsa bar, and delicious burritos. A good mission standard.
author: Michael A.

description: OMG - I have died and gone to heaven in the Mission with this taco joint. When I walk into this place, I have to take a few steps back and admire the menu. As if I am going to order anything else besides tacos and corona, but I make an effort. Amazing selection, fresh food and cheap!! My favorite spot for a first date seriously.
author: Palak P.

description: I don't really eat burritos so I am a bad judge, but i do love tacos.  the tacos here just don't cut it, the carne asada has little to no flavor.  I have gone back time and time again and always brought people here from out of town as the line and popularity made me think it was just me, but everybody i brought thought it was just alright.  Except for vegetarians - most vegetarians i know do truly love the burritos here.
author: Greg M.

description: Great taqueria in the Mission.  Great ambiance (though I can't say that I appreciate the security guard at the door...though he did open the door for me which was nice).  Check out the prawn burrito, very tasty!  The only thing i wish was that it was a little cheaper.  Ten dollars for a tasty burrito seems a bit much.  Don't forget to check out the art work on the big wall usually good and sometimes great.
author: Steven C.

description: I would actually give it 3.5 stars. It's very clean and the food is tasty...but for some reason there seems to be something missing....the food here tastes too....clean or something. Maybe you need all that grease to make the food taste authentic! In any case I love how you can get "baby burritos" (smaller size) which is perfect for gals. I also like the prawns, something most other places don't have. The salsa bar is an added plus.
author: lani P.

description:
Good. Consistent. Easy.

Anything else. ehhhh? Strangely overpriced for the Mission; burrito the way you want it costs over $7 and frankly isn't great. It's good, not great.

For better tasting Mexican and cheaper Mexican and later hours of operation Mexican, take yourself over to 19th and Mission at Cacun, where the real party is.
author: Matt T.

description: I like Poncho Villa better than El Toro. They have really good tortas here too, as well as the standard burritos and agua frescas. Get the Lengua when they have it. Hard to park, but then this is the Mission. Get a Mini-Cooper or a can opener.
author: Arlene C.

description: This is my second favorite burrito joint in the Bay Area.   They make very tasty Al Pastor and the chipotle prawns are surprisingly good.  Really shady location though, made the mistake of double parking and sending my wife in to grab the food, she'll never do that again.  Even some of the clientele is a little shady, but the food is good.
author: Raj M.

description: If you order a burrito spicy prepare to sweat. With clean ingredients (no lard/msg) and both authentic and yuppie items this place can't really be beat. Plus the prices are reasonable...if you are going to visit only one Mexican restaurant in SF Pancho Villas would not be a bad choice.
author: Cameron K.

description: Aqua Frescas!!  Sandia (watermelon) is the best!!
author: K W.

description: Love PANCHO VILLAS! try there cabo fajitas they are so yummy! service is always great! Love it!
author: stephanie p.

description: Another Pancho Villa off my list. I though overpriced burritos were limited only to the Peninsula, but I guess not. This place is expensive compared to its Mission peers, but it doesn't have that seedy grungy feel that the others have (there's only so much charm seeing a guy with puke on his jacket and drunkenly nourishing a burrito in a place that smells like bleach). In the Mission, I doubt I'd come back to this place when there are so many better options, but it was entertaining to see the lay ahead of me pay for her substantial order in dollar bills and nickels... haha, good ol' SF.
author: Rocky K.

description: My first burrito in SF was at Pancho Villa. I was optimistic, but overall I thought it was just so-so. The menu gives plenty of offerings for what you can get in a burrito, especially when it comes to the meat choices. I had the carne asada. It was good, but nowhere near spectacular. They also offer some healthier choices like whole wheat tortillas and tofu. It's a nice touch that they have these choices, but it kind of takes away from the authenticity of the place. One of the best qualities about burrito places is that the service is usually fast. Sadly, the service here was really, really slow. I don't know what the hold-up was. The set up should have been efficient, but I think the poor guy at the register was taking on too many responsibilities. Basically, you're standing in line with your made burrito and nowhere else to go because the service at the register is so slow.
author: Kristen R.

description:
My love hate relationship with Pancho Villa...

You are soooo close to my home... right off the Bart stop as well!  What could be better or more convenient?  Oh yes, your very affordable prices!  I crave the Super Vegetarian all day and almost every day.
And with the good comes the bad...
The line system and getting your food isn't very effective sometimes, my burrito/ order has been mixed up with other people's on occasion at time of checkout.  I understand why you don't just hand us the package of deliciousness when it is done being prepared, but c'mon... 
The staff is sometimes very nice and sometimes very not nice.  I understand it gets hectic in there, but if there was better paying attention of what people wanted exactly then maybe there would be less headaches?  I always dread picking up food for my roommates because on many occasions I do not get the specifications that I asked for (one of my roommates is very anti-lettuce and almost every time they still insist on putting lettuce on his nachos.  Oh, I warned you Pancho Villa - pretty soon he will freak out and I don't want to witness the wrath).
I will still crave you and eat you often, the service could use a little buffering, though...
author: Kristina K.

description: Very good super baby burrito with spicy chicken and refried black beans.  A little messy but tasty!  I will be back Pancho Villa!
author: Rise G.

description: the best place to get a burrito in the city and probably in northern CA. Where else can you get an authentic, fresh, FAST and fairly priced burrito as good as here?!?!  I always make my way here when craving un burrito!  Pollo asada with black beans, spicy salsa and a coke!  Te Quiero!!!
author: TC C.

description: Yumm!  I'll be honest when I lived upstairs from Taqueria Cancun I felt like a cheat going to Pancho Villas--- but now I'm able to say its the best damn carnitas and salsa fresca I've had.  I was born in New Mexico so God will strike me dead if I write that it's the best Mexican food. But it's some of the best in SF.
author: Ona E.

description:
awesome burrito but can get expensive. full salsa bar and very friendly atomsphere. 

after they have installed the fancy computer system, it takes much longer to get your food.
author: Emily Y.

description: I wanted a mission burrito and decided on this place to try it. I ordered a super burrito with steak. The place was quite crowded though it was around 1pm. The number of menu choices is astounding. The wait for our food wasn't too bad. They even brought the food to our table which I found surprising. The restaurant itself was clean and there was a security guard there to keep order too. The burrito was big and very tasty. It wasn't overly stuffed and bursting at the seams. It wasn't light on ingredients. It was perfect, and it tasted perfect. This is one of the things I miss most upon leaving San Francisco.
author: Kevin K.

description: this place is great however,it can get really busy, thier burritos are great
author: Seaera T.

description: pancho villa used to have my heart but ever since an ill fated day where my carnitas were sadly dry, i've discovered el farolito. it's cheaper, better and the fact that they charge 50 cents for chips is A-OK with me because they're the BEST GOD DAMN CHIPS!!!!! sorry pancho villa, you've been one upped but i'll always remember the good times we had.
author: Alyssa L.

description: Went there yesterday, I got a super vegitarian burrito. The food was amazing!!! better than another place my boyfriend brought me a couple weeks ago and that place tasted like shit (it was el tapa? on 18th and folsom) and this place was wayy better. they make everything right in front of you and the burritos are huge! amazing place if you wanna try a good burrito. Id deffinitaly go here again!
author: Nicole F.

description:
i hear they have good taco's.  never had 'em here.  only had the burritos and quesadillas. both of them have been WAY below par.  the only things this place have going for them is their salsa par, which is definitely above par and it's location.  the line assembly is not good and neither is the quality of food.  i don't get why ppl like this spot, i just don't get it unless ppl only care about location.

below is an email i sent to a friend during my recent visit (nay disappointment) here
"Besides cold veggies and cheese and sour cream in the burrito, it's also an at&t dead spot in the back"

i always come back here because i'll be on 16th and craving a burrito.  I am always let down.  I need to just walk the extra few feet and hit the El Castillito on mission around the corner.
author: Andrew r.

description: I don't know anyone who doesn't like Pancho Villa because they have the best burritos!  I am a big fan of the wet burritos, especially with prawns.  The chorizo is also really good here and has heat to it, which most places don't.  The tamales are pretty good, and they have fresh chips, salsa bar and drinks.
author: Violet S.

description: Each of the last several times I've flown out of the state (or country, for that matter) I've gone straight to Pancho Villa after landing back home at SFO. No matter how jetlagged, smelly, cranky I am or how much luggage I might or might not have: Pancho Villa first, home/hygeine/sleep second. This is of my two favorite places to get a burrito in SF - not only because of how goddamned good they are on such a ridiculously consistent basis, but also because of the fantastic salsa bar and the friendly & fast staff and the likelihood of this place reminding me why I never want to permanently move out of the Bay Area.
author: M M.

description: Really good food if you're in the area for lunch.  Sort of cafeteria-style as you can order tacos with a wide range of fresh meat.  I've had the quesadillas and burritos and they're also pretty good.  Tables are usually hard to come by when it's packed.  Good cheap lunch when you're hungry.
author: Keith M.

description: Nowadays few Mexicans dine at Pancho Blando.  I used to love this joint.  Now it's filled with yuppies and delivers fairly uneventful faire to office buildings downtown via waiter.com.  What happened guys????
author: matthew w.

description: The super veggie burrito here is awesome, as is the prawns dinner.  I love all of their salsas.  Nice and spicy!
author: Ann F.

description: Great burritos. I will brave the crack whores and drug addicts for this burrito any day!
author: michelle k.

description: Great Carnita Burrito!  Everything here looked good, I had to restrain myself from ordering everything on the menu.  Next time I'm getting the Chile Relleno!  The atmosphere is, from what I can tell, a very authentic taqueria.  In the financial district, its less authentic but there is outdoor seating, which is very nice when you have been stuck in an office all day.  The price was reasonable, we didn't spend too much money but we were thoroughly stuffed!
author: Brent G.

description:
this is MY favorite place to eat a burrito, and to all you haters out there, its okay to have your own favorite. i swear, in this city, hate or be hated on when it comes to your favorite burrito. 
this place has all the options in the world, i luurrve a refried black bean. and they make my favorite thing ever, a super baby burrito. now how can it be super and baby? well really baby just takes the whole burrito down a notch so you can actually finish the damn thing. booyah!
and yes, i am aware that it is more expensive than other places. that is why we lose a star. but come on, super baby with refried black? pretty much all i ever asked for. 

see other reviews for taco lovin.
author: shaine h.

description: There are better burritos in the city.  That being said, a super carne asada burrito from Pancho Villa is damn tasty,  the salsa bar has a solid assortment of condiments, and they are open late!  Probably in my top 5 or 6 slabs in the city overall, and definitely a place worth taking out of towners who want a true mission style burrito.
author: Korey A.

description:
So a few days ago, like 10... I was down in The Mission, I think thrift store shopping. Anyways, I got hungry and wanted to eat. Mexican food. And only Mexican food. So I started down Valencia and ended up on 16th. I went by I don't know, 3 or 4 places before ending up at Pancho Villa Taqueria (Rhyming makes it that much better). I remember stumbling past this place at 1am the last time I left Delirium. So I got about half way by it and looked in... Jesus Christ there were a lot of people!

The store front's not that big, but you look in at 12pm and there's about 934 people eating there. No shit. So I figure what the hell, it must be ok. I'm greeted at the door by a security guard who opens the door for me?? Where the hell did I end up? The Ritz Taqueria? There's actually about a 5 minute wait to order... This place is tripping me out. Feel like Johnny Depp in Fear and Loathing. And strangely, there's actually some cool paintings on the wall for sale. Slightly over priced but nice non-the-less.

I will say that the service SUCKED with a capital SUCKED. But it's a Mexican restaurant, I expected nothing less. So no minus points there. The lady that took my order and made my veggie burrito was not what I would call, umm nice. Well, more like unfriendly would be a better description of her attitude. But again, it's Mexican food. After another 5 minute wait to get rung up, I made my way to the salsa bar. What a selection. And by the 10 plus awards on the wall, I gather that   it must be good. I settled on something that has jalapenos (I like to sweat when I eat) and made my way to my seat. The food overall was really good, there were a good amount of people inside which is generally a good thing, and the busser that came around to take my plate called me "sir". Works for me. I'll be back.
author: Adam S.

description: So many options, everyone will get a burrito they love.  Beer is a great price too.  Awesome place to go before you hit up the mission for the night.
author: Joel M.

description: Cheap, delicious, free entertainment.  Uncomfortable seating, but hey, what do you want for a cheap taco?
author: Joy W.

description: First of all, the line you wait in is tantalizing. Grilled meat or prawns or both!? The chips are up to par, as is the salsa bar. The cooks look like they are having an ok time. So sit back and enjoy the view of the security guard kicking out the overzealous crack head and eat your food, dude.
author: mickey l.

description: After eating at Pancho's (on Geary) too many disappointing times, I finally decided to head to the Mission for a real burrito.  I ordered the shrimp burrito combo. med/hot salsa and it was delicious!  A few hot spicy bites and the rest with "just right" medium salsa.   I asked for "no cheese and add sour cream and guacamole" to the burrito and they made it just as I ordered.  From now on whenever I'm in the mood for an authentic burrito, I'm jumping in my car and heading back to Pancho Villa Taqueria.
author: Pisces B.

description: One of the best burritos in town - and I know a good burrito. I've heard it said before, San Franciscans won't wait in line for something unless it's REALLY worth it - so I suppose the regular line speaks for itself. Great atmosphere too - there was a mariachi singer with guitar in hand serenading the line while we waited and salivated. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Kevin K.

description: By far, the best vegetarian friendly Mexican place I've been to in SF. They are always staffed well so waiting is never a problem. The salsas are to die for too.
author: D M.

description: I just went to Pancho Villa for the 1st time and loved it. I had the prawn tacos and a side of grilled vegetables. My friends ordered the carne asada tacos and the baby burrito. Everything was great. I definitely recommend checking this place out!
author: Abby P.

description:
the strawberry agua fresca is the bomb. ugh, i can't even stand how lush it is.

burrito-wise, it's a good price for a large portion. they also have a great extensive vegan/veggie option for our friends who wish to remain meatless, and those who choose it will be greatly rewarded with meat stuffed in the entree of your choosing. the line can look daunting from the outside, but it moves rapidly and you can land a seat usually after paying for your grub. plus, it's in the middle of the mish so it's sure to be a place to stop by if you need to grab a bite to eat on the way out.

i wasn't aware of the battle between them and farrolito?? awesome. they should have a burrito-off.

also, anywhere that beck chooses to stand and play for the crowd is a-okay by me.
author: Jenz y.

description: So disappointed!  Every time I've walked by this place there's a line, so naturally I think, hey it must be good and since it's a taqueria it must have authentic mexican food at authentic (cheap) prices. Wrongo!  I'm not sure what the draw is.  Maybe the salsa bar, which is pretty decent, or the variety of mexican sodas, which is a lot.  But I had 2 el pastor tacos for $2.25 each (or something like that), which is incredulous in itself, but they weren't even that great, which completely chapped my hide.  Perhaps I've been spoiled by southern California living and receiving unbelievably good, authentic food at amazingly cheap prices.
author: tamera t.

description: 414 reviews? W O W. i guess there's not much i can say that's not already been said, but sources say this is the best mexican in the city. also, did you know that Pancho Villa is listed in the Slow Food San Francisco guide? this means they make everything from scratch and is (somewhat?) sustainable - not chain junk food!  anyhow, i really like pancho villa. i love the garlic prawn dinner and the vegetable tacos. i'm always grossed out when i see them chopping up all that raw chicken and beef and grilling it up right in front of you while you're in line, but boy, that chicken is good. bf always gets horchata which is incredibly tasty, or aqua fresca (strawberry yum!). i've seen some shady shit go down back near the bathrooms; maybe that's why they have a security guard at the door? anyhow, they do quick take out for the faint of heart.
author: Mary V.

description: Still my favorite taqueria in the Mission, although my boyfriend recently tried to convert me to Can Cun. What kept me more into Pancho Villa is the fact that you can choose your own beans and salsa, which is important to me because I have a very low tolerance for spiciness. It is a little pricier, but totally worth it. They have a good beer selection too, compared to other places nearby.
author: Jordan S.

description:
pancho villa is not a place you crave, it is a place you settle for. 

the only reason i ever go here is peer pressure or because they take cards and i can't leave work for more than ten minutes at a time. 

pancho villa never makes me feel satisfied or content. and also, why are you people standing in those long ass lines when you could walk a block down valencia and be the first in line at el toro for the same dang burrito!

sheesh!
author: Tara A.

description:
i wouldn't say that Pancho Villa is "great" by any means, but i do crave it from time to time. the few things that keep me away are: 

1) i prefer to eat at places that have people that can understand what i asked for.  reading my order right off the board shouldn't be hard for someone who works there to understand.

2) sitting on basically leather bound milk crates isn't fun. i have a tiny ass and even i have a hard time sitting on them.

3) i like clean silverware
author: Gary V.

description:
Yummy burritos!

Loved my chicken burritos, and the extensive salsa bar in the back. is divine! The prices are very reasonable also!!
author: Michele Y.

description: This place is BOMB...I don't even like burritos but I LOVE them from here!  The burritos are pretty ginormous...but you can always take it home and eat it the rest later!  At least you will never leave hungry!!! Its always crowded, probably because its so good!  It has a really positive environment and sometimes there is even a mariachi band there!!!  Which I LOVED!  Go here for SURE!!
author: Shea M.

description: I brought some New Yorkers here for a "mission-style burrito" and both were totes satisfied.  In fact, the girl New Yorker was over-satisfied and didn't feel that great 30 minutes later.  SUCCESS!
author: Marcus C.

description: Just came here the other day because my teacher kept raving about this place a few months ago . When I first walked in , there was a long line but no worries .. you will get your order quicker than you think . I got a super burrito which was okay but kind of on the bland side . I'm sure I've had better . They have a lot of different flavors of Jarritos to choose from which is awesome because some burrito places don't even carry that . Basically if you're looking for a cheap filling meal , this is the place to go . Order a burrito or whatever and wash it down with a Jarrito .. nothing can top that . Btw , it's kind of nice how the security guard is a doorman as well . He opens the door for you when you walk in and out . I'm giving this Pancho Villa an extra star just for that hehe .
author: Eileen L.

description: Not great, not bad.  Gets a lot of attention being right off the bart and close to the bars.  Getting a burrito here kind of feels like getting a manual carwash - there are like 20 people over there making it happen in 5 minutes or less.
author: Kurosh H.

description: I recently visit  Pancho villa  and not only was i sad i was pissed.Back in the 80's and 90's the food was to die for and now if you eat there your throwing away your money.It is evident that people feel the same way as I do,they just might not know about yelp.The foot traffic has dwindled,.Long lines out the door and down the street are a thing of the past.You want to know what happened,I see it all too often, the business becomes a money machine instead of a passion.11 Years ago I visited a friend in the south and she had a Bon Appetit magazine that  did a story and review on Pancho villa.I was happy to see that the owner had gotten recognition and had made it in the culinary wold.I returned back home and in a matter of weeks noticed that Pancho villa's prices had gone up.I then moved to another state that didn't have good Mexican only to return and find out the painful truth about  Pancho villa,it has become about quantity instead of quality.I had to give at least a one star rating in order to write a review,in my opinion  Pancho villa deserves no stars.It is a crying shame that a business that has been around for so long is one big disappointment.The owner  has his priorities all mixed up and needs  reevaluation of his business as well as paying attention to detail because,he is now putting down the real Pancho villa and misrepresenting the memory of  a legend.
author: Dolores O.

description: If you want a burrito with everything (meat, rice, beans, salsa, cheese, guac, and sour cream) be prepared to pay $8 each.  As I was looking at the menu (the combination of choices is endless) a friendly, but hurried lady gave me this upward nod of the head to let me know it was my turn to order.  I said I want a......steak, no carnitas......super burritio....no regular...(I am a newbie) so pretty much, I didn't know what I wanted.  She smiled and nodded again and said "you can get 3 burritos for $16.15"  I said "okay make two steak and one carnitas."  I was still gazing at the menu in amazement and I noticed her flagging me down "what kinda beans?"  At this point, I have found my niche on this conveyor belt burrito operation "whole on the carnitas and refried on the other two" and on we went like that until she had fixed them.  I slid on down and paid and she gave me a "you're a first-timer" smile.  AND THEN I SAW THE SALSA BAR!!  Good lord every salsa know to man on the face of the earth, plus roasted peppers, limes, onions, radishes and cilantro.  I had been here about 5 years ago, and I remembers how good the charbroiled steak was in the burrito.  I decided to go back and it was a good choice.  Whenever I go to the city, I'm definitely going to hit this place up.
author: K G.

description: Why do I always come back here? I am disappointed every time. One of the only places in the area taking credit cards and stocking diet Dr. Pepper, so once in awhile I try again. Maybe someday I'll learn.
author: Amber R.

description: I am by no means a Mission burrito expert, but the fish burrito here was so good that it made me cry. I even bought a freaking T-shirt. If it gets better than this, I'm afraid to try it.
author: Ian R.

description: Fast food but, healthy and fresh.  These guys (actually gals) really know how to make a burrito.
author: Sue L.

description: After going to Panco Villa for serveral years its obvious the prices have gone up and the qualityh down.  To begin, this past weekend me and my party ordered the #9 special which is a grilled salmon, shrimp, and carne asada combination plate and two regular tacos.   The number 9 special was a combination of burned,  dry and tastless shrimp, salmon and carne asada,  for $15.00 The carne asada and salmon were clearly not eatible.  They were so dry,that swalloing could be hazard.  Its obvious,  Its obviuous the owners of this place do not care of the quality of food presented.  The location has alot of foot traffic, but the area can be sketchy at times.  Just a heads up
author: Robert S.

description: Very good food, but not necessarily THE BEST. I am also surprised that you pay $20 for a veggie burrito and a shrimp burrito. Aren't they supposed to be a cheap and quick way to get filled up?  At least one out of two isnt't bad.  I particularly like the quesadilla.
author: Abraham Y.

description: We had friends from out of town and they had already been to Pancho Villa once before earlier that weekday and they wanted to eat there again. This was my first time eating at Pancho. I had a fish taco which was actually really good for my taste bud. 2 days later I went back there and ordered a dinner plate that had snapper, rice, beans and a salad. I also ordered there watermelon juice which was really good. I would go back here again.
author: Ge I.

description: Pancho's is insanely delicious, has fast service and have baller status guacamole.  I get the burrito everytime and the enchilada's are the jam.  I'm a little disappointed they don't have any breakfast burrito options (gotta go to the glorious papalote for that).
author: Jack H.

description: allway good , croud very ecletic , good food
author: matt p.

description: Pancho Villa in the Mission and their sister place in San Mateo both equally rock!!! El Toro also kicks ass..owned by the above as well I believe. Nothing beats the spicy chicken burrito and their salsa bar... I lived abroad for a while and out of state as well and I had dreams of this place and HUGE cravings!
author: Eric R.

description: LOTS of vegetarian options if you are scared of the meat.  I had the eh-Super Veggie and it was excellent.  I like a burrito with the fillings well distributed throughout the tortilla cylinder and Poncho hit the mark here.  Isn't it annoying when you bite into ALL rice or ALL sour cream?  There are some burrito joints out there that still haven't figured that out.  Pancho would get 5 beans out of 5 if the neighborhood wasn't so sketchy.  Burritos inside, smack dealers outside.
author: Doug A.

description: the first dinner I and my friend Gliceria wen to was at Pancho Villa... A lot of people were still there around 9:00pm, we waited to sit for 10 minutes, which wasn't that bad.. I had mexican chorizo meal (with pinto beans, and tacos, rice) It was good! But we didn't ate everything.. I can't imagine how big the plate was! it was kind of expensive though, compared to other taquerias... I liked the decent place....
author: nice m.

description: Pancho is a Cali-Mex Style walkup counter top Taqueria but with a lot more to offer than your "typical" Mexican Food. Beyond the Burritos and Tacos you will find so much more for example; Los Camarones a LA Plancha are unbelivable, and the award winning salsa selection is probably the best in the city. If you go on a Friday night you will find the Trio of Musicians playing all the Mexican songs you love right there by your table. Overall I would rank Pancho Villa as one of the best Taquerias in The Mission.......Arriba Mexico!
author: JC C.

description: I wanna hate this place so much because it's so over run all day long. I just can't, though. Their quesadillas are still the best artery clogging injection of curd in the city and the spices in their hot salsa is simply awesome. Plus they were one of the first places to throw your burrito on a spinach or tomato tortilla without jacking up the price.
author: Andrew L.

description: Well done but pricey. The salsa bar is nice. Get the roast pork super burrito.
author: Mer S.

description: Good fresh fast food.  Wide menu selection.  Several salsa choices.  Try the over the top steak and prawn burrito.
author: oliver w.

description: I agree with Max B. Strangely overpriced for the Mission, and just good, not great. The chicken nachos downright suck. Taqueria Cancun is cool, but you'll be dodging gang members if it's after dark...If you're in the area, cut kitty corner across the street to Coyote Taqueria and get the same burrito for a few bucks less. Also, their tortas are better.
author: Lolo G.

description:
Kickass Taqueria. I came in out of desperation during a hunger attack between bar and Bart on a Saturday night. When I saw all the options for burritos I was drooling.
