C'mon refried black beans! the prawns smelled great and there's mountains of meat getting grilled and chopped. Theres just so much going on it's hypnotizing,  like a Mexican Benihana's. 
The food's good, fresh, fresh salsas, good chips, Negra Modelo.
author: John W.

description: I love this place!!!  The food is sooooo good.  My favorites are the prawn tacos (make them "super"), tamales, guacamole, churros, and limon drink.  Mmmmmm, Yummy!
author: L C.

description: I love this place.  YOU SHOULD EAT HERE.  The lime drink is addictive.  All the meat is good.  Veggie options.  They'll make custom stuff.  One of the salas is incredibly addictive (the tangy red one).  The white cookies in the case are bomb.  Of course the burritos are good (green shell, please).  Its gooood!
author: chadmalik ..

description: 3 and 1/2 stars....I've had better and I've had worse.  It is a good location, the line moves swiftly and there is plenty of indoor seating.  The food is fresh but nothing really distinguishes it from other restaurants.
author: regina k.

description:
it's all hype.
actually stay there, don't go to El farolito, if you're happy enough with Pancho Villa, then you probably don't deserve to eat there
author: Kevin S.

description: Always fresh. Pretty good salsa bar. I ask for xtra guac so I expect my burrito to be cold(my cheese is always melted though). The staff is always friendly with me which I don't expect from taqueria employees. I kinda dig it! The meats are ALMOST amazing but not quite. That is cool though when you have consistency. I really wanted to write a positive review because recently I've sort of torn everybody a new one. I picked Pancho Villa which is amusing because it will certainly get lost in a sea of 4-5 star reviews. For people that complain about burritos in good places like this, I still hold a theory that they most likley annoyed the staff in some way resulting in a shitty, loveless food log. No?
author: Boxxxman J.

description: Great burritos; rolled extra tight. The real draw is their selection of salsas.
author: Scott F.

description: I had heard through a few people that this was the "it" taqueria in San Francisco. I must have ordered the wrong thing because I was not at all impressed with the food. I got the spicy chicken burrito, which was very spicy, almost to the point where you cant savor the taste of the other ingredients of the burrito. The service was good, and the price was fair although I must say. I have had worse, but then again i've definitely had better.
author: rich s.

description: Terrific fast mexican food. Terrific salsa bar. My favorite here is the pollo chile verde tostada, but the burritos are yummy too! I only wish we had taquerias like this where in live in Hawaii.
author: Marc K.

description: my most fav burrito spot in the city. tho slightly expensive for a burrito, mos def well worth it.
author: Randall P.

description: Love love love the food here!   It's the best mexican.  It's worth traveling across town just to eat here.  HUGE portions.   YUM YUM YUM
author: Nat S.

description: LOVE the vege burrito but it is all good. Hate to say I have never had the tacos. Always fresh and good. Love this place.
author: julie q.

description: Second time here. The first time (last summer) was great. Perhaps I expected more this time but it was not that great. The steak in the burrito was full of gristle.
author: Malcolm D.

description:
I have been going to Pancho Villa since they opened.  That space used to be a Chinese restaurant named Luckys. I remember going there to get their veggie burritos because they were cheap and big.  My friend and I use to split one, eat it with lots of chip and salsa..what a meal!!  Well they do have commercials now, so we are paying for that.
I still love them, even if they are the most expensive in the Mission.  Love love love their salsa bar...I give it a 5 star.  From the mildest (for all u wimps) and super hot for me.  
I wish the staff was friendlier.  Since I've been coming here, I have never felt welcomed, except for the one of the owners...when he use to work the counter.
I think the dinners are the best.  I am going to spend almost $10. on a burrito, then I am going to get a prawn dinner.  The best!  The drinks are good to...especially strawberry.
When Pancho Villa came into the scene back-in-the-day, there were some great places that didn't last like, Chapalita Delicatessen, they had the best Crab burritos.  If anyone remembers them or the old 16th street, please e-mail me..
author: rebecca h.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE! I probably ate at all of the taquerias and this thus so far has the best quality meats. The burritos are a killer and i really like all the different salsas which they have won awards for.
author: Jay M.

description: What can i say this place is great.... not necessarily for the burritos mind you (they are good but you can find better)  but for tacos you cant go wrong and the quesadillas are also really good. What is the secret you might ask?  Its all about the meats, the grilled chicken and beef are perfect and they really lay a char down on them so there is that extra depth of flavor. The salsa bar has a great selection and the chips are never stale. Open late and  add the real cane sugar cokes and your looking at one of the best spots in the mission.
author: Ben S.

description: hands down the best mexican food i've tried in the bay area (thus far).  as a socal native there is a serious lack of proper mexican food up here but i think poncho villa comes pretty close.  the grilled meats are enough to attract crowds like 10 blocks away and the salsa bar is insane!  super friendly staff and really really good food.  sometimes they have live mariachi music goin on inside which adds to the whole ambiance of the place.
author: Tara H.

description: Simply the best mexican I ever tried, and trust me, I've tried quite a few.
author: Wisam D.

description: Really, their salsa bar is the main reason I come here. The burritos are great, large and tasty, but I don't think I would frequent here if I didn't love the salsa so much. I get at least six salsa cups with my burrito, so I have some for every bite. Love how much it makes my mouth burn and my eyes water.
author: Robin S.

description: A favorite for sure.. Try the Carnitas for a meat eater alternative to the Carne  Asada.
author: don l.

description: Good, solid burrito. Probably top ten in SF, but I wouldn't go quite so far as to give it top 5 status. REALLY good meat-less burritos though... if you're into that kinda thing... which I am... sometimes.
author: Matt W.

description: Awww man!  This USED to be the best place in the Mission for a great burrito at a fair price.  But we walked in last night, took one look at the huge price increases and walked right back out.  It's good, but not $8 for a regular burrito good.  Raising prices is understandable...but to go so extreme is really going to turn people off I'm afraid.
author: Erin H.

description: Quick and friendly service considering how busy they get, with a 15 deep queue! They've got a system down to take your order and ring you up in no time. Finding a seat may require you to make new friends and share a table. I would consider this a hole-in-the-wall joint that offers delicious comfort food for a cheap price. I had the deluxe chicken burrito, twice -- which never failed to stuff me halfway through. Their salsa bar is packed with a variety of flavorful, mild to hot and spicy salsas that make a great sauce to your entree. Make sure you ask for a side of chips (free) to top off your scrumptious meal!
author: L C.

description:
A moratorium, please, on burritos as the bellwether of taqueria quality.  The stupidity inherent in that calculus should be obvious.  The Mission is slowly being ruined by bad taste.  Can't we just set a limit on the number of taco bells allowed?

Burritos are stupid.  You know what the best burrito is?  A taco.  Why spoil delicious meat, lard-fried tortillas, and great salsa with beans and rice?  Please, hipsters, stop ruining Mexican food with your demands for big burritos.  Rice and beans, especially at a taqueria, are virtually guaranteed to be less than stellar.  If you wanted a good beer but also felt like you wanted to fill up your stomach, would you ask for a giant glass of equal parts beer and water?  NO.  You wouldn't.

Walked in here with high expectations as it came recommended from people I respect.  Ordered three tacos al pastor (the proper way to gauge a taqueria's quality), which cost $3 each or $8 for three.  The meat was old and had been reheated so long it had become stewed.  There was a choice (Yay!  A choice!) of beans.  I had to ask for no rice.  

Oye! Pancho VIlla:  Tacos do not have beans (or rice FFS!) in them!  Tacos also should never cost $3.  Al pastor meat is BARBECUED not stewed.  Tacos should have grilled, or at least warmed, tortillas.  And Tacos should NEVER be served on a flour tortilla.  

Call this place what it is:  Tex/San Diego-Mex.   Yuck.
author: Nick V.

description: I have been going to this place for, literally, almost 25 years (no kidding).  In all honesty it is the BEST taqueria in San Francisco, bar none!  Can't say enough about it and have turned quite a few people into Pancho Villa regulars.  I even have requests to have burritos sent overseas by my cousins and aunts when relatives travel to visit them ---- they are that good!  Just thinking about this place makes my mouth water...
author: D. E.

description: purrrrdy goooodd stuuuufff.
author: Jason G.

description: This is one of the best Mexican restaurants in the city. The food is great and the staff is efficient!!
author: Catherine S.

description: Hahahahah as the 669th review of pancho villa i feel like this is pointless but im still doing it! :) Being from Miami i just cant say im an expert of Mexican food though i do know a good bit about it since traveling around Mexico many times and enjoying some of the finest restaurants there as well as the hot local joints... Ok onto the Pancho Villa Review.  First things to note is the long line even though there are a million mexican places on the block and the fact that you order at the counter and the girl/guy you order from makes your personal item...My personal favorite is the Steak & Prawn Quessadilla Super (lettuce, tomatoes, guac, salsa) with half spicy and half regular salsa.. They skillet the prawns right there and then mix it in with the steak. :) Amazing!  If you look on their wall you can see the awards for their salsa over the years.. It is truly the bomb!  Their Guacamole on the other hand i found to be decent to weak.  The green sauce in the salsa bar is sooo good. I like to add all the cilantro and lime and mix it in. OK last note Im all for improving the environment by switching from Styrofoam to organic material for cups..  BUT DOWNSIZING AND INCREASING THE PRICE OF THE XXL MIXED AGUA FRESCA IS NOT COOL!
author: Jarett M.

description: not one of my favorite burrito places.  i found the burritos to be dry without the sauces from the salsa bar.  i do like how they have about 6 different types of salsa. each being gradually spicier than the other.   they have many awards on the wall to show that they're salsa is one of the best in the bay.
author: Cedric F.

description: My absolute favorite taqueria. The food is always good and even with a line its worth the wait.
author: Marika C.

description: I went there around 3pm on a Saturday for an afternoon snack.  The line was long but it provided the extra time needed to review the menu board.  I ended ordering the steak nachos.  The lady was very nice and provided the pico gallo salsa on the side.  The nachos came with beans, cheese, carne asada and the salsa.  The nachos were good but the proportion of steak and other ingredients were very low.     It was a little over $7.  On the way out, I  got a churro for a $1.50.  It was the skimpiest churro ever.  I was disappointed on the portion size and the poor ventilation.  Your clothes will reek burritos after wards.
author: Edmund W.

description:
I come here alone. On Sundays. 

Because eating Pancho Villa's carne asada is a truly worshipful experience. 

Thick quesadillas grilled to golden perfection, with fresh avocado slices and carne asada... it makes me want to beg for sweet, sweet mercy. 

Come as you are, leave your offering, and leave a believer.
author: kaili h.

description: ive traveled around eating at hundreds and hundreds of taquerias in my life...but NONE surpass the authenticity, freshness, and outstanding taste that pancho villa provides. This place is as  good as it gets and has set the bar with only few places coming close. La corneta in san francisco in my eyes is great but is just a close runner up. If you are looking for an amazing mission style burrito pancho villa is the place to go.
author: jonathan s.

description: My most recent visit to P.V. is probally my last.  I ordered a regular burrito, which you think at $7.50 would be good, think not.   Just looking at the variety of meats, should have been a clue not to dine there.   Anyhow, the grill chicken burrito, was the most tastless, dry meat I have tried.   I threw away half the burrito.   Its unfourtante, the meat items are prepared hours in advanced.  Just ask for a sample prior to purchasing.   This will be the opportunity to decide, if its worth your time or money.   All the meats sit on the hot oven, with boiling water, causing excess cooking.  As  the consumer, you are wasting your money., if this is the standard here.   I have to  be starved, for me to go bck to P.V.
author: JERRY B.

description: This is a pretty good burrito place in the Mission District but not sure why all the hype given the amount of good taquerias in this area of SF.  My gf and I went at night by bus and when you walk in there's a security guard to greet you.  Being the true hedonist glutton that I am when it comes to food, I got a carne asada AND carnitas burrito.  I was STFU.  Stuffed. the. f. up.  Just in time for the mariachi band to come in and serenade the entire place by standing right in front of us thereby giving us front row seats.  I coughed up a couple of dollar bills for the tip and possibly part of a burrito and went by merry way to be harrassed by the bums near the 16th st. BART station.  Ah, the mission by night.
author: William J.

description: High Prices, small burritos. I used to go there all the time, but not anymore.   I I have been going to El Farolito  on 2779 Mission St, (24th and mission) and I get a fat super burrito for around $5 bucks.  A regular burrito at Pancho Villa Taqueria is like $7 bucks. La Cornetta on 23rd and Mission I think is the best of all though.  I like to go to  can go to La Cornetta and get a nice sized taco and a soda for around five bucks.
author: Sydney A.

description: Ok, why is this place always so crowded all the time? If you want the taco bell of the mission, look no further. El Farolito is much better, geez, even Taqueria Cancun is.
author: John B.

description:
my favourite burrito in the mission

which i know is odd

since there are so many choices

i like the K burrito

nachos rock

and they have excellent refrescos
author: Eva S.

description:
mariachi.  check.
(completely unnecessary) security guard. check.
("award winning") salsa bar.  check.
huge menu.  check.
gut busting burritos.  check.

i heart negra modelo and therefore i heart pancho villa.   don't forget to tip the mariachi.
author: Eric L.

description:
This is one of the best Mexican restaurants ever.  Pancho Villa has great food, served efficiently by a pleasant staff and at great prices.  Try the garlic prawn dinner but ask for a take-home container because you won't be able to eat it all in the restaurant.  Their salsa bar is also special: their own award-winning recipes and a variety for every taste from maximum hot to mild.  

The crowd is usually Mission funky and the ambiance is loud but fun. But I hate the stools that they use instead of chairs.  I have a bad back and the stools kill me.  Also I suspect that they use them to move the customers on thru at a good speed.  But I always return because it is such a great place.  There's also a good parking garage around the corner because you will never find anything on 16th St.

P.S. One time there I got distracted by a friend at the cash register and took my tray to a table, my wallet still on the counter.  Instead of leaving it to its fate--next customer pocketing it, etc.--as many restaurants would, the manager grabbed it and put it under the counter.  When I eventually went back for it, he happily gave it to me and I was greatly relieved and knew that Pancho Villa had a customer for life.
author: Murray S.

description: I actually love this place. I know it's Gringo of me.  My boyfriend, who's Mexican, complains that the food isn't very authentic-tasting, but I find myself going back for a burrito a time or two very month (and so does he).  Their salsa roja is amazing and nicely spicy.
author: Jay S.

description: I moved from SF to NYC a few years ago, and Pancho Villa is always one of my first stops when I come back to visit. I have yet to find a taqueria, east or west, that compares. The ingredients are fresh, tasty and authentic, burritos are big enough for two meals, and there are so many choices that everyone's happy! I'm hungry just thinking about it!
author: Danielle F.

description: ok, so it's not a typical sit down mexican place, but it probably serves one of the best fajitas i've ever had.  it's kind of like a cafeteria-style restaurant.  i went here with my wife about 10 pm one night; not expecting too much, i ordered the fajita platter with steak chicken and shrimp.  when the guy in front of me in line saw what i ordered, he was mesmorized and said, damn, i should have ordered that.  the aroma and the sheer size of that fajita platter was overpowering.  i must say, it definitely is one of the best fajita platters i've ever had and it comes from an authentic mexican eatery, not a chain place.  for mexican food lovers, try this place out, you'll be satisfied.  parking is hard to find since it is street parking, so expect to circle around for awhile
author: will m.

description: Reasonable price.  A good mariachi band on the side while you're enjoying your tightly wrapped al pastor, lengua, carne asada burrito.  Located in the heart of the Mission with a lot of good bars nearby.  It does not compare to Las Mesas (a defunct taqueria in the Lower Haight), but still better than most taquerias.
author: Maricar M.

description:
I was at Pancho Villa on Tues night after MacWorld Expo. I ordered 2 grilled chicken tacos & added a bunch of the roasted jalapeno salsa & the green salsa (it's hotter than it looks). Squoze on a little lime juice. Grabbed a malta from the bodega ons the corner of 16 & Valencia. My mouth was in heaven!

I used to drive all the way from Cupertino to the Mission to eat at Taqueria La Cumbre, around the corner on Valencia. At some point I gave Pancho Villa a try. Now I'm a convert.

Last year I happened to see their new location on the Embaracdero about 2 days after it opened. It looked like a couple of white guys running the place, but the help was Hispanic & the food the just as good as the 16th street location.
author: Lynn D.

description: Can't say enough about their carne asada and al pastor (pork taco)dishes!! Very affordable and a great location in the Mission District if you're looking for a lively vibe.
author: John c.

description: Prices are mostly reasonable for what ya get.  I had the tacos and I was happy with the taste.  My friend got the Pura Carnitas(ALL meat burrito) and I must say it was too much beef for him.  I won't bitch and moan like most about the salsa.  It was about average over all.
author: Kristi B.

description: always amazed at how clean the place is with the amount of business they do.  So many great taquerias in the mission, but this is always so reliably  good.
author: herb w.

description: They have two types of vegetarian tacos: tofu and vegetable. Only about $2. Great find.
author: Jaime R.

description: I could probably eat Mexican food everyday and be happy, but I'm picky about where I get my Mexican food from.  Since I work around the corner, this spot is my saving grace, as I go at least once a week for lunch.  I usually order a Carnitas baby burrito, and I can't even eat all of it.  If you're in the area and hungry, go to Pancho Villas.
author: Jenessa L.

description: Pancho villa is amazing!  It's by far my favorite taqueria in the city.
author: Sesily M.

description: The best mexican food in San Francisco! They have a variety of meats and salsa's and you easily build your own lunch or dinner they way you like it. On the wall, you will note many awards they have won for their salsa's. You have to try the tomatillo green salsa, it is my favorite. Every time we have come in, there is a small line which tells you that they're making the food right, and the customers keep coming back! This location is a must if you love Mexican food!
author: Michael Y.

description: this place is a godsend. really over the top excellent, efficient, friendly service. i always order the steak nachos. yum. right now i'm absolutely sick of burritos. but i eat those steak nachos just about every other day and i still love them. thank you pancho villa for raising the bar for a taqueria joint. lots of seating. clean. cool artwork. i can't express how much i love this place in words.
author: Jessica M.

description: The place to go for Prawn tacos!!! My fav. mexican place, no doubt.
author: Milli G.

description: just went there last night...any mexican place that has refried BLACK beans is alright in my book...definitely one of the better I have been to in SF...especially since everyone thinks they know the best burrito place here...
author: Eric L.

description: I went here because a friend of mine dragged me here. And it's OK don't get me wrong. But this place PALES compared to Taqueria Guadalajara on 24th Street!
author: Anthony H.

description: good, moderately-priced veggie burrito... conveniently located next to a bunch of bars where I like to hit on boys who ride bikes worth more than my kidneys on the black market.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description: best happy hour prices in san francisco! their carne asada is to die for! i love the $1 tacos, so go there if you are on a budget and want to get your grub on! i love carnitas, but theirs are juicy and soft...i like a bit of a crisp on mine. it doesn't stop me from having one, but that's it. if you really want to treat yourself to a yummy surf and turf burrito, go here, they have a crazy prawn and steak burrito that is so tasty you can't stop at one bite-just make sure to wear pants with an elastic wiastband...
author: rachel anne p.

description: dirty ass burrito joint in the mission. it's a pretty tasty burrito joint, better than McMexi but it churns out too many and i don't think they can keep up with fresh ingredients. granted we were there on a Friday night so there was a huge line but the chicken open face burrito my friend got had chunks of raw chicken. My Steak burrito was decent but nothing i would go across town for and the salsa bar was nasty dirty. Good thing we were pretty drunk so the alcohol could kill anything we might have caught here. it is not clean, even a little.
author: Stephen K.

description: Happened to be in the neighborhood today as my wife's car was in the shop for service a couple of blocks away. I caught BART to 16th and Mission and walked up 16th and as I passed by I stumbled upon some really good aromas coming from Pancho Villa's. I peeked in the window and saw where those good smells were coming from and decided it was lunch time! I hadn't eaten yet except for a breakfast banana and I was going to need nourishment before tonight's Democratic party debate. Should be a barn burner. Anyway, I digress. I walked toward the door and the security guard opened it for me. I don't recall ever having eaten at a place that had a security guard. Although I've been to some places that NEEDED one or two. It was cool though as the place was clean, bright and everything behind the counter looked good. I did have to ask a lovely stranger where I was supposed to place my order. I'm sure for the regulars it was quite obvious.  I never said I was smart. (Start near the grill.) I ordered an Al Pastor Especial Burrito to go. I had to dash off to pick up the car before the shop closed. I didn't eat it until I got home which was a torturous wait. It was very good! The Al Pastor wasn't as tasty as Tacos El Grullense in Hayward but no complaints here.  I'll have to find another excuse to get back over there. Now I am ready for tonight's debate.
author: Neal A.

description: Came here today and had a chicken asada quesadilla and chicken baby burrito between me and my friend. the portions are quite large for 2 asian girls but it was so good that we gobbled both down. very fresh and tasty ingredients for a cheap price! i'm not much for mexican food but i'd come back here again if i'm ever in the area again craving a quesadilla.
author: Ellie Y.

description: For years I have been coming here and bringing everyone to this particular casual tacqueria.  Great salsa, excellent al pastor, carnitas, chile rellenos, and vegetarian dishes.  I heard the seafood is good too.  Everything was/is always fresh and the service quick.  The plates are my favorites.
author: Mara O.

description: I've known of this place since I actually grew up next door to it! If you want real CLEAN mexican food in the city then this is where you need to go. You can always find the best Frescas here too! No matter what you pick on the menu, you wont be disappointed
author: Fat L.

description: best damn burrito, period. i just wish it wasn't so CROWDED
author: Ron O.

description: if there is one Mexican restaurant which does business volume in the city, its Pancho Villa. i mean, can someone tell me what time they are slow? they have 25+ customers at 11:30pm at nite!! & thats on a Tue nite...a slooooooowww nite for my restaurant! what the hell. we are in the wrong business, guys! anyway, love this place.
author: Sha A.

description: So, I was having a shitty night. I had just braved far too much traffic to meet one of my friends, only to find out that she totally piked and basically fucked up my evening. Fortunately, another of my friends wanted to hang out. Needless to say, I was in a foul mood and all I wanted was some good food and a beer. My friend's solution: Pancho Villa. I admit, I was a little skeptical because the one in the Embarcadero is NOT good. But I said ok. So, we trek from the Castro to Pancho Villa. They have SO many meat options. I opted for a spicy chicken burrito. mmmmm. good. And with a beer, even better. Everything in the burrito was well seasoned, extremely flavorful and very easy to eat without coming up for air. Their salsa bar is fantastic. They had some cactus concoction that was fabulous. If I hadn't gorged myself on the burrito, I probably would have had far more than I did. Also, they don't use lard, which is a major plus for me. This is definitely a place I plan on frequenting more.
author: Veronica W.

description: I eat a lot of burritos. I'm not talking once a month or "a lot of burritos for a white guy". I'm talking about an assload of burritos: at least three times a week, maybe more (and yes, my cholesterol is 130, thank you very much). Also, I live in the Mission. I am not looking for atmosphere or plants on the tables when I want Mexican food. Pancho Villa is the REAL DEAL. It's better than El Faro, El Toro, La Cumbre, Puerto Allegre, La Taqueria, blah, blah, blah. Pancho has high quality carne asada, real guacamole, fresh vegetables and nice staff. The only burrito that used to compare favorably is a place in the financial district called Pepitos. I loved Pepitos. I would kill for Pepitos. On lonely nights I curl up in bed, under the covers and cry myself to sleep thinking about why Pepitos is no longer around. Alas! I will keep my hope alive. I will continue to search for the ultimate burrito experience. I will know love again!
author: Mike B.

description: super vegetarian and a beer. what else do you need? oh yeah dolores park. their burritos are so good and the security guy at the door holds the door open for everyone and keeps it closed in between to keep you warm in their huge line (that goes quick, don't worry). i love iiiiiiittttttttttf
author: Kelly H.

description: Someday, the interviewers at National Galactica will be able to trace the extent of my wisdom and considerable interspace influence by the gaudiness of the art I keep in my homes.  The Last Supper, velvet-tized and hanging next to a ridiculously oversized crucifix? Not my fancy, but as long as it screams, "Questionable taste!?!?!" I shall have it on display. So after a few occasions of staring at the large painting of Senor Villa at the aforementioned joint on 16th, I made it my goal to have that picture, perhaps an even bigger and less faithfully rendered version, in my possession at some point in the not-so-distant future.  You can't help but get an eyeful here. It's a sensory inundation, from the smells of frying carne asada to the glaring overhead lights to the contained (sometimes not) roar of people stepping in for a bite from the bars. If you could ever consider a taqueria in an area of the city where taquerias run as rampant as tossed cigarette butts, this would be the seen and be-seen destination. Maybe a "hipsteria" . . .
author: Kimberly V.

description: The Target of taquerias. Does this even qualify as a taqueria? For me, it more closely resembles a bona-fide sit-down traditional restaurant or, at the very least, a slightly fancier cafeteria. There's even cute artwork on the walls. Pancho is slightly pricier than other taquerias in the Mission, but you get a ton of food for what you pay for. Thank goodness I came here with a friend! The rent-a-cop stationed at the door amuses me. I'd expect "incidents" to happen at other taquerias, but not here for some reason. In any case, this is a "special occasion" taqueria. I won't be going here for casual lunches, get-togethers with my friends, or post-boozy satisfaction. Here's a place to enjoy a true-blue meal and some good conversation.
author: Joseph R.

description: Tofu Ranchero burrito was off the freaking hook! So awesome! Cantaloupe juice was so effing good. Salsa, this place is muy super bueno. Muchas gracias por lo mejor taqueria.
author: Martin G.

description: I look inside the restaurant and I see tons of people.  I think to myself, "this place must be good."  NOT! I ordered 3 burritos for my friends and I and we were all disappointed.  Terrible!
author: Nick H.

description: my go to Mexican in the Mission. regular burrito with Chkn, black beans, & avocado...delish.
author: dha A.

description: pancho villa is my absolute favorite taqueria around.  i've tried a bunch of their different burritos, and every one was amazing.  from the grilled chicken, to the barbecued pork, to the spicy chicken... all of it was great.  plus, they have refried black beans. i definitely have'nt seen that in many taquerias around town.  plus, their salsa is incredible.  they have a ton of different kinds, and they're *all* really good.  especially the one that's all tangy and sour.. YUM.
author: vlad k.

description: So delicious, totally non greasy with a very fresh taste. This is one of my hands down favorite restaurants anywhere.
author: R B.

description: Easily one of the better burritos I've had in the city -- the options are pretty much limitless, and they do it right.  The tacos are really good too.  They also have a pretty large salsa bar.
author: Luke P.

description: way too expensive for a burrito but this is the only place where ill get carnitas, WHICH is soo good and flavorful,  with avocado, OMG it is so good.  my mouth is watering right now!
author: regan g.

description: this place used to be good.  went in the other day and they have a shiny new menu that comes with shiny new prices.  i was charged $6.08 for a bean and cheese burrito with avocado.  UNACCEPTABLE.
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description: I always rely on the super Quesadilla.  One of the best in the city, and we got a load of Mexican restaurants.
author: Antony E.

description: Totally overrated burrito place. They do not put the ingredients on to the tortilla in the correct order. La Cumbre, around the corner is much better. Why is everybody like "you have to go to Pancho Villa" to out-of-towners when they visit?
author: Ben B.

description: its always a good meal. sometimes you wait a bit longer than i'd like but its worth it. the food is amazing and well priced.
author: Andrew D.

description: I really enjoy the food here.  The burritos totally satisfy my Mexican junk food cravings.  When I want pure, simple, high quality Mexican, I go elsewhere.  When I want to binge on a yummy burrito with all the frills like sour cream, guacamole, and cheese, I come here.  One of my favorite things is the salsa bar.  I think Mexican salsa is one of my favorite foods, which is hard for me to believe because it is all vegetables.  They have 5 or 6 kinds here, so I can dip my burrito in alternating ramekins of salsa and get a different taste each time.  I love dipping food in sauces; I think condiments in general are my favorite foods.  Yummm......dipping food in other food.......yummmmmmmm
author: t l.

description: Authentic "Mission Style" Burrito's. Unique to the Bay Area. I like the Super Carne Asada personally. The nachos and tacos are pretty darn good there as well. Friendly staff will encourage you to practice your Spanish. The spicy salsa is the real deal.
author: Ben C.

description: this was my first mission taqueria after moving here, and it definitely helped me realize why the neighborhood has earned a reputation for excellent mexican fare. however, i had a feeling this wasn't the cheapest good mexican food to be had in the neighborhood, and i was right. but when i sat down to eat, a mariachi singer in head-to-toe polyester wheeled in his rudimentary sound system and began singing latin classics next to me. it was one of those moments that i felt acutely aware that i was in a new place with new experiences--dc just doesn't have mariachi troubadours.
author: Marla W.

description: The burritos here are the tastiest in the City. The prawn burrito is muy bueno with the chicken burrito coming in at a close second.
author: Mama L.

description: Why eat at a mediocre taqueria where the burritos are prepared by scooping meat that was prepared hours ago out of a bin onto a rubbery steamed tortilla when you can walk an extra 5 minutes to get a good burrito?  I'm surprised that a place like this can stay in business with mediocre food and high prices.  Must be the fact that they are so close to bars and pick up the foot traffic of drunk people who will eat anything edible.  If you must go here, don't order the chile relleno unless you want to know what the worlds worst chile relleno tastes like.
author: Jose W.

description: I ate Taco Bell the other day just for kicks and I felt sick, like I had food poisoning. I blame you Pancho Villa. Why do you have to be so good you mofo?
author: Hmmm W.

description: best burritos...reason enough to move back to the bay area!
author: Diane I.

description: yes!  i had the most amazing super veggie burrito just a few days ago.  watch out for the jalepenos, though.  they don't cut 'em small and they don't skimp on 'em either.
author: Aimee C.

description: Seriously, what is the big deal about this place?  You see the commercials, the awards, the long lines, etc, etc...but where is the good food?  They aren't bad but they certainly don't live up to the hype.  Everytime I go here I get a mismatch burrito full of cold and hot ingredients.  How about keeping your food a little hotter so the cheese melts all the way through, so the guac doesn't taste fresh out the fridge?  It's hard to explain but here the ingredients just don't blend well.  And especially being in the Mission?  C'mon folks, there are MANY better places out there.  Try Guadalajara or El Farolito on Mission and Onondaga.  They're across the street from each other but you can't go wrong at either place.  They don't have the long lines like Pancho Villa (which IS a good thing after all) but I guarantee the food is ridiculously better.  And they won't charge $8 for a fuckin burrito.
author: O'Shea J.

description:
an extra star for filling my mexican craving ... 

you can't blame me for my "harsh, real review" 

i'm from LA...

mexican food = LA or SD ... *hands DOWNNNNNNNN*

sry SF ... yea, it was edible, but it sure didn't taste a bit authentic AT ALL... their salsa did...

another star for the size of the supreme burrito ... great size for anyone who's starving to the point of feeding 2 homies in ur tummy... their carnita was sweet? how is carnita supposed to be sweet? bleh...
their fish taco tasted like baja fresh's, but it was still good...

their salsa, ooh, i heart their spices, it truly left me sweatin for more...

prices were relatively average, considering we're in SF. i'm trying a different taqueria...
author: Jennifer S.

description: a little better than average. decent prices, fairly quick, pretty wide selection of options. not as good as el farolito, but it works when i'm too lazy to walk 8 more blocks.
author: Kevin L.

description: yummy, one of my favorite taquerias in the city. i love the garlic shrimp they fry up in front of you.
author: Jacqui M.

description: i love you san francisco burrito! i love going to pancho villa. it's really consistent and who else has tofu on the menu, seriously? oh, and cream filled churros. it's not always crowded, you just have to know when to go. if only my burrito could stay warm on the bart ride home...
author: Oleya P.

description: I pass this restaurant every day on my way home from Bart, and it's almost always crowded.  The food's pretty decent, and the menu is certainly expansive.  I think they have about 16 different kinds of meat for your burrito/taco/enchilada/other mexican combination of rice, beans, meat, and/or cheese.  And the prices are pretty good, too.  My favorite is the super baby burrito, which means that you get all the good stuff but in a perfectly sized package, instead of one of those enormous burritos where you try to save the second half for your next meal but the tortilla falls apart and you have to stuff the whole thing down your throat before it disintegrates.  That said, better mexican food can be found, it being in the mission and all.  It's a nice, big, comfortable place with an unintimidating english menu and a hot stop for drunk mission partiers on the weekend, but it won't be the best burrito you've ever eaten.
author: Rachel B.

description: tofu burrito?  weird, but it's still a good place to eat.  i like the shrimp tacos.  yum!
author: jen b.

description:
had a carne asada taco, an al pastor taco and their super burrito with carne asada. 

sure it was good standard mexican food, but i think i will try their other dishes next time i'm in the area. 

or if i want burritos/tacos I will go to el farolito or san francisco tacquiera where the meat doesnt sit in metal bins on top of warm water/steam and get dried out. but i like their salsa with the red pepper in it !
author: Porkers T.

description: i tried the tacos here and was pretty unimpressed.  they use simple ingredients -- lettuce, tomato, meat, avocado, etc.  it tastes pretty clean, but more american-style mexican food than anything.  i might come again just because it's convenient, but there are much better mexican restaurants in the mission.
author: Robyn F.

description: the lady who works the register is such a sweetheart! and she hooks it up with the chips!
author: Jo L.

description: Burritos with really good flavor, and huge selection.  My favorite at this taqueria is the grilled vegetable.  Also has very good salsas.
author: Mike R.

description: "ok, I dont know where to begin with this place, I've been going here for so long.  first: dont go to the one down by the ferry building, it is simply not as good.  second, its delicious.  pretty much everything is good with my personal favorites being all the burritos.  I honestly I cannot recommend any one particular thing at this place since it all, across the board, yummy.  well actually I can recommend one thing: talking to the autistic table cleaning guy.  that homeboy is amazing, if you tell him the date of your birthday he can tell you exactly home many days its been since your birthday, home many days till your next birthday, and how many total days old you are, all in a matter of seconds. thats awesome."
author: greg B.

description: the Pancho Villa in San Mateo is way better.
author: Lisa Marie G.

description: what's with all the hype?  i got this taco. man it was little.  and man it was not that great.  what i would expect for 2 bucks.  do i need to be drunk or coming from a foodless party or come super late night to rave about this place?  i mean the people are cool and make sure they make it your way, but it's just all right.
author: Monk R.

description: Doesn't stand up to El Farolito or La Taqueria, but still a solid burrito.
author: Tom S.

description: Highly recommend the super-vegetariano mojado (wet) style (they cover the burrito with a savory sauce). Yummy food and yummier salsa's. Value for money. Great for grabbing a quick bite
author: Nilofer M.

description: I loved this place when I first moved to the city. . . Then it became commercialized and the food suffered a bit.  Still one of the best Taquerias in sf, but the decline in taste gives it 3 stars
author: Elizabeth F.

description: When I lived in San Francisco, this place was a Sunday ritual.  They have some of the best Mexican food anywhere.  I was totally addicted to the spicy whole bean carne asada burritos... and they even have Mexican Coke/Pepsi in glass bottles. Even though I live further south these days, I always make it a point to swing by Pancho Villa's whenever I'm in San Francisco.
author: Geo M.

description: meh. lacking in taco-stand charm, pancho villa is not only too big, too crowded, and too clean to be a taqueria of any importance...it just doesn't taste authentic. although their back wall proudly displays awards won for their salsa, i was sorely disappointed. i like my salsa to be HOT, and theirs had a lot of seasonings...but it was extremely mild and tame. again, meh. definitely a gringo trap.
author: Kayla K.

description: With a bad roach experience at Cancun, I had to really be picky about the cleanliness and consistency of my burrito homies. These guys do well when I order my Pura Carne on my beefatarian nights. Keep up the great work guys.
author: Daniel C.

description: why do people eat here?  is it because they've never had good mexican food before and they think this is all there is?  i just don't get it.
author: a g.

description: pretty ordinary burrito joint in the Mission..it's run like a total assembly line and the place is super popular...I frequent it once in awhile but I never have a craving for Pancho Villa...it's always because I'm drunk and just need some protein...and it's location is so perfect.
author: Adrian H.

description: Though the Mission kids tend to throw rocks at me when I visit their neighborhood,  I would endure their yuppie hatred to trek across SF to Pancho Villas.  I stopped into this place around 11:00pm one night and the place was slammed.  I had the carne asada burrito with all the fixins, and it wasn't bad at all.  Having grown up in Southern California, Mexican food was a staple of my diet since I was old enough to mispronounce "quesadilla," and I have a pretty discerning palate.   If I had been drunk when I went to eat here, I probably would have given the place five stars.  Unfortunately, Pancho Villa, you caught me in a rare sober moment.
author: Jason B.

description: no matter how long the line, don't be intimidated. you will be through that sucker in no time. delicious burritos, lots and lots of options on the menu, and pretty well-priced. i don't know why i don't go here more often.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
just my %0.02-----
convenient to 16th st bart.
if you are looking for upscale  food and ambiance don't come here

my combo of carne asada and grilled shrimp was $14?? both the steak and shrimp were fresh and well seasoned so i got over the sticker shock as i'm scarfing down my tasty food. next time im here i wanna try one of their burritos.

the crush of peeps (hipsters, locals, crack heads, and the occasional tourist) ordering their food can be daunting, but the ladies and gents behind the counter are speedy and efficient.
author: Amber A.

description: the line for this place is massive...but it goes fast. the burritos are thick and delicious. the salsa bar is crap! i need fresh tomato salsa. not that runny crap!  price is okay, it's crowded, but i always get a seat after a minute, and i run into people i know all the time.
author: Ann M.

description: when the burrito was born, pancho villa taqueria delivered it. these guys really know their stuff. i judge other taquerias based on pvt; they are the defacto standard on burritos and tacos. and their salsa, oh boy, their pico de gallo is the best!
author: papa c.

description: God only knows why I love this place so much. In a lot of ways this is like the McDonalds of taquerias in the mission. It is like a well oiled machine of matching uniforms, hair nets, and carne asada smoke. It's not necessarily what you would call an 'authentic experience'. You know why I love it though? Because I don't care about an authentic experience in the Mission. I care about really good shrimp tacos, and cleanliness. I realize everyone else is talking about how dirty this place is. Have you been to any other taquerias in the mission? This place even has a door man for crying out loud! And as much as I love Los Jarritos, I once got a burrito there on a hot day that had curdled sour cream in it.:x That would never happen at Pancho Villa. Not to mention they dont flinch when i ask for a 'baby' burrito with a 'whole wheat' tortilla and 'extra' avocado etc etc. and it is always reliably tasty. Yeah I'm one of those jerks.
author: Carly S.

description: From San Diego, I know Mexican food. This place is great, clean, always has seating and fresh chips and salsa. Mahi Mahi and Swordfish burritos are the best!
author: K T.

description: Plenty of vegetarian options plus mexican band playing now and then. What more is there to ask for? Uhm, comfortable chairs, maybe.
author: Linda M.

description:
spicy chicken and prawn burrito!  so good!
one of the best mexican places in the city and inexpensive too!
author: Angela C.

description: Great selection of salsas.  I like to get the burrito especial with carne asada.
author: Bryan J.

description: This is my girlfriend's favorite place for a burrito when visiting San Francisco. The portions are huge and the salsa doesn't get much better. This is one place I will truly miss in San Francisco.
author: Jarad B.

description: the only thing that would make this place more perfecter would be if you didnt have to walk by crack-heads to get there.
author: stella s.

description: so i'm originally from la and we have some pretty good mexican resturants, but this place takes the cake. their tongue tacos are the best things i've ever tasted, their tortas are better then any other places out here and their steak and pawn quesadillas are two died for. and i have to begin everyone who visits me here.  i love pancho villa
author: Star C.

description: This place is such a treat for anyone visiting from outside of California who doesn't have access to great taquerias.  I love the ambiance of this place; every time I walk in the door I feel like I'm in Mexico on vacation.  The prices are reasonable and the food is consistently good.  I've been here twenty times and never had a bad experience.
author: Michael M.

description: I've had better Mexican food. Honestly, I think this place is quite overpriced for its quality. The burrito was small and it was ~7 for a regular sized one. Not to mention, sour cream, cheese, salsa, etc. were considered sides and were charged additionally. I'd pick Gordo over this anytime.
author: Dianne I.

description: Finest burrito in California, Please someone dispute that....Inside scoop- if you can pretend to be a beaner and speak Spanish, they hook you up super hard-
author: Michael V.

description: This place might as well be my living room, but its like my living room when I lived at home with my mom- b/c as nice as it is there are some serious flaws. I use to really love their burritos like about five years ago & now I do sometimes. The problem is that the burritos aren't consistently good. Now I'm lucky to get that really good burrito I love 1/10 time I go, and when I do its really skimpy. The prices have also increased tremendously. A vegetarian burrito has cost me $10 numerous times now, and been really small. If I'm going to spend ten dollars on a burrito I need to be in a restaurant where I get a side of yummy rice & beans, can get a dozen Margaritas, and some table service. They must be confused? Ten dollars for a burrito? & No its not organic, wtf? There is one lady who consistently makes the best burritos (but still small), but everyone is on to that fact & does everything they can to get her. I've seen numerous people pretend to not be ready in hopes of getting her- I've done it myself, & this just isn't true- everyone knows what they want before they get there. I find myself going across the street to los coyotes even more lately.
author: Brandi S.

description: open late.  cheap fish tacos with fish they actually cook FRESH (*gasp*).  all v. good..but minus one star because I wished the chips were saltier.
author: jozilla w.

description: my all time favorite mexican place.  why don't everywhere else have black beans...  i know... i've been told there's no black beans in mexico.  just like there's no sweet and sour pork in china, but it's in every stinkin chinese restaurant.  get with it East Bay...  Black Beans all around on me...
author: Jeanie L.
